ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-4-1. - Scope. 
This chapter shall govern acquisitions by the city of commodities, equipment, and services. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 2-4-2. - Purpose. 
This chapter shall be construed and applied to promote its underlying purposes and policies which are: 
(1)  To foster effective, fair and broad-based competition for public procurement within the free enterprise system; and 
(2)  To provide safeguards for the maintenance of quality, integrity and equity in the purchasing process of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 2-4-3. - Application of federal and state law. 
It is intended that this chapter shall conform to all applicable provisions of the laws of the United States and of the state, and the provisions hereof shall be so construed wherever possible. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the city may enter into contracts, follow any procedure, or take any action which is otherwise at variance with this chapter if required as a condition to receiving funds from the State of Georgia or the United States Government. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 2-4-4. - Budgeted expenditures and expenses. 
It is the responsibility of the department director to ensure all purchases are consistent with and support the current approved budget prior to committing funds. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 2-4-5. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, or phrases, when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Acquisition means a transaction in which the city purchases, orders, contracts for, or otherwise agrees to obtain for value any commodity, service, real property or combination thereof. 
Active vendor status means a vendor has completed and returned all necessary documents and met requirements according to the city's vendor program policy and procedures. 
Bid means submission of information from an offeror that describes the offeror's commodities or services, and any other information necessary to respond to the specifications and other requirements set forth in a request for bids. 
Bid bond means a bond with good and sufficient surety or sureties for the faithful acceptance of the contract payable to, in favor of, and for the protection of the city. 
City means City of Gainesville, Georgia. 
Commodity means a discrete and distinct item of tangible personal property, including, without limitation, any such item that is intended to become an integrated part of another item of tangible personal property or of any improvement to real property, but not including after incorporation into another item of personal property or real property in a manner which ends to separate character as personality under the law. 
Confidential information means any information that is available to an employee because of the employee's status as an employee of the city and is not a matter of public knowledge or available to the public on request. 
Contract means any agreement, purchase order, lease, or other document which creates or intended to create binding reciprocal obligations including, without limitation, any document evidencing a bid or proposal award that has been accepted by the offeror. 
Contractor means any person who is party to a contract, except the city. 
Day(s) means calendar day(s) unless otherwise stated. 
Employee/official means an individual drawing a salary or wages from the city, whether elected or not; any noncompensated individual performing personal services for the city or any department, agency, commission, council, board, or any other entity established by the executive or legislative branch of the city; and any noncompensated individual serving as an elected official of the city. 
Gratuity means a payment, loan, subscription, advance, deposit of money, service or anything of more than nominal value, present or promised, unless consideration of substantially equal or greater value is received. 
Invitation to bid means all information and documentation disseminated by the city to solicit bids. 
Local vendor means a bidder or offeror which operates and maintains a brick and mortar business, i.e., a physical business address, within the city limits of the City of Gainesville, has a current business license, has paid in full all real and personal taxes owed the city, is considered a vendor in good standing with the city and can obtain an active vendor status. 
Offeror means any person who has submitted a bid or proposal to the city or otherwise offered to form a contract with the city. 
Person means any individual or legal entity. 
Proposal means submission of information from an offeror (including a consultant) which states how that offeror intends to fulfill the specifications and other requirements described in a request for proposals. 
Purchasing manager means the employee designated by the city to review purchase requests and bids, make purchasing recommendations, and ensure that employees of the city comply with rules, regulations, and laws relating to purchasing. 
Request for proposals means all information and documentation disseminated by the city to solicit proposals. 
Responsive bidder or offeror means a person who has submitted a bid or proposal that conforms in all material respects to the requirements set forth in the invitation. 
Services means the furnishing of labor, time or effort by a contractor which is not intended to accomplish the delivery of a specified tangible product other than reports that are merely incidental to the required performance, including, without limitation, a professional or consulting service. 
Specification means, in connection with a request for bids or request for proposals, a list of the characteristics of the commodities or services that will meet the city's requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16) 
Secs. 2-4-6—2-4-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 2. - PROCUREMENT ORGANIZATION 

Sec. 2-4-11. - Procurement procedures. 
The purchasing manager is authorized to establish, implement and enforce written operational procedures relating to procurement and contractual arrangements on behalf of the city. Such procedures shall, to the extent consistent with applicable law, be based upon generally accepted public purchasing principles and practices and shall become effective upon approval by the chief financial officer and the city manager. These procedures may be revised, as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 2-4-12. - Parks and recreation. 
The city parks and recreation board was established as a legally separate entity through a special election in 1924 and operates pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq., and is given the same status with parks and recreation transactions relative to purchasing as the city council has with respect to other city departments. The parks and recreation director, under full authority of the city parks and recreation board, is the chief executive officer and is given the same status with parks and recreation transactions relative to purchasing as the city manager has with respect to other city departments. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16) 
Secs. 2-4-13—2-4-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 3. - SOURCE SELECTION 

Sec. 2-4-16. - Protests. 
(a)  If a vendor or bidder/offeror may be aggrieved by any aspect of a solicitation, the vendor or bidder/offeror must protest in accordance with this section. 
(b)  Bidders/offerors may protest the contract award in connection with the invitation to bid/request for proposal on which the bidder/offeror has submitted a bid/proposal. Any such protest must be filed no later than ten (10) days following the date of the notice of award or purchase order. Vendors who do not submit a timely bid proposal may not protest the contract. 
(c)  Protests pertaining to events or facts arising during the solicitation process, including, but not limited to, specifications, must be filed no later than two (2) business days prior to the bid opening or proposal due date. 
(d)  Issues not raised in the initial protest may at the discretion of the city be deemed waived with prejudice by the protestor. 
(e)  A protest is filed when a written protest signed by a company officer authorized to sign contracts on behalf of the vendor is received by the purchasing manager or designee. 
(f)  A written protest shall include as a minimum the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the protestor; 
(2)  Appropriate identification of the solicitation; 
(3)  A statement of the reasons for the protest; 
(4)  Supporting exhibits, evidence, or documents to substantiate any claims unless not available within the filing time; in which case the expected availability date shall be indicated. 
(g)  Stay of procurement during protest. 
(1)  When a protest pertaining to events or facts arising during the solicitation process, such as protests concerning specifications and evaluation criteria, has been timely filed at least two (2) business days prior to the bid opening or proposal deadline date, the city shall make no award of a contract until a final decision has been issued, unless the purchasing manager makes a written determination, after consulting with the user department, that the award of the contract without delay is necessary to protect the interests of the city. 
(2)  When a protest has been filed in a timely fashion within ten (10) calendar days following the issuance of a contract award, the purchasing manager shall consult with the user department to determine if performance of the contract without delay is necessary to protect the interests of the city. If it is determined that it is necessary to proceed with contract performance without delay, the bidder/offeror with this contingent contract may proceed with performance and receive payment for work performed in strict accordance with the terms of the contract; however, such bidder/offeror shall not be entitled to reimbursement for any capital outlay costs, or other up front expenses incurred in performing the contract. 
(h)  Decision by purchasing manager. A decision on a protest shall be made by the purchasing manager as expeditiously as possible after receiving all relevant requested information. If a protest is sustained, the available remedies include: 
(1)  If a protest is sustained prior to an award: modification of the solicitation document, including but not limited to specifications, terms and conditions and evaluation criteria, and extension of the opening date if appropriate. 
(2)  If a protest is sustained after an award is made: suspension or cancellation of the award, re-evaluation and re-award or re-solicitation with appropriate changes to the new solicitation document. 
(i)  Request for formal review. 
(1)  If a protestor or user department disagrees with the decision of the purchasing manager, the protestor or user department may request a formal review of the decision by the chief financial officer or designee within three (3) days of the date of the purchasing manager's decision. The request for formal review shall contain a detailed statement of the factual and legal grounds upon which reversal or modification is deemed warranted, specifying any errors in the purchasing manager's decision. The chief financial officer or designee may, in his/her sole discretion, allow the protestor to make an oral presentation, and may solicit whatever other information he/she deems appropriate. 
(2)  The decision of the chief financial officer or designee shall be final. 
(j)  Recovery of costs. In no event shall a protestor be entitled to recover any costs incurred in connection with the solicitation, including bid/proposal preparation costs or attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 2-4-17. - Local vendor preference. 
(a)  Opportunity to match. For purchases, bids, proposals or contracts at twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) or more and less than one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00), the local vendor may be given an opportunity to match the lowest price proposal, if the quotation or bid of the local vendor is within three (3) percent of the lowest price proposal by a nonlocal vendor. In the event a local vendor matches the lowest price proposal, including all other terms, quality, service and conditions, then the local vendor shall be awarded the contract. 
(b)  Multiple local vendors. In the event the price proposal of more than one (1) local vendor is within three (3) percent of the lowest overall price proposal of a nonlocal vendor, the local vendor with the lowest proposal will be given the first opportunity to match the lowest overall price proposal. If this local vendor declines to match the price proposal, then the local vendor with the next lowest bid within three (3) percent will be given the opportunity to match the lowest proposal. This process will continue with all local vendors having proposals within three (3) percent of the lowest overall bid by a nonlocal vendor. 
(c)  Policy to be stated. This policy shall be so stated in all applicable solicitations. 
(d)  Exemptions. This provision does not apply to public works construction projects or road projects pursuant to the laws of the State of Georgia or other situations to be found in conflict with federal or state laws or granting agency contracts. 
(Ord. No. 2016-27, § II, 12-20-16)

CHAPTER 3-1. - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Public safety, Tit. 3; business license fees, Tit. 10; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 3-4; destruction of trees or vegetation, § 4-4-14. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1-1. - Powers of mayor—Declaration of emergency; specification of emergency area. 
(a)  In addition to all other powers enumerated in this Code, the mayor may declare an emergency to exist when, in his opinion, one (1) or more of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  There is extreme likelihood of danger of destruction of life or property due to unusual conditions. 
(2)  Unusual or extreme weather conditions, making the use of city streets or areas difficult or impossible. 
(3)  Civil unrest, commotion or uprising is imminent or exists. 
(4)  There is a stoppage or loss of electrical power affecting a major portion of the city. 
(b)  The declaration of an emergency as to a portion of the city shall specify with exactness the area in which the emergency is declared to exist. 
(Code 1958, § 2-02) 
State Law reference— Offenses against public order and safety, OCGA § 16-11-1 et seq.; calling out state militia during invasion or insurrection, OCGA § 45-12-28. 
Sec. 3-1-2. - Same—Powers specified; duration of emergency. 
(a)  After declaration of such emergency the mayor, as chief executive, shall have the right to exercise any or all of the following: 
(1)  The power to use employees of the city to assist in the safety and preservation of life, limb and property of citizenry of the city. 
(2)  The power to close streets and sidewalks and to delineate areas within the city wherein an emergency exists. 
(3)  The power to impose emergency curfew regulations. 
(4)  The power to close business establishments within the affected area. 
(5)  The power to close any and all municipallyowned buildings and other facilities to the use of the general public. 
(6)  The power to do any and all acts necessary and incidental to the preservation of life, limb and property of the citizenry of the city. 
(b)  No emergency power set forth herein may be effective for more than seventy-two (72) hours after the declaration of an emergency by the mayor. However upon declaration of a second or further emergencies to exist, the emergency powers as set forth herein may be exercised during such further emergency period or periods, but never for more than seventy-two (72) hours in one (1) declared emergency period. 
(c)  No emergency period shall extend beyond the next regular, special or called meeting of the city council. 
(Code 1958, § 2-03) 
Secs. 3-1-3—3-1-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 2. - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Legislative, Ch. 1-3. 

Sec. 3-1-21. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Civil emergency means: 
(1)  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of force or violence or the threat of riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of force or violence. 
(2)  Any civil disturbance or threat of civil disturbance to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the city. 
Curfew means a prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the city, excepting persons officially assigned to duty with reference to a civil emergency. 
(Code 1958, § 14-1.2) 
State Law reference— Offenses against public order, OCGA § 16-11-30 et seq. 
Sec. 3-1-22. - Declaration. 
When in the judgment of the mayor, or any council member acting for him in his absence, a civil emergency is deemed to exist he shall forthwith proclaim in writing the existence of same. 
(Code 1958, § 14-1.3) 
Sec. 3-1-23. - Imposition of curfew. 
After proclamation of a civil emergency the city council may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the city or the city as a whole as it deems advisable and such curfew shall be applicable during such hours of the day or night as it deems necessary in the interest of public safety and welfare. 
(Code 1958, § 14-1.4) 
Sec. 3-1-24. - Powers of city council. 
After proclamation of a civil emergency, the city council may also in the interest of public safety and welfare make any or all of the following orders: 
(1)  Private clubs. Order the closing of all private clubs. 
(2)  Gasoline. Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle. 
(3)  Gasoline stations. Order the closing of gasoline stations and other establishments, the chief activity of which is the sale, distributing, or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products. 
(4)  Firearms. Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever. 
(5)  Firearms establishments. Order the closing of any or all establishments or portions thereof, the chief activity of which is the sale, distribution, dispensing or giving away of firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever. 
(6)  Protection of life and property. Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property. 
(Code 1958, § 14-1.5) 
Sec. 3-1-25. - Closing of streets. 
After the proclamation of a civil emergency the chief of police shall have the authority to temporarily close any and all streets, alleys and other public ways in the city to the public whenever, in the opinion of the chief of police, it is necessary in order to maintain the public safety and welfare of said community. 
(Code 1958, § 14-1.6) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 4-4. 
Sec. 3-1-26. - Penalty. 
Any person violating the provisions of this article, or any order issued pursuant thereto, shall be guilty of an offense against the city and shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-7. 
(Code 1958, § 14-1.7) 
Secs. 3-1-27—3-1-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 3. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Emergency appropriations, § 2-3-96; police department, Ch. 3-2; fire department, Ch. 3-3; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 3-4; pollution and contamination, Ch. 3-6; flood protection and prevention, Ch. 4-5; water shortage management, § 5-2-96 et seq.; fallout shelters, § 7-1-20. 
State Law reference— State militia, OCGA § 38-2-1 et seq.; emergency management, OCGA § 38-3-1 et seq.; emergency funds for local government, OCGA § 50-8-8. 

Sec. 3-1-46. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency management means the preparation for and carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions other than those functions for which military forces or other state and federal agencies are primarily responsible to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of man-made or natural origin. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, law enforcement and police services, medical and health services, rescue services, engineering services, warning services, communications, defense from radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for carrying out the foregoing functions. 
Energy emergency means a condition of danger to the health, safety, welfare or economic well-being of the citizens of this city arising out of a present or threatened shortage of usable energy resources; also any condition of substantial danger to the health, safety or welfare of the citizens of this city resulting from the operation of any electrical power-generating facility, the transport of any energy resource by any means whatsoever, or the production, use or disposal of any source material, special nuclear material, or by-product, as defined by the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, 68 Stat. 919, 42 U.S.C. 2011 et seq.; also any nuclear incident, as defined by the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, occurring within or outside this city, substantially affecting the health, safety or welfare of the citizens of this city. 
(Code 1958, § 8-1; Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, 9-4-90) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, OCGA § 38-3-3. 
Sec. 3-1-47. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this article, or any rules, orders or regulations made pursuant to this article, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-1-7. 
(Code 1958, § 8-6; Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, 9-4-90) 
Sec. 3-1-48. - Office established; appointment, general duties of county emergency management director/coordinator. 
In agreement with the governing officials within the county, there is hereby established the Hall County Emergency Management Office. The commissioners of Hall County and the city council shall jointly nominate, for appointment by the governor, a director/coordinator of emergency management for the entire county. When appointed, the emergency management director/coordinator is charged with the following duties: 
(1)  To represent the governing officials of the city and county therein on matters pertaining to emergency management. 
(2)  To assist the city, the county and other officials in organizing city, county and all other governmental departments for emergency operations. 
(3)  To develop, in conjunction with all county and city departments and other governmental agencies, the county plan for the emergency functions set forth in this chapter. Such plan will be in consonance with the state natural disaster operations plan and nuclear emergency operations plan, and shall be submitted to the governing officials of the county and the city and thence to the state emergency management agency for approval. 
(4)  To maintain the emergency management office and carry out the day-to-day administration of the county emergency management program, including the submission of required reports to the state emergency management agency. 
(5)  To submit reports as required by governing officials in keeping with good management practices. 
(6)  To produce, with the authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the county emergency operations center. 
(7)  To coordinate the activities of the county emergency operations center staff during periods of a declared emergency, and under the supervision of county and city governing officials. 
(Code 1958, § 8-2; Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, 9-4-90) 
Cross reference— General government, Tit. 1. 
State Law reference— State director of emergency management, OCGA § 38-3-20 et seq.; plans and programs for emergency management, OCGA § 38-3-22; local organizations for emergency management, OCGA § 38-3-27. 
Sec. 3-1-49. - Emergency management organization. 
(a)  The county emergency management organization shall be established around the existing county and city departments and other agencies and the emergency functions listed in section 3-4-1 are assigned as follows: 

 
(b)  Heads of departments listed above are responsible for developing the plan for their assigned emergency functions. Such plans will be submitted through the emergency management director/coordinator to the city and to the county commission and other governing officials for approval. 
(Code 1958, § 8-3; Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, 9-4-90) 
Cross reference— General government, Tit. 1. 
State Law reference— Local emergency management regulations, OCGA § 38-3-28. 
Sec. 3-1-50. - Emergency powers. 
In the event of manmade or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States, or any other emergency which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the county, the chairman of the county commission, and/or mayor, or in his absence a legally appointed successor (vice chairman/mayor pro tem), may declare that a state of emergency exists and thereafter the mayor, or in his absence, a legally appointed successor, shall have and may exercise for such period as such state of emergency exists or continues, the following powers: 
(1)  To appropriate and expend funds, execute contracts, and to obtain and distribute equipment, materials, and supplies for emergency management purposes. 
(2)  To provide for the health and safety of persons and property, including emergency assistance to the victims of any emergency or disaster resulting from manmade or natural causes or enemy attack, and to direct and coordinate the development of emergency management plans and programs in accordance with the policies and plans set by the federal and state emergency management agencies. 
(3)  To appoint, employ, remove, or provide, with or without compensation, chiefs of services, warning personnel, rescue teams, auxiliary fire and police personnel, and other emergency management workers. 
(4)  To establish a primary and one (1) or more secondary control centers to serve as command posts during an emergency or disaster. 
(5)  Subject to the order of the governor or the mayor or his legally appointed successor, to assign and make available for duty the employees, property, or equipment of the city relating to firefighting, engineering, rescue, health, medical and related services, and to police, transportation, construction, and similar items or services for emergency management purposes, within or outside of the physical limits of the city. 
(6)  In addition to the heretofore stated powers and authorities, to acquire, temporarily or permanently, by purchase, lease, or otherwise, sites required for installation of temporary housing units for disaster victims; and to enter into whatever arrangements, including purchase, of temporary housing units and payment of transportation charges, which are necessary to prepare or equip such sites to utilize the housing units. 
(Code 1958, § 8-4; Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 91-49, § 1, 12-3-91) 
State Law reference— Emergency interim successors to officials, OCGA § 38-3-50 et seq. 
Sec. 3-1-51. - Volunteers. 
All persons, other than officers and employees of the city, performing emergency functions pursuant to this chapter, shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as municipal and county officers and employees. 
(Code 1958, § 8-5; Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, 9-4-90) 
State Law reference— Immunity under emergency management law, OCGA §§ 38-3-32, 38-3-33, 38-3-35; emergency management personnel, OCGA § 38-3-34. 
Sec. 3-1-52. - Liberality of construction. 
This chapter shall be construed liberally in order to effectuate its purpose. 
(Code 1958, § 8-7; Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, 9-4-90)

State Law reference— Obstruction or hindering of law enforcement officers, OCGA § 16-10-24; arrest of persons, OCGA § 17-4-1 et seq.; law enforcement officers and agencies, OCGA Title 35; state grants for public purposes, OCGA § 36-40-20 et seq. 

CHAPTER 3-3. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Emergency management, § 3-1-46 et seq.; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 3-4; guard dogs, § 4-1-60; fire prevention code, § 7-1-56 et seq. 
State Constitution reference— Power of city to provide fire protection services, Art. 9, § 2, para. 3. 
State Law reference— Fire escapes, OCGA § 8-2-50 et seq.; forest fires, OCGA § 12-6-89; transmitting false report of a fire, OCGA § 16-10-27; fire protection and safety, OCGA Title 25; remedy of unsafe conditions upon failure to comply with court order, OCGA § 25-2-25; local ordinances, regulations or codes relating to fire prevention or protection, OCGA § 25-3-4; state grants for public purposes, OCGA § 36-40-20 et seq.; electronic security systems, installation, service, etc., by counties or municipal corporations, OCGA § 36-60-12; Georgia Firemen's Pension Fund, OCGA § 47-7-1 et seq.; liability of officers, agents, etc., of fire departments for activities, OCGA § 51-1-30. 

Sec. 3-3-1. - Injuring fire apparatus. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or damage in any way and by any means, any of the apparatus of the fire department. 
(Code 1958, § 10-3) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, OCGA § 16-7-22 et seq.; interference with government property, OCGA § 16-7-24 et seq. 
Sec. 3-3-2. - Obstruction of fire plugs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct with building material or otherwise, or to place any post nearer than three (3) feet of any fire plug on their side, such as would obstruct the approaches of the fire department to the same. 
(Code 1958, § 10-4) 
Cross reference— Water, Ch. 5-2. 
State Law reference— Obstruction or hindering of firefighters, OCGA § 16-10-24.1. 
Sec. 3-3-3. - Members of fire department vested with police power during fire. 
The chief and each member of the fire department are hereby vested with all the powers of a police officer of the city, insofar as to make arrests within the city, during a fire. 
(Code 1958, § 10-6) 
Cross reference— Police department, Ch. 3-2. 
State Law reference— Power of state fire marshal and staff to make arrests and carry weapons, OCGA § 25-2-9. 
Sec. 3-3-4. - City firefighting equipment not to be used outside city, exception. 
(a)  No firefighting equipment or personnel of the city shall be used outside the corporate limits of the city, except for: 
(1)  The purpose of extinguishing fires at schools, churches, industrial plants, veterans' clubs, radio stations or in response to calls for aid from other municipalities within Hall County unless approved by the city manager. 
(2)  The purpose of complying with the terms and conditions of any automatic aid agreement entered into with any other governmental entity. 
(Code 1958, § 10-8; Ord. No. 97-63, § I, 10-21-97) 
State Law reference— Mutual aid resource pacts, OCGA § 25-6-1 et seq.

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-4-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known and cited as the "Traffic Ordinance." 
(Code 1958, § 23-101) 
Sec. 3-4-2. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the term: 
Central traffic district means all streets and portions of streets within the boundaries described as follows: 
Beginning at the center of intersection of West Academy Street and Academy Street; extending along West Academy Street to Jesse Jewell Parkway; extending along Jesse Jewell Parkway to E. E. Butler Parkway; extending along E. E. Butler Parkway to Academy Street; and thence along Academy Street to the beginning point at the intersection of Academy Street and West Academy Street. 
Curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
Freight curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight. 
Limited loading zones means zones in which it shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within a properly marked loading zone between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. (except if otherwise marked), Sundays excepted, except for the purpose of loading or unloading such vehicle. It shall be unlawful to be parked in any loading zone for more than fifteen (15) minutes between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Sundays excepted. 
Passenger curb loading zone means a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. 
Speed detection device means, unless otherwise indicated, that particular device designed to measure the speed or velocity of a motor vehicle and marketed under the name "Vascar" or any similar device operating under the same or similar principle and any devices for the measurement of speed or velocity based upon the Doppler principle of radar or the speed timing principle of laser. All such devices must meet or exceed the minimum performance specifications established by the department of public safety. 
Traffic division means the traffic division of the police department of this city, or in the event a traffic division is not established, then such term whenever used herein shall be deemed to refer to the police department of this city. 
(Code 1958, § 23-104; Ord. No. 93-16, § 1, 5-4-93; Ord. No. 98-40, § I, 7-21-98) 
Sec. 3-4-3. - Penalty for violation of provisions. 
If any person shall be convicted of the violation of any section of the traffic ordinance of the city, such person shall on conviction thereof, be punished as prescribed in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 23-103) 
Sec. 3-4-4. - Repeal of ordinances in conflict; effect on prior violations. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with or inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter are hereby repealed, except that this repeal shall not affect or prevent the prosecution or punishment of any person for any act done or committed in violation of any ordinance hereby repealed prior to the taking effect of this chapter. 
(Code 1958, § 23-102) 
Sec. 3-4-5. - Uniform rules of the road. 
(a)  Adoption by reference. Pursuant to Chapter 6 of Title 40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, OCGA Sections 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, Code Sections 40-6-1 through 40-6-395, of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in OCGA section 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited herein. 
(b)  Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(c)  Repeal. The existing ordinances covering the same matters as embraced in this section are hereby repealed and all ordinances or parts of ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of this section are hereby repealed. 
(d)  Effective date. The effective date of this section shall be upon approval by the city council. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1601; Ord. No. 91-46, 11-5-91) 
Sec. 3-4-6. - City public works director. 
(a)  The city public works director shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(b)  It shall be the general responsibility of the city public works director to determine or cause to be determined the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control devices, to conduct or cause to be conducted engineering analysis of traffic accidents and to devise remedial measures, to conduct or to have conducted engineering investigation of traffic conditions, to plan or cause to be planned the operation of traffic on the streets of this city, to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1958, § 23-105) 
Cross reference— General government, Tit. 1. 
Sec. 3-4-7. - Operation of vehicles on streets; exceptions. 
The provisions of this chapter relating to the operation of vehicles refer to the operation of vehicles upon streets except: 
(1)  Where a different place is specifically referred to in a given section; 
(2)  The provisions of this chapter shall apply to a vehicle operated at shopping centers or parking lots or similar areas which although privately owned are customarily used by the public as through streets or connector streets; 
(3)  The provisions of this chapter relating to reckless driving, driving in violation of section 3-4-132, and homicide by vehicle shall apply to vehicles operated upon streets and elsewhere throughout the city; and 
(4)  The provisions of section 3-4-10 shall apply upon the streets of this city, in all parking areas, and in all areas which are customarily open to the public and within two hundred (200) feet of all such streets, parking areas, and areas customarily open to the public. 
(Code 1958, § 23-106) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, OCGA § 40-6-3. 
Sec. 3-4-8. - Duty of driver to stop at or return to scene of accident. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or the death of any person or in damage to a vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of the accident or shall stop as close thereto as possible and forthwith return to the scene of the accident and shall in every event remain at the scene of the accident until fulfilling the requirements of OCGA Section 40-6-271. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. 
(b)  If such accident is the proximate cause of death or a serious injury as defined in OCGA Section 33-34-2, any person knowingly failing to stop and comply with the requirements of subsection (a) above shall be guilty of a felony and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than one (1) nor more than five (5) years. 
(c)  If such accident is the proximate cause of an injury other than a serious injury as defined in OCGA Section 33-34-2, or if such accident resulted in damage to a vehicle which is driven or attended by any person, any person knowingly failing to stop or comply with the requirements of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and: 
(1)  Upon conviction shall be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), which fine shall not be subject to suspension, stay, or probation, or imprisoned for up to one (1) year, or both; 
(2)  Upon the second conviction within a five-year period of time, as measured from the dates of previous arrests for which convictions were obtained to the date of the current arrest for which a conviction is obtained, shall be fined not less than six hundred dollars ($600.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), which fine shall not be subject to suspension, stay, or probation, or imprisoned for up to one (1) year, or both; and for purposes of this section, previous pleas of nolo contendere accepted within such five-year period shall constitute convictions; and 
(3)  Upon the third or subsequent conviction within a five-year period of time, as measured from the dates of previous arrests for which convictions were obtained to the date of the current arrest for which a conviction is obtained, shall be fined one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), which fine shall not be subject to suspension, stay, or probation, or imprisoned for up to one (1) year, or both; and for purposes of this section, previous pleas of nolo contendere accepted within such five-year period shall constitute convictions. 
For the purpose of imposing a sentence under this subsection, a plea of nolo contendere shall constitute a conviction. If the payment of the fine required under this subsection will impose an economic hardship on the defendant, the judge, at his sole discretion, may order the defendant to pay such fine in installments and such order may be enforced through a contempt proceeding or a revocation of any probation otherwise authorized by this section. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the limits set forth in the charter, the municipal court shall be authorized to impose the punishments provided for in this section upon a conviction of violating this section or upon conviction of violating any ordinance adopting the provisions of this section. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, OCGA § 40-6-270. 
Sec. 3-4-9. - Duty upon striking unattended vehicle. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle which collides with any vehicle which is unattended shall immediately stop and shall then and there either locate and notify the operator or owner of such vehicle of the name and address of the driver and owner of the vehicle striking the unattended vehicle or shall leave in a conspicuous place in the vehicle struck a written notice giving the name and address of the driver and the owner of the vehicle doing the striking. 
(b)  Any person who fails to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, OCGA § 40-6-272. 
Sec. 3-4-10. - Duty to report accident resulting in injury, death, or property damage. 
The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or property damage to an apparent extent of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more shall immediately, by the quickest means of communication, give notice of such accident to the police department. The above notice shall be in addition to the written report required by OCGA Section 40-9-30. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1508) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, OCGA § 40-6-274. 
Sec. 3-4-11. - Public employees to obey traffic regulations. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government, this state, county or city. It shall be unlawful for any driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or by state statute. 
(Code 1958, § 23-111) 
Cross reference— General government, Tit. 1. 
State Law reference— Observance of Uniform Rules of the Road, OCGA § 40-6-1. 
Sec. 3-4-12. - Animals, use of devices for self-transportation and similar devices restricted. 
(a)  The utilization of any device designed for self-transportation or self-propulsion, or riding any animal shall be prohibited in places not specifically designated for their use. Prohibited places shall include the downtown square, public courtyards, public parking lots and decks, and all sidewalks and roadways. Exceptions may be granted by the city council at their discretion based on specific requests presented to them in a timely manner and via the proper channels. This section shall not limit the provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(b)  Bicycles are allowed on roadways subject to the provisions of state law but are prohibited in places not specifically designated for their use. Prohibited places shall include public courtyards, public parking lots and decks, and all sidewalks. Exceptions may be granted by the city council at their discretion based on specific requests presented to them in a timely manner and via the proper channels. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § I, 3-3-10) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-06, § I, adopted Mar. 3, 2010, repealed § 3-4-12 in its entirety and enacted a new § 3-4-12 as set out herein. The former § 3-4-12 pertained to use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices restricted and derived from the Code of 1958, § 23-112. 
Sec. 3-4-13. - Standing on streets or highways and soliciting employment, business, or contributions from occupants of vehicles prohibited. 
No person shall stand on any street or highway of the city for the purpose of soliciting employment, business, or contributions from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2000-97, § I, 12-21-00) 
Secs. 3-4-14—3-4-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 2. - TRAFFIC SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS 

Sec. 3-4-26. - Authority to establish play streets. 
The city public works director shall have authority to declare any street or part thereof a play street and to place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. 
(Code 1958, § 23-208) 
Cross reference— Recreation and parks, Ch. 1-7. 
Sec. 3-4-27. - Driving on play streets. 
Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1958, § 23-209) 
Sec. 3-4-28. - Designation of crosswalks and safety zones. 
The city public works director is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may deem necessary; 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(Code 1958, § 23-210) 
Sec. 3-4-29. - Traffic lanes. 
(a)  The city public works director is hereby authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary. 
(b)  Where such traffic lanes have been marked, it shall be unlawful for the operator of any such vehicle to fail or refuse to keep such vehicle within the boundaries of any such lane except when lawfully passing another vehicle or preparatory to making a lawful turning movement. 
(Code 1958, § 23-211) 
State Law reference— Driving on roadways laned for traffic, OCGA § 40-6-48. 
Sec. 3-4-30. - Authority to sign one-way streets and alleys. 
Whenever any ordinance of this city designates any one-way street or alley the city public works director shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1958, § 23-212) 
Sec. 3-4-31. - Authority to restrict direction of movement on streets during certain periods. 
(a)  The city public works director is hereby authorized to determine and designate streets, parts of streets or specific lanes thereon upon which vehicular traffic shall proceed in one (1) direction during one (1) period and the opposite direction during another period of the day and shall place and maintain appropriate markings, signs, barriers or other devices to give notice thereof. The city public works director may erect signs temporarily designating lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction, regardless of the center line of the roadway. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle in violation of such markings, signs, barriers or other devices so placed in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1958, § 23-213) 
Secs. 3-4-32—3-4-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 3. - RAILROADS 

Sec. 3-4-46. - Speed of trains restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, its agent or employee, or any other person to operate a train within the corporate limits of the city at a rate of speed greater than thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
(Code 1958, § 17-1) 
Sec. 3-4-47. - Crossings—Obstructing. 
Any railroad train or part of a railroad train or railroad car or locomotive or other rolling equipment shall not be halted upon railroad crossings of the public streets, alleys or thoroughfares of the city so as to block or interfere with the use of any public street, alley or thoroughfare for a period of time in excess of fifteen (15) minutes. 
(Code 1958, § 17-2) 
Sec. 3-4-48. - Same—Manner of keeping. 
All railroad companies shall keep the street crossings over their tracks level with the top of the rails by plank or otherwise, and in a safe and convenient condition for vehicles or foot passengers. When the railroad runs under any street so as to make a bridge necessary, it shall be the duty of such company to keep such bridge at all times safe and in good repair. Upon failure of any railroad company to comply with the provisions of this section, the agent of such company shall be served with a notice of the defect, and upon failure to put such crossing in proper condition within thirty (30) days, the same shall be remedied by the city at the expense of the company, and the costs collected by execution against the company as provided by law. 
(Code 1958, § 17-3) 
State Law reference— Duty of railroads to maintain grade crossings, OCGA § 32-6-190; procedure for grade crossing elimination, OCGA § 32-6-194; responsibility for maintenance of overpasses and underpasses, OCGA § 32-6-197; procedure to obtain maintenance of grade separation structures, protective devices and grade crossings, OCGA § 32-6-202; crossing obstructed or in disrepair, OCGA § 46-8-128. 
Sec. 3-4-49. - Same—Protection to be provided. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person operating trains across grade crossings in the city, to provide at each such grade crossing complete public safety from danger from approaching trains for all persons using the streets at such crossings. For this purpose, persons operating trains, or having control of the track, shall place and keep at each such grade crossing at all times a watchman or flagman, or shall install, operate and maintain standard automatic gates or signaling devices sufficient to protect the public fully from the danger of any approaching train. 
(b)  No train shall be run across any grade crossing where adequate provision, as required by the preceding section, has not been made for the protection of human life. 
(Code 1958, § 17-4) 
Sec. 3-4-50. - Train water closet. 
All conductors of railroads and sleeping car companies running into or through the city shall keep the water closets of the cars in them clean, securely locked, and shall not permit them to be used while stopping in this city. Any conductor failing to comply with the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 17-5) 
Secs. 3-4-51—3-4-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 4. - SPEED 

Sec. 3-4-61. - Speed laws applicable. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. ch. 6 of tit. 40, §§ 40-6-181, 40-6-184, 40-6-185, and 40-6-188 of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of City of Gainesville with like effect as if recited herein. 
(Code 1958, § 23-801; Ord. No. 2017-26, § I, 11-7-17) 
State Law reference— Speed restrictions, OCGA § 40-6-180 et seq.; alteration of speed limits by local authorities, OCGA § 40-6-183. 
Sec. 3-4-62. - Regulation of speed by traffic signals. 
The city public works director is authorized to regulate the timing of traffic signals so as to permit the movement of traffic in an orderly and safe manner at speeds slightly at variance from the speeds otherwise applicable within the district or at intersections and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1958, § 23-804) 
Secs. 3-4-63—3-4-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 5. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Off-street parking under zoning ordinance, § 9-1-13 et seq. 

Sec. 3-4-76. - Application of article provisions. 
The provisions of this article prohibiting the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic-control device. 
(1)  The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(2)  When official traffic-control devices are in place giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets or portions of streets described in Schedules 4 and 5 set out in sections 3-4-174 and 3-4-175. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1013) 
Sec. 3-4-77. - Official traffic-control devices. 
Whenever by this or any other ordinance of this city any parking time is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets, it shall be the duty of the city public works director to install appropriate official traffic-control devices giving notice thereof and no such regulations shall be effective unless such devices are in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1014) 
Sec. 3-4-78. - Limited loading zones—Designation, criteria. 
(a)  The city public works director is hereby authorized to determine the location of limited loading zones. 
(b)  Limited loading zones will be based upon the following criteria: 
(1)  Passenger loading zones. Loading zones for passengers will be limited to places of public gatherings. Therefore, passenger loading zones will be limited to the following areas: 
a.  Public auditoriums and meeting places. 
b.  Hotels. 
c.  Theaters. 
d.  Schools. 
e.  Churches. 
(2)  Package and freight loading zones. Package and freight loading zones will be established without charge by the city after study by the public works director to determine need and location. The following standards must be met to justify a package and freight loading zone: 
a.  A minimum of five (5) establishments without off-street access that will derive service from the zone. 
b.  A maximum of two (2) freight loading zones within a one (1) block area. 
(3)  Limited loading zones are hereby established on parts of the streets described in Schedule 8, section 3-4-178 and Schedule 9, section 3-4-179. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1006; Ord. No. 93-16, § 2, 5-4-93) 
Sec. 3-4-79. - Same—Applications. 
The city public works director shall not designate or sign any loading zone upon special request of any person unless such person makes application for a permit for such zone. The city public works director upon receipt of the application will make a study to determine the loading characteristics of the establishment in question. After analysis of the information and comparison with the established standards set forth in section 3-4-78 the request will be granted or denied on the basis of the results. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1007) 
Sec. 3-4-80. - Standing in passenger curb loading zone. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three (3) minutes. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1008) 
Sec. 3-4-81. - Standing in freight curb loading zone. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed thirty (30) minutes. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1009) 
Sec. 3-4-82. - Designation of public carrier stops and stands. 
The city public works director may establish bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands and stands for other passenger common carrier vehicles on such public streets, in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every bus stop, bus stand, or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1010) 
Cross reference— Taxicabs, Ch. 6-8. 
Sec. 3-4-83. - Stopping, standing and parking of buses and taxicabs regulated. 
(a)  The operator of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than a bus stand so designated as provided herein. 
(b)  The operator of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage other than at a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone so designated as provided herein, except in case of an emergency. 
(c)  The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone on a public street in such a manner that a bus when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage shall be in a position with the right front wheel of such vehicle not further than eighteen (18) inches from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(d)  The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than in a taxicab stand so designated as provided herein. This provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1011) 
Cross reference— Taxicabs, Ch. 6-8. 
Sec. 3-4-84. - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1012) 
Cross reference— Taxicabs, Ch. 6-8. 
Sec. 3-4-85. - Parking in shopping center fire lanes. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle within ten (10) feet of the curb adjacent to a sidewalk in the front or rear of any business located within a shopping center, if such sidewalk exists, or within fifteen (15) feet of the front or rear of any building if a sidewalk does not exist and when such area has been marked as a fire lane, for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers or the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place, and then only for a period not to exceed three (3) minutes; provided, however, this section shall not apply to designated loading zones. 
(b)  As used herein "shopping center" is defined as a group of five (5) or more commercial establishments existing on a single tract of land which have been planned and developed as a unit and which have a combined floor area of not less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1014.1) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and business regulations, Tit. 6. 
Sec. 3-4-86. - Reserved parking spaces for city officials and employees. 
Reserved parking spaces are hereby established for the exclusive use of city officials and city employees on property owned by the city and marked for use by city officials and/or city employees. The parking of a vehicle in these reserved spaces except by a city official and/or city employee shall be a violation of this section. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1015) 
Cross reference— General government, Tit. 1. 
Sec. 3-4-87. - Parking zones. 
(a)  Limited parking zones are hereby established on those streets or parts of streets described in Schedule 6, section 3-4-176, in which zones the parking of vehicles upon streets shall be for a maximum of two (2) hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day except Sundays and public holidays. Parking for more than two (2) hours in any limited parking zone shall be a violation of this section and each two-hour period in which any such violation shall continue shall be a separate offense. 
(b)  The city public works director is hereby authorized, subject to the approval of the city council by amendment of Schedule 6, section 3-4-176, to establish parking zones at other locations upon those streets or parts of streets where it is determined upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that limited parking shall be necessary to aid in the regulation, control and inspection of the parking of vehicles. 
(c)  Limited parking zones are hereby established on those streets or parts of streets described in Schedule 10, section 3-4-180, in which zones the parking of vehicles upon streets shall be for a maximum of twenty (20) minutes between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day except Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays. Parking for more than twenty (20) minutes in any limited parking zone shall be a violation of this section and each twenty-minute period in which any such violation continues shall be a separate offense. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow or permit any vehicle to park adjacent to a yellow curb. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1016; Ord. No. 89-51, § I, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 2010-12, § I, 4-20-10) 
State Law reference— Public and legal holidays, OCGA § 1-4-1. 
Sec. 3-4-88. - Trucks or tractors prohibited from using certain streets. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall operate any truck or tractor at any time upon any of the streets or parts of streets described elsewhere in this chapter, except that such vehicles may be operated thereon for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise and then only by entering such street at the intersection nearest the destination of the vehicle and proceeding thereon no farther than the nearest intersection thereafter. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1017) 
Sec. 3-4-89. - Parking time limits—Posted notices. 
Any vehicle parking or standing in any designated and posted parking space shall be parked within the lines marked on the street or curb and may occupy such space during the parking limited provided by this article and the posted notice for the part of the street in which such parking space is located. 
(Ord. No. 93-16, § 3, 5-4-93) 
Sec. 3-4-90. - Same—Parking overtime; separate offenses, marking system, fines, wheel locks, bonds and fees. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to be parked overtime or beyond the period of legal parking time. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to stay parked in any designated parking space beyond the designated unit of time. 
(c)  Exceeding the period of legal parking time in any designated parking space, or designated parking spaces, within the established downtown business parking zone (see section 3-4-91), shall constitute a separate violation of this section. 
(d)  The police department shall adopt an appropriate marking system for identifying cars in order that this section may be adequately enforced. 
(e)  The fine for the first violation of the following parking offenses shall be: 
(1)  First offense for parking in a fire lane, section ..... $100.00 
(2)  Parking in a handicapped zone ..... 250.00 
(3)  Parking on sidewalk ..... 50.00 
(4)  Parking in employee parking spaces or lot without permit ..... 50.00 
(5)  All other violations not described in subsections (e)1—4. ..... 20.00 
(f)  Any person who fails to pay any parking offense within five (5) days of receipt thereof shall pay double the fine for such parking offense. 
(g)  Any person who receives two (2) parking tickets within thirty (30) days shall pay double the fine of the first parking offense. 
(h)  Any person who receives three (3) parking tickets within thirty (30) days shall pay triple the fine of the first parking offense. 
(i)  The vehicle owner shall, within five (5) days of receiving the fifth unpaid parking ticket, satisfy all delinquent tickets or shall be subject to an additional penalty six (6) times the fine of the first parking offense. 
(j)  Court summons; bond for failure to appear. Additionally, such owner shall be issued a summons to appear in the municipal court of the city. If such owner fails to appear at the appointed time and date as specified in the summons, he or she shall be subject to arrest and shall post a fifty dollar ($50.00) bond plus an amount equal to all fines and penalties accrued to such date. 
(k)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 93-16, § 4, 5-4-93; Ord. No. 2003-57, §§ I—IV, 9-2-03; Ord. No. 2010-12, § II, 4-20-10) 
Sec. 3-4-91. - Establishment of a downtown business parking zone. 
A downtown business parking zone is hereby established to facilitate enforcement of section 3-4-90 of this Code, which zone shall include the herein described portions of the following downtown streets: 
Bradford Street—from Spring Street to Academy Street. 
Broad Street—from Main Street to West Academy Street. 
Brenau Avenue—from E.E. Butler Parkway to Main Street. 
Green Street—from Jesse Jewell Parkway to Academy Street. 
Main Street—from Jesse Jewell Parkway to Academy Street. 
Maple Street—from Broad Street to Academy Street. 
Spring Street—from Green Street to West Academy Street. 
Washington Street—from E.E. Butler Parkway to West Academy Street. 
(Ord. No. 93-16, § 5, 5-4-93; Ord. No. 2003-57, § V, 9-2-03) 
Sec. 3-4-92. - Construction permit parking fees in the downtown area. 
There shall be a construction permit parking fee for the use of parking spaces in the downtown area by contractors in the performance of their work as follows: 
Per parking space per day ..... $5.00 
(Ord. No. 93-16, § 6, 5-4-93; Ord. No. 2003-57, § VI, 9-2-03) 
Secs. 3-4-93—3-4-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 6. - MISCELLANEOUS RULES 

Sec. 3-4-101. - Control of vehicle load. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul or transport or cause to be hauled or transported by truck or other vehicle any load of logs, lumber, pipes and other like material on or over the public streets of the city without first having such load securely fastened to such vehicle by at least two (2) chains or steel cables of sufficient strength to securely hold the load upon the truck or other vehicle. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1116) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, OCGA § 32-6-21. 
Sec. 3-4-102. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 99-32, § I, adopted June 1, 1999, repealed § 3-4-102 which pertained to blowing horns excessively, and derived from Code 1958, § 23-1116.

Sec. 3-4-104. - Permits for loading or unloading at an angle to the curb. 
(a)  The city public works director is authorized to issue special permits to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized herein. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1118)
