ARTICLE 11. - TRAFFIC CONGESTION THOROUGHFARES[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 90-42, adopted Sept. 4, 1990, amended the Code by adding provisions thereto; inclusion of the provisions as Art. 11 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 3-4-201. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to prohibit the repeated driving of a motor vehicle along and across any portion of a congested public thoroughfare, which shall constitute a strict liability violation without any requirement of culpable mental state, all as described in this article. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1(23-1801), 9-4-90) 
Sec. 3-4-202. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Thoroughfare is any public roadway or street in the city. 
Traffic congestion thoroughfare is any portion of a public thoroughfare within the city affected by traffic congestion caused in whole or in part by the repeated driving of the same motor vehicle(s) along or across that portion of the thoroughfare. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1(23-1802, 23-1803), 9-4-90) 
Sec. 3-4-203. - Posting signs. 
(a)  With respect to any traffic congested roadway or street, the chief of police or his designee after consulting with the city traffic engineer is authorized to declare that portion of the street to be a traffic congestion thoroughfare and to cause signs, as described in this article, to be posted notifying of that designation. 
(b)  The signs referred to in subsection (a) shall notify drivers that they are entering a traffic congestion thoroughfare; that repeated passage of a motor vehicle along or across the traffic congestion thoroughfare is a violation of section 3-4-204; and that for a subsequent violation, the vehicle will be towed. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1(23-1804, 23-1805), 9-4-90) 
Sec. 3-4-204. - Prohibited acts. 
Between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following morning, no vehicle shall pass along or across a traffic congestion thoroughfare, designated as such by signs as described in section 3-4-203(b), more than 3 times. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1(23-1806), 9-4-90) 
Sec. 3-4-205. - Penalty generally. 
If any person shall be convicted of the violation of this article, such person shall on conviction thereof, be punished as prescribed in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1(23-1807), 9-4-90) 
Sec. 3-4-206. - Subsequent violations—Generally. 
If a vehicle passes along or across a traffic congestion thoroughfare as designated by signs as referred to in section 3-4-203(b), in violation of section 3-4-204, any single subsequent drive along or across that traffic congestion thoroughfare by that vehicle within the same 6:00 p.m to 5:00 a.m. time period shall constitute a separate violation of section 3-4-204 punishable as provided in section 3-4-205; and the vehicle may be towed and taken to a storage area designated by the city and may be held for not more than twenty-four (24) hours, all at the expense of the owner or person entitled to possession. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1(23-1808), 9-4-90) 
Sec. 3-4-207. - Same—Notice of towing. 
Upon issuing a citation for a violation of section 3-4-204, the officer shall give the person to whom the citation is issued a written notice which shall state: 
NOTICE 
You have been cited for violation of section 3-4-204 of the Code of the City of Gainesville for repeated passage of a motor vehicle along or across a traffic congestion thoroughfare. 
If the vehicle you are driving is again driven along or across this traffic congestion thoroughfare before 5:00 a.m. this morning this vehicle shall be impounded and towed in accordance with section 3-4-206 of the Code of the City of Gainesville. 
Chief of Police of the City of  Gainesville, Georgia 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1(23-1809), 9-4-90) 
Sec. 3-4-208. - Exemptions. 
This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any publicly owned vehicle of any city, county, state or federal agency; 
(2)  Any vehicle licensed for public transportation; 
(3)  Any other vehicle granted an exemption by the chief of police because passage of the vehicle along or across the traffic congestion thoroughfare is necessary for commercial or medical reasons. 
(Ord. No. 90-42, § 1(23-1810), 9-4-90) 
CHAPTER 3-5. - OFFENSES—MISCELLANEOUS[12] 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference— Crimes and offenses, OCGA Title 16; limitations on home rule powers, OCGA § 36-35-6; abatement of nuisances in cities, OCGA § 41-2-5. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-5-1. - Aircraft and pilots restricted. 
Except as otherwise provided by law, only aircraft and pilots licensed by the Federal Aviation Administration may operate in or over the city; however, this restriction shall not apply to public aircraft of the federal government, or of a state, territory, possession or political subdivision thereof. 
(Code 1958, § 14-1) 
State Law reference— Aviation, OCGA § 6-1-1 et seq.; licensing of pilots, OCGA § 6-2-10. 
Sec. 3-5-2. - Peddling balloons, trinkets, etc., on streets prohibited. 
The peddling of balloons and trinkets and the sale of other merchandise is hereby prohibited on the public streets, roads, alleys and thoroughfares of the city. 
(Code 1958, § 14-1.1) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 4-4. 
State Law reference— Peddling without license, OCGA § 43-32-7. 
Sec. 3-5-3. - Crowding or following officer with prisoner. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to crowd around or follow after an officer when making an arrest or taking a prisoner to or from the jail, or through streets or any street or alley in the city, unless such persons are duly summoned and authorized by the officer to assist in keeping the prisoner in safe custody. Any person violating any of the provisions of the above section shall be deemed guilty of disorderly conduct. 
(Code 1958, § 14-3) 
State Law reference— Obstruction or hindering of law enforcement officers, OCGA § 16-10-24. 
Sec. 3-5-4. - Disorderly conduct generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an act of disorderly conduct in the city. 
(b)  A person commits disorderly conduct when he: 
(1)  Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person whereby that person is placed in fear of safety of his life, limb or health; or 
(2)  Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person whereby the property of that person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged; or 
(3)  Without provocation, uses to or of another person, in his presence, opprobrious or abusive words which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace; that is to say, words which as a matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to or of another person in his presence, naturally tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called "fighting words"; or 
(4)  Without provocation, uses obscene and vulgar or profane language in the presence of or by telephone to a person under the age of 14 years, which threatens an immediate breach of the peace; or 
(5)  Causes, provokes or engages in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another; or 
(6)  Disturbs the peace of others by violent, indecent, offensive or boisterous conduct or language which conduct or language was calculated to cause anguish or injury to another and had a direct tendency to cause immediate acts of violence by the person to whom the conduct or language was addressed, i.e., constituted "fighting words"; or 
(7)  Throws any stone or other missile upon or at any person, vehicle, building, tree, sign or other public or private property; or 
(8)  Throws any stone or missile from any vehicle, either moving, stopped, or parked, upon or at any person, building, vehicle, tree, sign, or other public or private property; or 
(9)  By acts of violence, interferes with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; or 
(10)  Expectorates, urinates, or defecates on any public street, alley, sidewalk or floor of any public building or a building where the public gathers or has access; or 
(11)  With the intent to prevent or disrupt a lawful meeting, procession or gathering, substantially obstructs or interferes with the meeting, procession or gathering by physical action or verbal utterance; or 
(12)  Frequents any public place with intent to obtain money from other persons by illegal and fraudulent schemes, tricks, artifices or devices; or 
(13)  Assembles for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person in the city, or who shall aid and abet therein. 
(c)  Any person who shall violate any subsection of this section may be charged with the offense of disorderly conduct, and on conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 14-6; Ord. No. 2016-13, § I, 7-5-16) 
Cross reference— Serious traffic offenses, § 3-4-131 et seq. 
State Law reference— Assault and battery, OCGA § 16-5-20 et seq.; fraud and related offenses, OCGA § 16-9-50 et seq.; offenses against public order, OCGA § 16-11-30 et seq.; fighting in a public place, OCGA § 16-11-32; loitering or prowling, OCGA § 16-11-36; use of fighting words, obscene and vulgar or profane language, harassing telephone calls, OCGA §§ 16-11-39, 46-5-21; pointing or aiming gun or pistol at another, OCGA § 16-11-102. 
Sec. 3-5-5. - Criminal trespass by motor vehicle—Generally. 
A person commits the offense of criminal trespass by motor vehicle when the person, after having been requested not to do so by a law enforcement officer or by the owner or an authorized agent of the owner, parks or stands an occupied or unoccupied motor vehicle in, or repeatedly drives a motor vehicle through or within, a parking area which is located on privately owned property and is provided by a merchant, a group of merchants, or a shopping center or other similar facility for customers if: 
(1)  The parking area is identified by at least one (1) sign as specified in this paragraph, and if the parking area contains more than one hundred fifty (150) parking spaces then by at least one (1) such sign at each entrance to the parking area, each such sign containing the following information in easy to read printing: 
a.  Notice of the elements of the crime of criminal trespass by motor vehicle; 
b.  Identification of the property which is reserved for customers' use only; 
c.  Identification of the merchant, group of merchants, or shopping center or other similar facility providing the parking area; 
d.  Warning that violators will be prosecuted; and 
(2)  The motor vehicle is parked, is standing, or is being operated other than for the purpose of: 
a.  Transporting some person to or from the interior of the place of business of a merchant identified by the sign or signs in the parking area or to or from the interior of the shopping center or other facility so identified; 
b.  Making use of a telephone, vending machine, automatic teller machine, or other similar facility located in the parking area; 
c.  Meeting the requirements of a situation in which it has unexpectedly become impossible or impractical for the motor vehicle to continue to travel on the public roads; or 
d.  Carrying out an activity for which express permission has been given by the owner of the parking area or an authorized representative of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 90-43, § 1, 9-4-90) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 90-43, adopted Sept. 4, 1990, repealed provisions of the 1958 Code included in this Code as §§ 3-5-5—3-5-7, and enacted provisions in lieu thereof included by the editor as §§ 3-5-5 and 3-5-6. The repealed provisions pertained to disorderly conduct in parking areas and derived from Code 1958, §§ 14-6.4—14-6.6. 
Sec. 3-5-6. - Same—Penalty for violation. 
Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of section 3-5-5 shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine: 
(1)  Not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first such violation; 
(2)  Not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second such violation; and 
(3)  Not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the third or subsequent such violation. 
(Ord. No. 90-43, § 2, 9-4-90) 
Note— See the editor's note following § 3-5-5. 
Sec. 3-5-7. - Reserved. 
Note— See the editor's note following § 3-5-5. 
Sec. 3-5-8. - Drunkenness on streets. 
All persons found drunk on the streets, or who while in a state of intoxication, shall behave in a disorderly manner on the streets of this city shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 14-13) 
State Law reference— Public drunkenness, OCGA § 16-11-41; treatment of alcoholics and intoxicated persons, OCGA §§ 37-7-1 et seq., 37-8-1 et seq.; pedestrian under influence of alcohol or drug, OCGA § 40-6-96. 
Sec. 3-5-9. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages upon public property. 
(a)  Except as provided in chapter 1-7 and chapter 6-4 of this Code, no alcoholic beverages shall be consumed upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, parks, or parking lots within the city, whether public or private. 
(b)  Anyone convicted of violating this section shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 14-13.1; Ord. No. 2015-05, § I, 2-20-15) 
Sec. 3-5-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 92-47, § 1, adopted Nov. 3, 1992, repealed former § 3-5-10, which pertained to public indecency. 
Sec. 3-5-11. - Leaving of junk or salvage materials. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place, abandon, leave, keep or store junk and salvage materials, including nonfunctioning motor vehicles, appliances, machinery, equipment or parts thereof, out-of-doors upon any public or private land within the city except within the confines of a licensed junk or salvage yard or within designated public disposal areas. 
(b)  Whenever it shall appear to any authorized member or representative of the city government that subsection (a) is being violated, he shall, in writing, notify the owner or tenant in possession of the land on which the violation exists to abate such violation by removing the material or materials to a conforming location, or into an enclosed garage, barn or other building. 
(c)  There shall be a systematic method and program to inspect all premises within the city to locate nonlicensed junk salvage areas and premises and to require the abatement thereof. 
(d)  If the tenant or owner of the premises on which the violation exists fails to abate the violation within the required time after notice, the city, by and through its agents, shall abate the violation, charge the cost thereof to the legal owner of the premises, and the legal owner of the premises shall pay the cost of such abatement to the city. 
(e)  Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section, shall upon conviction thereof, be punished as prescribed in section 1-1-7 of this Code. Each day such violation exists fifteen (15) days after receipt of notice of violation shall be considered a separate offense or violation of this section. 
(Code 1958, §§ 14-17.1—14-17.5; Ord. No. 2004-77, §§ I, II, 10-5-04) 
State Law reference— Junkyards near certain highways, OCGA § 32-6-240 et seq. 
Sec. 3-5-12. - Offenses against public health generally. 
(a)  Weeds, untrimmed grass, litter, trash, deleterious or unhealthful growths, other noxious matter or other debris of any kind. No owner of any lot, parcel or area of land within the city, or the agent of such owner, or tenant of an owner, or other occupant of the premises, shall permit on such lot, parcel or area of land, or upon any sidewalk abutting the same, any weeds, untrimmed grass, litter, trash, deleterious or unhealthful growths, other noxious matter, or other debris of any kind which may in any way impair the visibility of persons using the public streets to the danger of such users thereof; or which may emit foul or unhealthful odors; or which may serve as a place for the breeding of flies, mosquitoes, or other insects of a destructive nature; or serve as the haven or refuge of mice, rats, snakes or other animals and reptiles of a destructive nature and generally odious to man; or which may constitute a fire hazard; or which may constitute an impediment on or overhanging the sidewalks along any of the streets; or which may be generally disagreeable or obnoxious to the residents in the immediate vicinity of any lot, parcel or area of land from which such weeds, untrimmed grass, litter, trash, deleterious or unhealthful growths, or other noxious matter, or other debris of any kind may exist; or which may constitute a public nuisance or health hazard. 
(b)  Inspection of lot, parcel or area of land. The city marshal, or such subordinate official as may be designated to act in his behalf, may enter and inspect every lot, parcel or area of land to determine if same is being kept in a clean and neat condition free from weeds, untrimmed grass, litter, trash, deleterious or unhealthful growths, other noxious matter or debris of any kind. 
(c)  Notice to destroy. Whenever it shall appear to the city marshal or his designee that subsection (a) is being violated, he shall, in writing, notify the owner of any such lot, parcel or area of land within the city or the agent of such owner, to cut, destroy or remove any such weeds, untrimmed grass, litter, trash, deleterious or unhealthful growths, other noxious matter or other debris of any kind, found growing, lying or located on such owner's lot, parcel or area of land, or upon the sidewalk abutting same. Such notice may be served by registered or certified mail, addressed to the owner, or the agent of such owner, at his last known address or service of such notice may be perfected upon such owner or the agent of such owner as provided by OCGA Section 36-34-1 et seq. 
(d)  Action upon non-compliance . Any person who receives a written notice pursuant to subsection (c) shall have the right to appeal the decision of the city marshal and shall be entitled to a hearing, pursuant to section 1-8-1. Unless such hearing is requested within five (5) working days after receipt of the written notice, such person shall be presumed to have accepted summary process. The administrative hearing officer may affirm or deny the decision of the city marshal. If the administrative hearing officer affirms the decision of the city marshal in issuing the notice pursuant to subsection (c), the owner of the property or agent shall have ten (10) days from the date of the decision of the administrative hearing officer in which to comply with the notice received pursuant to subsection (c). If the administrative hearing officer overrules the decision of the city marshal, the owner or agent will have no further duty as a result of the notice received pursuant to subsection (c). If the owner or agent shall fail, neglect or refuse after being so notified to cut, destroy or remove such weeds, untrimmed grass, litter, trash, deleterious or unhealthful growth, other noxious matter or other debris of any kind growing, lying or located upon such owner's property or upon the sidewalk abutting same within ten (10) days after receipt of the written notice provided for in subsection (c) or within ten (10) days after the date of such notice in the event same is returned to the city by the United States Postal Service because of its inability to make delivery thereof, provided the same was properly addressed to the last known address of such owner or the agent of such owner, or within ten (10) days after the date of a decision by the administrative hearing officer affirming the decision of the city marshal, the city marshal may pay for the cutting, destroying or removal of such weeds, untrimmed grass, litter, trash, deleterious, unhealthy growth, other noxious matter or other debris of any kind or to order the removal by the city. 
(e)  Charges. When the city has effected the removal of such weeds, untrimmed grass, litter, trash, deleterious or unhealthful growths, other noxious matter or other debris of any kind, or has paid for its removal, an amount provided in Title 10 shall be charged to the owner of such property, and such charge shall be due and payable by the owner within thirty (30) days. Service of notice of such charge may be served by registered or certified mail, addressed to the owner or the agent of the owner, at his last known address or service of notice of such charge may be perfected upon the owner or the agent of the owner as provided in OCGA § 36-34-2. Upon nonpayment of such charge within thirty (30) days after receipt of the written notice of such charge, in the event same is returned to the city by the United States Postal Service because of its inability to make delivery thereof, provided the same was properly addressed to the last known address of such owner or the agent of such owner, the secretary of the council may issue an execution against such owner's property or against the owner and shall deliver the same to the levying officer of the city or his deputy, who shall levy the same upon the property liable therefore and after advertisement, and other proceedings as in the case of sales for city taxes, the same shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder. Such charge shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month in the event same is not paid in full on or before the date the bill upon such charge appears becomes delinquent. Sworn statements recorded in accordance with the provisions hereof shall be prima facie evidence that all legal formalities have been complied with and that the work has been done properly and satisfactorily and shall be full notice to every person concerned that the amount of the statement, plus interest, constitutes a charge against the property designated or described in the statement and that the same is due and collectible as provided by law. 
(f)  Penalty. Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section, shall on conviction thereof, be punished as prescribed in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 14-17.6; Ord. No. 2004-76, §§ I—III, 10-5-04) 
Cross reference— Animals, Ch. 4-1; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 4-4; fire prevention code, § 7-1-56 et seq. 
State Law reference— Georgia Pesticide Control Act of 1976, OCGA § 2-7-50 et seq. 
Sec. 3-5-13. - Loitering or prowling. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of loitering or prowling when he is in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. 
(b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(Code 1958, § 14-18; Ord. No. 2012-37, § I, 1-8-13; Ord. No. 2016-14, § I, 7-5-16) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-37, § I, adopted January 8, 2013, changed the title of section 3-5-13 from "Loitering and idling" to "Loitering."   Subsequently, Ord. No. 2016-14, § I adopted July 5, 2016, changed the title of section 3-5-13 from "Loitering" to "Loitering and prowling." These historical notations have been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 3-5-14. - Obstructing officers. 
No person shall in any manner oppose or obstruct by acts or menaces the city marshal, deputy marshal or any police officer in the discharge of his official duties, or strike or assault, molest or abuse such officer. 
(Code 1958, § 14-19) 
State Law reference— Obstruction or hindering of law enforcement officers, OCGA § 16-10-24. 
Sec. 3-5-15. - Public or private property—Injuring or defacing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person wilfully to injure or deface any church or schoolhouse, building or property belonging to the state, county, city or to any person, or for any person to write or draw figures, letters or characters, on walls thereof, or on the fences or enclosures thereof; 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the area known as "The Rock" located on the property described in Exhibit "A" and shown on the plat attached as Exhibit "B" unless such person has written permission to enter such area signed by the superintendent of the Gainesville City Schools, the principal of Gainesville High School or their designee. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, write, draw or paint letters, characters or pictures on "The Rock" located on the property described in Exhibit "A" and shown on the plat attached as Exhibit "B" unless such person has written permission to enter such area signed by the superintendent of the Gainesville City Schools, the principal of Gainesville High School or their designee. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person maliciously or wantonly to kill, disable, disfigure, destroy or injure any article or commodity of value which is the property of another. 
(e)  Any person found guilty of any of the crimes against this section shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-1-7 of this Code. Each occurrence shall constitute a separate and distinct offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Code 1958, §§ 14-25, 14-26; Ord. No. 88-11, § I, 3-15-88) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, OCGA §§ 16-7-22, 16-7-23; interference with government property, OCGA §§ 16-7-24, 16-7-25. 
EXHIBIT "A" 
All that lot, tract or parcel of land, together with all improvements thereon, situated, lying and being in the Gainesville District, GMD 411, Hall County, Georgia, being more particularly shown and designated according to a plat prepared by Edward J. Standera, Jr., Georgia Registered Surveyor, dated November 20, 1987, entitled "Survey for City of Gainesville," which plat is incorporated herein by reference for a more complete description and all other legal purposes. According to said plat, the property is more particularly described as follows: 
TO FIND THE TRUE POINT OF BEGINNING, commence at the common corner of Land Lots 155, 156, 163 and 164 of said District and County; thence South 37° 16′ 53″ East 257.60 feet to a point, being the TRUE POINT OF BEGINNING; thence from said TRUE POINT OF BEGINNING South 33° 52′ 17″ East 50.00 feet to a point; thence South 56° 07′ 43″ West 50.00 feet to a point; thence North 33° 52′ 17″ West 50.00 feet to a point; thence North 56° 07′ 43″ East 50.00 feet to the TRUE POINT OF BEGINNING. 

Sec. 3-5-16. - Same—Tampering with utility property. 
Any person who shall tap, connect with, disturb, damage, turn on or off any main, service connection or meter of any public utility in the city, whether such device is within the public ways, or on private premises, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, unless such person is acting by the consent of, or under the direction of the utility owning such property. 
(Code 1958, § 14-27) 
Cross reference— Municipal utilities, Tit. 5. 
State Law reference— Damaging, injuring or interfering with property of public utility companies, municipalities or political subdivisions, OCGA § 16-7-25. 
Sec. 3-5-17. - Same—School and recreational property, use for office purposes restricted. 
(a)  No person shall occupy as an office any space on any property of the city devoted to school purposes or recreational purposes, or devoted to use as a place of public gathering, contrary to the order of the city council. 
(b)  Any person occupying any such property contrary to the order of the city council shall be summarily ejected. 
(c)  Any person who shall occupy any property referred to in this section contrary to the order of the city council or who shall refuse to immediately vacate such property upon the order of the city council shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(d)  Each day such property shall be occupied contrary to the order of the city council shall constitute a separate and distinct offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Code 1958, § 14-27.1) 
Cross reference— Recreation and parks, Ch. 1-7. 
State Law reference— Failure to leave campus or facility of unit of university system when directed, OCGA § 16-11-35; disrupting public school, OCGA § 20-2-1181. 
Sec. 3-5-18. - Wells or excavations, covering required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow any well or like excavation to remain open or uncovered. Such wells or excavations shall be covered or capped with concrete or other permanent material. 
(Code 1958, § 14-32) 
State Law reference— Abatement of hazard from abandoned well or hole, OCGA § 44-1-14. 
Sec. 3-5-19. - Discharging firearms within the city limits. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fire, shoot off or discharge a firearm within the city. The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Persons who shall fire, shoot off or discharge a firearm in defense of person or property; 
(2)  Law enforcement officers; and 
(3)  Persons who shall fire, shoot off or discharge a firearm at a firing range approved by the sheriff or police chief of the county or city in which the firing range is located and which is supervised by law enforcement officers or representatives of a local, state or national gun club. 
(b)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section, shall on conviction thereof, be punished as prescribed in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 14-33) 
State Law reference— Discharge of firearm, OCGA § 16-11-103 et seq. 
Sec. 3-5-20. - Disturbance at night. 
No person shall make, and no person shall permit to be made on his premises by any person or thing, any noise at night calculated to disturb the peace of the city, or the rest and quiet of any of the citizens thereof. 
(Ord. No. 92-40, § 1, 10-6-92) 
Sec. 3-5-21. - Urban camping and improper use of public places. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bridge means a structure, including the approaches thereto, erected in order to afford passage over any obstruction in any public road, railroad, or other right-of-way; or to afford passage under or over existing public roads, railroads, or other rights-of-way. As used in section the definition of "bridge" shall include a controlled access highway overpass as defined herein. 
Camp means to reside in or use a location for private living accommodations, such as erecting tents or other temporary structures or objects providing shelter; sleeping in a single place for more than an hour at a time; cooking or preparing meals; or other similar activities. 
Controlled access highway overpass means a crossing of two (2) controlled access highways or of a controlled access highway and other public road, pedestrian path, railroad or public right-of-way at different levels where clearance to traffic on the lower level is obtained by elevating the higher level. 
Public park means and includes all municipal parks and trails, public playgrounds, public plazas & squares, attractions, and monuments. 
Public street means and includes all public streets and highways, public sidewalks, public benches, public parking lots, and medians. 
Store or storing personal property means leaving one's personal effects, such as, but not limited to, clothing, bedrolls, cookware, sleeping bags, luggage, knapsacks, or backpacks, unattended for more than one (1) hour. This term shall not include parking a bicycle or other mode of transportation. 
(b)  Public parks. It shall be unlawful to camp or to store personal property in any public park. 
(c)  Public streets. It shall be unlawful to camp, sleep, store personal property, sit, or lie down on any public street. 
(d)  Underneath bridges. It shall be unlawful to camp or store personal property underneath any bridge. 
(e)  Other property; blocking ingress or egress. It shall be unlawful to camp, sleep, store personal property, or to sit or lie down on any public property so as to interfere with the ingress or egress from buildings. 
(f)  Warning. No person may be arrested for violating this section until he has received an oral or written warning to cease the unlawful conduct. If the violator fails to comply with the warning issued, he is subject to arrest for urban camping. 
(g)  Exceptions: This section shall not be construed to prohibit the following behavior: 
(1)  Persons sitting or lying down as a result of a medical emergency; 
(2)  Persons sitting in wheelchairs in public parks, public streets, or other public places; 
(3)  Persons sitting down while attending parades for which valid permits have been issued; 
(4)  Persons sitting down while patronizing sidewalk cafes; 
(5)  Persons sitting on chairs or benches supplied by a public agency or abutting private property owner; provided, however, that this exception shall not be construed so as to allow persons to camp on such a chair or bench; 
(6)  Persons sitting on seats in bus zones occupied by people waiting for the bus; 
(7)  Persons sitting or lying down while waiting in an orderly line outside a box office to purchase tickets to any sporting event, concert, performance, or other special event; 
(8)  Persons sitting or lying down while waiting in an orderly line awaiting entry into any building, including shelters, or awaiting social services, such as provision of meals; or 
(9)  Children sleeping anywhere while being carried by a supervising adult or while sitting or lying in a stroller or baby carriage. 
(Ord. No. 2018-20, § I, 10-2-18) 
Sec. 3-5-22. - Prohibited solicitation. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Aggressive manner means: 
(1)  Approaching or following a person before, during, or after soliciting if the conduct is intended to or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon property in the person's possession, or is intended to, or is reasonably likely to intimidate the person being solicited into responding affirmatively to the solicitation; 
(2)  Continuing to solicit from a person after the person had given a negative response to such solicitation, if continuing the solicitation is intended to or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon property in the person's possession, or to is intended to, or is reasonably likely to intimidate the person being solicited into responding affirmatively to the solicitation; 
(3)  Intentionally touching or causing physical contact with a person, without that person's consent, in the course of soliciting; 
(4)  Intentionally blocking or interfering with the safe or free passage of the person being solicited or requiring the person, or the driver of a vehicle, to take evasive action to avoid physical contact with the person making the solicitation. Acts authorized as an exercise of one's constitutional right to picket or legally protest and acts authorized by a permit issued by the city shall not constitute an obstruction of pedestrian or vehicular traffic; or 
(5)  Using abusive or threatening language or gestures intended to or likely to cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon property in the person's possession, or intended to, or reasonably likely to intimidate the person being solicited into responding affirmatively to the solicitation. 
Automated teller machine means a device linked to a financial institution's account records which is able to perform transactions, including, but not limited to, account transfers, deposits, cash withdrawals, balance inquiries, or mortgage and loan payments. 
Automated teller machine facility means the area comprised of one (1) or more automatic teller machines and the adjacent space which is made available to financial institution customers after regular financial institution hours. 
Check cashing business means any person duly licensed to engage in the business of cashing checks, drafts, or money orders for consideration pursuant to Georgia law. 
Financial institution means any banking corporation, credit union, or foreign exchange office as defined by Georgia law. 
Public area means an area to which the public or a substantial group of persons has access, including, but not limited to, alleys, bridges, buildings, driveways, parking lots, parks, playgrounds, plazas, sidewalks, and streets that are open to the general public. 
Solicit means to request an immediate donation of money or other thing of value from another person, regardless of the solicitor's purpose or intended use of the money or other thing of value, including employment, business, or contributions, or to request the purchase of goods or services. The solicitation may be, without limitation, by the spoken, written, or printed word, or by other means of communication. 
(b)  Aggressive solicitation prohibited. It shall be unlawful to solicit in an aggressive manner in any public place. 
(c)  Other prohibited solicitation. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to solicit in any public transportation vehicle or at any bus or public transportation station or stop. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to solicit within fifteen (15) feet of any entrance or exit of any financial institution or check cashing business or within fifteen (15) feet of any automated teller machine without the consent of the owner or other person legally in possession of such facility. When an automated teller machine is located within an automated teller machine facility, the distance of fifteen (15) feet shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the automated teller machine facility. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful to solicit on private property if the owner, tenant, or lawful occupant has asked the person not to solicit on the property or has posted a sign clearly indicating that solicitations are not welcome on the property. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful to solicit any operator or other occupant of a motor vehicle while such vehicle is on any public street for the purpose of performing or offering to perform a service in connection with such a vehicle or otherwise soliciting the sale of goods or services. This subsection shall not apply to services rendered in connection with emergency repairs requested by the operator or passengers of such vehicle. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful to solicit from any operator or occupant of a motor vehicle on a public street in exchange for blocking, occupying, or reserving a public parking space. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful to solicit in any public parking lot or public parking structure. 
(7)  It shall be unlawful to solicit within ten (10) feet of an entrance to any building. 
(8)  It shall be unlawful to solicit from any person who is waiting in line for entry to any building, public or private, including, but not limited to, any residence, business, or athletic facility. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful to solicit while under the influence of alcohol or a controlled substance. 
(10)  It shall be unlawful to solicit after sunset or before sunrise. 
(11)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make a false or misleading representation in the course of soliciting. False or misleading misrepresentations include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(A)  Stating that the solicitor is from out of town and is stranded when this statement is not true; 
(B)  Stating or suggesting falsely that the solicitor is either a present or former member of the armed services; 
(C)  Displaying any indication of physical disability when the solicitor does not suffer the disability indicated; or 
(D)  Stating that the solicitor is homeless when he or she is not. 
(12)  It shall be unlawful to solicit in a group of three (3) or more persons. 
(d)  Applicability. This chapter regulates the time, place, and manner of solicitations and shall not apply to any persons exercising their clearly established constitutional right to picket, protest, or engage in other constitutionally protected activity. 
(Ord. No. 2018-21, § I, 10-2-18) 
Secs. 3-5-23—3-5-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 2. - REMOVAL, STORAGE AND DISPOSITION OF ABANDONED MOTOR VEHICLES, NONSELF-PROPELLED VEHICLES, ABANDONED PERSONAL PROPERTY AND FIREARMS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 3-4. 
State Law reference— Abandoned motor vehicles, OCGA § 40-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 3-5-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned means all personal property, except motor vehicles, that has been left unattended on any public street, road, or highway or any other public or private property within the limits of the city for a period in excess of five (5) days. 
Abandoned motor vehicle means a motor vehicle or trailer: 
(1)  Which has been left by the owner or some person acting for the owner with an automobile dealer, repairman, or wrecker service for repair or for some other reason and has not been called for by such owner or other person within a period of thirty (30) days after the time agreed upon; or within thirty (30) days after such vehicle is turned over to such dealer, repairman, or wrecker service when no time is agreed upon; or within thirty (30) days after the completion of necessary repairs; 
(2)  Which is left unattended on a public street, road, or highway or other public property for a period of at least five (5) days and when it reasonably appears to a law enforcement officer that the individual who left such motor vehicle unattended does not intend to return and remove such motor vehicle; 
(3)  Which has been lawfully towed onto the property of another at the request of a law enforcement officer and left there for a period of not less than thirty (30) days without anyone's having made claim thereto; 
(4)  Which has been lawfully towed onto the property of another at the request of a property owner on whose property the vehicle was abandoned and left there for a period of not less than thirty (30) days without the owner's having made claim thereto; or 
(5)  Which has been left unattended on private property for a period of not less than thirty (30) days without anyone's having made claim thereto. 
City marshal means the marshal of the city or his lawfully appointed deputy. 
Firearm means any weapon which fires a projectile by means of powder, spring, gas cartridge or any other means, other than by means of elastic bands and shall not include archery equipment. 
Motor vehicle means any vehicle which is self-propelled and designed to travel along the ground and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motorbikes, motorscooters, motorcycles, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts, campers and trailers. 
Nonself-propelled vehicle shall mean all vehicles other than motor vehicles whether propelled by human or by animal power and shall include, but not by way of limitation, bicycles, unicycles and tricycles. 
Other personal property means all other tangible and intangible personal property. 
Private property means any real property within the city which is privately owned and which is not public property as defined in this section. 
Public property means any street, road, highway or sidewalk which shall include the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained for the purpose of vehicular traffic or pedestrian traffic, and shall also mean other city or publicly owned property or facility. 
(Code 1958, § 14-41) 
State Law reference— Definitions relating to abandoned motor vehicles, OCGA § 40-11-1. 
Sec. 3-5-32. - Motor vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any abandoned motor vehicle upon any public or private property within the city for a period in excess of twenty-four (24) hours after such motor vehicle shall become abandoned within the meaning of this article. The presence of an abandoned motor vehicle on public or private property is hereby declared a public nuisance which may be abated as such within the provisions of this article. 
(b)  If any motor vehicle shall become an abandoned motor vehicle within the meaning of this article while located on any public street, road or highway or on any other publicly owned property within the city or upon any privately owned property in the city without the consent of the owner of such property, the chief of police or the city marshal may have such abandoned motor vehicle removed from such public street, road, highway, sidewalk or other public or private property and stored at such place as the chief of police or city marshal shall designate. Notice in writing of such action shall be given by registered mail within five (5) days to the registered owner of the vehicle or as soon thereafter as he can be ascertained. The contents of such notice shall include a complete description of the motor vehicle and license number, the date the vehicle was removed by the city, a statement of the towing cost and storage cost and notice that the owner has a right to redeem the vehicle upon payment of towing and storage cost. In addition, written notice shall be sent to the state department of revenue and the state department of public safety. 
(c)  If within seven (7) days of the date of notice of removal no person has made any claim to the abandoned motor vehicle, the chief of police or the city marshal shall sell the vehicle or vehicles at public auction upon notice of sale under this subsection. 
(1)  Notice by registered mail at least twenty (20) days prior to the date of sale shall be sent to the person or legal entity in whose name the vehicle is registered and to all persons claiming a lien on such vehicle as shown by the records of the state department of revenue or with corresponding agencies of any other state. In addition, notice of the time and place of such sale shall be given by publication of such notice once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation, or in the newspaper officially designated for legal advertisements, published in the county where such vehicle is lawfully towed at the request of a law enforcement officer, or where a person shall have such abandoned motor vehicle on his property. The first publication or posting, as the case may be, shall be at least twenty (20) days before the sale. The notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle and the date and place the vehicle was found or taken into possession, provided however, if after diligent search the registered or true owner of the abandoned vehicle cannot be determined, then the notice by registered mail shall not be required but in lieu thereof the report of sale as required by subsection (c)(4) hereof shall contain the reason why such notice could not be given. 
(2)  The chief of police or the city marshal shall have the right to reject any and all bids if the amount of the bid is unreasonably low, and shall have the right to continue the sale from time to time if no bidders are present. 
(3)  Upon sale to the highest bidder, the chief of police or the city marshal shall upon payment of the sales price issue a bill of sale to the purchaser, free and clear of all liens and encumbrances. 
(4)  The person making such sale shall promptly file with the city clerk a report of the sale, showing the date such abandoned automobile first came into his possession or was abandoned on his premises, the name of the newspaper in which notice of sale was published and the dates of such publication, the time and place of the sale, the amount for which the abandoned motor vehicle was sold, the amounts deducted from such sales price for repair, towing, storage expenses, expense of publication of notice of sale, and the amount paid over to the city clerk. Such report shall contain a statement by the person making such sale, certifying to the correctness of such report under oath. 
(5)  The proceeds of such sale shall, after the costs for towing and for storage have been deducted, be paid to the city clerk who shall hold such proceeds for one (1) year. If at the end of that period no person has made any claim thereto, the city clerk shall pay such proceeds into the general fund of the city. 
(d)  The owner of any vehicle impounded under this section may redeem such vehicle at any time after removal but prior to sale or destruction by the payment to the city clerk of all costs of towing and storage, plus all other expenses incurred in connection therewith. 
(e)  Any peace officer who, under the provisions of this section, causes any motor vehicle to be removed to a garage or other place of safety shall be liable for gross negligence only, and any person removing such vehicle or other property at the direction of a peace officer in accordance with the provisions of this section, shall have a lien on such motor vehicle for a reasonable fee for such removal and for storage of such motor vehicle. 
(Code 1958, § 14-42) 
Sec. 3-5-33. - Nonself-propelled vehicles and other personal property. 
(a)  No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any abandoned nonself-propelled vehicle or other personal property upon any public or private property within the city. The presence of any abandoned nonself-propelled vehicle or other personal property on any public or private property shall constitute a public nuisance which may be abated as such under the provisions of this article. This subsection shall not apply to any person who places such a vehicle at the curbside for the regular pickup of such refuse as provided by this Code. 
(b)  The procedure for the removal of such vehicles or personal property shall be the same as for abandoned motor vehicles except that no notice to a registered owner or to the state department of revenue or the state department of public safety shall be required. 
(c)  The method of notice and sale by the chief of police or the city marshal shall be the same as that for abandoned motor vehicles except that the proceeds shall not be held by the clerk for one (1) year but shall be paid immediately into the general fund for the city. 
(Code 1958, § 14-43) 
Sec. 3-5-34. - Firearms. 
(a)  All firearms which come into the possession of the city whether due to the commission of a crime or otherwise shall be stored in a properly secured area within the city public safety building. 
(b)  All firearms which come into the possession of the city due to the commission of a crime shall be held until the final disposition of any proceedings arising out of the commission of such crime before being disposed of. All other firearms shall be held for thirty (30) days before being disposed of. 
(c)  Firearms shall be disposed of as follows: 
(1)  They shall be returned to their lawful owner: 
a.  If the weapon was used in the commission of a crime but the lawful owner was not convicted thereof, or 
b.  If the weapon was lost or stolen and recovered by city law enforcement personnel. 
(2)  If not returned to the lawful owner under provisions of subsection (c)(1) above, they shall be sold or destroyed by the chief of police or city marshal as provided below regardless of whether the firearm came into the possession of the city due to the commission of a crime or otherwise. At such time as there shall be a final judgment entered finding the accused guilty of the commission or attempted commission of a crime against any person, any firearm which was used as a weapon in the commission of such crime which was the property of the accused shall be turned over by the person having custody of such device to the chief of police or the city marshal wherein such device was confiscated. The chief of police or the city marshal shall within ninety (90) days after receiving such device either destroy the same or advertise it for sale in such manner as sheriff's sales are advertised and shall sell such devices to the highest bidder at the sale conducted after the completion of the advertisements and fulfilling the requirements of the laws of the United States and this state pertaining to the sale of firearms. The proceeds of any sale shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(3)  All handguns which are .32 caliber or smaller, have a barrel four (4) inches or less in length, and have a market value of less than forty dollars ($40.00) and all weapons which are declared illegal by the Federal Firearms Control Act, 18 U.S.C., Section 921 et seq. shall be destroyed by the chief of police or the city marshal. 
(4)  All provisions of this subsection except where no forfeiture would work under subsections (c)(1) and (2) or under any other federal or state law shall be subject to the following provision: In the event the director of the state department of archives and history or the director of state department of public safety, in that order or priority, shall desire to receive and retain the device for historical or instruction purposes of his department and gives written notice thereof to the chief of police or city marshal either prior to the advertisement of same for sale or within ten (10) days thereafter, the chief of police or city marshal shall forthwith deliver the device to the department which shall retain same for such purposes. A device delivered to such department in accordance herewith shall become property of the state. 
(Code 1958, § 14-44) 
State Law reference— Disposition of weapon involved in criminal offense, OCGA §§ 17-5-51, 17-5-52; department of public safety, OCGA § 35-2-1 et seq.; department of archives and history, OCGA § 45-13-40 et seq. 
Sec. 3-5-35. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-7 of this Code. Each act in violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1958, § 14-45) 
Sec. 3-5-36. - Article provisions deemed cumulative and supplemental. 
This article is hereby declared to be cumulative of and supplemental to any power or authority now possessed by the city relative to the disposal of discarded, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped, ruined or junk motor vehicles under any provision of law, and not in lieu thereof, and supplemental and cumulative of any state law relative to same. 
(Code 1958, § 14-46) 
Secs. 3-5-37—3-5-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 3. - RESTRICTED CITY FACILITIES 

Sec. 3-5-51. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Escort means an employee or other official of the city who has authorized access to restricted city facilities. 
Restricted city facilities means those areas, under the operation and control of the city, that are posted with at least one (1) sign bearing the following legend: "Restricted City Facility." 
(Code 1958, § 14-51) 
Sec. 3-5-52. - Declaration of policy. 
The rapid increase in the abuse of unauthorized persons in entering certain sensitive and extremely dangerous city facilities is a matter of concern to the city council and to the people of the city. Such abusive actions threaten the city's liability and endanger the safety of each person, authorized or unauthorized, coming in contact with such sensitive city facilities. Therefore, in order to ensure the safety of each of the individuals and the public, to limit the city's liability, to enable such sensitive city facilities to operate without distraction, and to protect the lives and property of the people of the city, this article is hereby enacted. 
(Code 1958, § 14-50) 
Sec. 3-5-53. - Declared prohibited areas. 
It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to enter or for any person in charge of a restricted city facility to permit any unauthorized person to enter any restricted city facility without an escort, unless such person has permission to enter such areas through the consent of the city manager or by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1958, § 14-52) 
Sec. 3-5-54. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any section of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 14-53)

ARTICLE 2. - AIR POLLUTION[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference— Fire prevention code, § 7-1-56 et seq. 

Sec. 3-6-11. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Air-cleaning device means any method, process, or equipment which removes, reduces, or renders less noxious air contaminants discharged into the atmosphere. 
Air contaminant means solid or liquid particulate matter, dust, fumes, gas, mist, smoke, or vapor or any matter or substance either physical, chemical, biological, radioactive (including source material, special nuclear material, and by-product material), or any combination of any of the above. 
Air pollution means the presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one (1) or more air contaminants. 
Approved means meeting the requirements of the public works director. 
ASTM means the American Society for Testing and Materials. 
Chimney means a vertical masonry or concrete shaft enclosing one (1) or more flues. 
Department means the public works department. 
Dust means solid particles released into, or carried in the air by natural forces, or by any fuel-burning, combustion or process equipment or device or by construction work, or by mechanical or industrial process. 
Excess air means air entering a combustion chamber in excess of the amount theoretically required for complete combustion of materials in the combustion chamber. 
Flue means a passageway for the purpose of removing products of combustion from solid, liquid or gas fuel. 
Fly ash means particulate matter capable of being gas-borne or air-borne and consisting essentially of fused ash and/or other burned or unburned materials resulting from combustion of fuel or refuse. 
Fuel-burning equipment (incinerator) means any equipment, device or contrivance for burning any fuel except refuse and all appurtenances thereto, which is used for indirect heating and in which the material being heated is not contacted by, and adds no substance to, the products of combustion. Such equipment typically includes that used for; heating water, generating or super-heating steam, heating air as in warm air furnaces, furnishing process heat indirectly through transfer by fluids or transmission through process vessel walls. 
Hand fired fuel-burning equipment means fuel- burning equipment in which fresh fuel is manually introduced directly into the combustion chamber. 
Incinerator means any equipment, device, or contrivance used for the destruction and/or reduction of rubbish or other waste by burning, and all appurtenances thereto. 
Multiple chamber incinerator means any article, machine, equipment, or contrivance which is used for disposal of refuse by burning and which consists of a series of three (3) or more combustion chambers physically separated by refractory walls, inter-connected by gas passages or ducts, lined with refractories having a pyrometric cone equivalent of at least 17, tested according to ASTM Method C-24, and is designed for efficient combustion of the type and volume of material to be burned. 
Objectionable odor means an odor deemed objectionable by the public works director and at least twenty-five (25) percent of the people exposed to it if there are at least twenty (20) people so exposed or at least five (5) people if there are fewer than twenty (20) people exposed. 
Open burning means any outdoor fire from which the products of combustion are emitted directly into the open air without passing through a flue. 
Particulate matter means material other than water, which is suspended in air or other gases, in a finely divided form as a liquid or solid. 
Person means any individual, corporation, partnership, association, state, municipality or political subdivision of a state, and any agency, department or instrumentality of the United States government, or any other entity, and any officer, agent or employee of any of the above. 
Process equipment means any equipment, device or contrivance for mixing, changing, storing, or handling any material, the use or existence of which may cause any discharge of air contaminants into the open air, but excluding that equipment defined herein as "fuel-burning equipment" or "incinerator." 
Process input weight rate means a rate established as follows: 
(1)  For continuous or long-run, steady-state source operations, the total process weight for the entire period of continuous operation or for a typical portion thereof, divided by the number of hours of such period. 
(2)  For cyclical or batch source operations, the total process weight for a period that covers a complete operation or an integral number of cycles, divided by the hours of actual process operation during such a period. Where the nature of any process or operation or the design of any equipment is such as to permit more than one interpretation of this definition, the interpretation that results in the minimum value for allowable emission shall apply. When recycled material is handled by the process equipment, it shall be included in the total process weight. Moisture shall not be considered as part of process weight. 
Public works director means the public works director or his designee. 
Ringelmann smoke chart means the chart published and described in the U.S. Bureau of Mines Information Circular 7718 for use in measuring the shades, density or opacity of air contaminants arising from stacks and other sources, and being on file in the department. The miniature Ringelmann is a derivative of the above in common use. 
Smoke means gas-borne or air-borne particles resulting from combustion operations and industrial processes and consisting of carbon and ash or other matter and present in sufficient quantity to be visible. 
Source means any property, source, facility, building, structure, location or installation at, from or by reason of which emissions of air contaminants are or may reasonably be expected to be emitted into the atmosphere. Such terms include both real and personal property, stationary and mobile sources or facilities, and direct and indirect sources or facilities, without regard to ownership, and both public or private property. 
Standard cubic foot means one (1) cubic foot of a gas mixture corrected to standard conditions of sixty (60) degrees Fahrenheit and 14.7 pounds per square inch absolute. 
Vapor means the gaseous form of a substance normally in the liquid or solid state. 
(Code 1958, § 16-1) 
State Law reference— Definitions relating to air quality, OCGA § 12-9-3. 
Sec. 3-6-12. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person charged with a violation of any provision of this article shall be given a written notice and instructions from the public works director as to the required remedy for such violation and shall be given thirty (30) days to comply. Failure to comply with the requirements of such written notice and instructions shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and in addition thereto may be enjoined from continuing such violation. Each day violations occur thirty (30) days after receipt of notice of violations, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1958, § 16-10) 
Sec. 3-6-13. - Visible emissions; prohibited, exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall cause, allow or permit visible smoke into the open air from any source, of an opacity, shade or appearance equal to or darker than number two (2) of the Ringelmann Smoke Chart. The use of miniature Ringelmann charts to determine compliance with this section is authorized. 
(b)  Exceptions to subsection (a) are as follows: 
(1)  Visible emissions consisting of uncombined water droplets. 
(2)  Smoke emitted during the cleaning of a fire, the building of a new fire or the blowing of soot from boiler surfaces, the shade or appearance of which is not darker than number three (3) of the Ringelmann Smoke Chart for a period or periods aggregating no more than three (3) minutes in any thirty (30) consecutive minutes. 
(3)  Smoke resulting from any fire ignited for the purpose of training firemen or for research in fire protection or prevention. 
(4)  Smoke resulting temporarily and briefly from an unavoidable breakdown or malfunction of equipment, provided that nothing in this section shall be construed to permit the continued operation of equipment subject to repeated breakdown or chronic malfunction, or of equipment so obsolete or worn as to require frequent repairs or to preclude dependable and efficient operation. The department shall be notified when breakdowns of equipment cause smoking for thirty (30) minutes or longer, by the owner or his agent. 
(Code 1958, § 16-2) 
State Law reference— Control of air pollution by state, OCGA § 12-9-4 et seq. 
Sec. 3-6-14. - Open burning. 
(a)  No open burning shall be allowed on any premises, except for the cooking of food and/or training of firefighting personnel except under a permit from the fire department under the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code, Article 501, section 501.1. 
(b)  Materials such as asphaltic materials, plastic materials, rubber materials, gasoline and/or oils, or any other material producing dense smoke and/or obnoxious odors shall not be used for starting or maintaining an open fire as permitted in subsection (a) above. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-1-7. 
(Code 1958, § 16-3) 
Sec. 3-6-15. - Incinerators; minimum requirements. 
(a)  No person shall construct a new incinerator within the city unless: 
(1)  It is a multiple chamber incinerator with sufficient combustion volume for its rated capacity and type of material to be burned. 
(2)  It is provided with an auxiliary burner for the purposes of creating pre-ignition temperatures. 
(3)  It has an efficient gas washer of the venturi or impingement type with at least three (3) wet impingement surfaces plus any needed dry collection or electrostatic equipment. 
(4)  It has an adequate and approved induced draft fan. 
(5)  It has a secondary burner for use when necessary to destroy smoke and/or odors and maintains a temperature of at least fifteen hundred (1500) degrees Fahrenheit in the secondary chamber. 
(6)  Designs other than those mentioned above shall be considered on an individual basis and will be exempt from those provisions if, in the judgment of the department, such design results in performance which meets the standards set forth in subsection (c). 
(b)  Incinerators shall be maintained in good working order and shall be operated so as to: 
(1)  Maintain a temperature of at least eight hundred (800) degrees Fahrenheit in the primary combustion chamber. 
(2)  Comply with generally recognized good practices and all applicable provisions of this article. 
(3)  Make full and proper use of all components and appurtenances thereof. 
(c)  No person shall cause or allow to be emitted into the open air from any refuse-burning equipment, fly ash or other particulate matter in quantities exceeding 0.2 grains per dry standard cubic foot of flue gases, calculated to twelve (12) percent carbon dioxide for products of combustion and at sixty (60) degrees Fahrenheit and at a gas pressure of 14.7 pounds per square inch absolute. This limitation shall apply when the refuse-burning equipment is operating at full load. In measuring emissions from refuse-burning equipment, the carbon dioxide produced by combustion of any "auxiliary" fuels shall be excluded from the calculation to twelve (12) percent carbon dioxide. 
(Code 1958, § 16-4) 
Sec. 3-6-16. - Emission of fly ash and other solid particulate matter from fuel-burning equipment. 
(a)  No person shall cause, let, permit, suffer or allow any emission from any fuel-burning equipment which does not comply with the visible emission limitations in Figure 1 (maximum permissible emission of fly ash and other particulate matter from fuel-burning installations), which is hereinafter set out. 
(b)  Equipment in operation, or under construction contract, on or before September 2, 1969, shall be considered existing equipment. All other equipment put in operation or extensively altered after said date is to be considered new equipment. 
(c)  No person shall cause, let, permit, suffer, or allow the emission from any fuel-burning equipment of particles in sufficient number, or of sufficient size, or of such nature as to be visible individually as incandescent particles so as to unreasonably interfere with enjoyment of life, or use of the property of any other person. This subsection shall only apply if such particles fall on real property other than that of the person responsible for the emission. 
(Code 1958, § 16-5)
