(4)  The following three publications: "Do 'Off Site' Adult Businesses have Secondary Effects? Legal Doctrine, Social Theory, and Empirical Evidence" by Richard McCleary and Alan C. Weinstein; "Rural Hotspots—The Case of Adult Businesses" by Richard McCleary, Criminal Justice Policy Review; and "Do Peep Shows 'Cause' Crime?—A Response to Linz, Paul, and Yao" by Richard McCleary and James W. Meeker; 
(5)  The transcript of proceedings before the City Council of the City of Sandy Springs, Georgia, of December 20, 2007, and December 27, 2007, which documents extensive evidence of adverse secondary effects of adult entertainment; 
(6)  The following special reports relating to the secondary effects of adult entertainment establishments on real property values: September 2004 Survey of Appraisers, Forth [Fort] Worth and Dallas, Texas; May 2008 Survey of Appraisers, Palm Beach County, Florida; and June 2008 Survey of Texas Appraisers, Texas City Attorneys Association; 
(7)  Certain documents and information consisting of thirty nine (39) pages relating to the guilty plea and plea agreement in the criminal prosecution case of former Fulton County Police Lieutenant Mark Timothy Lance; 
(8)  A report by BCI private investigators relating to adult bookstores in Sandy Springs, Georgia; and 
(9)  A report by BCI private investigators relating to adult cabarets in Sandy Springs, Georgia; and 
(10)  The February 16, 2010 decision of the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals in the case of Flanigan's Enterprises, Inc., of Georgia v. Fulton County, Georgia, No. 08-17035, 2010 WL 520542 (11 th Cir. 2010), detailing evidence of numerous adverse secondary effects resulting from the activities of adult entertainment establishments; and 
(11)  Other evidence presented at various hearings and meetings of the mayor and city council relating to adverse secondary effects of adult entertainment, which has been recorded and incorporated into the record of proceedings of the City of Gainesville, including past meetings of the governing body. 
(b)  Based upon all of this evidence, the City of Gainesville Governing Body finds: 
(1)  Sexually oriented businesses, also known as adult entertainment establishments, lend themselves to ancillary unlawful and unhealthy activities that can be uncontrolled or inadequately controlled by the operators of the establishments. The commercial exploitation of human sexuality, in all forms in which such exploitation may be manifested, has a deleterious effect on the community where it takes place. Sexually oriented businesses cause an increase in criminal behavior in nearby areas, including, but not limited to, disorderly conduct, prostitution, solicitation, drug trafficking, drug use, assaults and batteries, and corruption of public officials. 
(2)  Sexual acts, including masturbation, oral sex, and anal sex, occur at sexually oriented businesses. Offering or providing private or semi-private space encourages such activities, which creates unhealthy conditions. 
(3)  Adult entertainment establishments escalate and exacerbate undesirable community conditions, including, but not limited to, blight, diminished property values, increased need for law enforcement and emergency medical response resources, and increased burden on the judicial system as a result of the criminal behavior which the governing body finds such business establishments bring to a community. The negative secondary effects that are caused by such businesses are not limited to facilities that offer live or recorded performances with human nudity or the depiction of sexual acts, but also arise from other forms of sexually oriented businesses that also have a deleterious effect on nearby neighborhoods, commercial districts, and urban life in general. These other types of sexually oriented businesses include, but are not limited to, adult bookstores, peep shows, massage parlors, bath houses, adult gift and novelty shops, and lingerie or nude modeling studios. 
(4)  Persons frequent certain adult theatres, adult arcades, and other sexually oriented businesses for the purpose of engaging in sex within the premises of such sexually oriented businesses. 
(5)  Communicable diseases may be spread by activities occurring in sexually oriented businesses. 
(6)  AIDS and HIV infection may be transmitted through sexual contact, intravenous drug abuse, exposure to infected blood and blood components. 
(7)  According to the best scientific evidence, AIDS and HIV infection, as well as syphilis and gonorrhea, are principally transmitted by sexual acts. 
(8)  Sanitary conditions in some sexually oriented businesses are unhealthy, in part, because the activities conducted there are unhealthy and, in part, because of the unregulated nature of the activities and the failure of the owners and the operators of the facilities to self-regulate those activities and maintain those facilities. 
(9)  Numerous studies and reports have determined that semen is found in some areas of some sexually oriented businesses. 
(10)  The findings noted in paragraphs number (1) through (9) raise substantial governmental concerns. 
(11)  Sexually oriented businesses have operational characteristics which should be reasonably regulated in order to protect those substantial governmental concerns. 
(12)  Removal of doors on adult booths and requiring sufficient lighting on premises with adult booths advances a substantial governmental interest in curbing the illegal and unsanitary sexual activity occurring in adult entertainment establishments as defined herein. 
(13)  Requiring licensees of sexually oriented businesses to keep information regarding current employees and certain past employees will help reduce the incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects and by preventing minors from working in such establishments. 
(14)  The disclosure of certain information by those persons ultimately responsible for the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the sexually oriented business, where such information is substantially related to the significant governmental interest in the operation of such uses, will aid in preventing the spread of sexually-transmitted diseases and other secondary negative effects as described herein. 
(15)  It is desirable in the prevention of the spread of communicable diseases to obtain a limited amount of information regarding employees who may engage in the conduct which this chapter is designed to prevent or who are likely to be witnesses to such activity. 
(16)  The fact that an applicant for an adult entertainment license has been convicted of a sexually related crime leads to the rational assumption that the applicant may engage in that conduct in contravention of this chapter. 
(17)  The barring of such individuals from the management of adult entertainment establishments for a period of years serves as a deterrent to and prevents conduct which leads to the transmission of sexually-transmitted diseases. 
(18)  The general welfare, health, morals and safety of the citizens of the City of Gainesville will be promoted by the enactment of this chapter. 
(c)  Based on the experiences of other counties and municipalities as described above, which experiences are found to be relevant to the problems faced by the City of Gainesville, Georgia; and based on the documentary and oral evidence presented at the public hearings before the mayor and city council (hereinafter "the governing body") held prior to the adoption of this article; and based on the evidence and statements of persons who have appeared before members of the governing body on other occasions, and on other documentary evidence submitted to the governing body, the Governing Body for the City of Gainesville, Georgia, takes note of the well-known and self-evident conditions and secondary effects attendant to the commercial exploitation of human sexuality, which do not vary greatly among the various communities within our country. 
It is the finding of the governing body that public nudity (either partial or total) under certain circumstances in establishments offering live nude entertainment or "adult entertainment," begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. In the same manner, establishments offering cinematographic or videographic adult entertainment have the same deleterious effects on the community. 
Among the undesirable community conditions identified in other communities with commercial nudity and cinematographic or videographic adult entertainment are criminal activity, depression of property values, and acceleration of community blight in the surrounding neighborhoods, increased allocation of and expenditure for law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, and increased burden on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior hereinabove referenced. The governing body finds it is reasonable to believe that some or all of these undesirable community conditions will result in the City of Gainesville, Georgia, as well, unless these regulations are adopted. 
Furthermore, it is the finding of the governing body that live nude or semi-nude entertainment and other forms of adult entertainment including, but not limited to, adult book stores, adult novelty shops, adult video stores, peep shows, adult theaters, and massage parlors have an adverse effect upon the quality of life in the city and surrounding communities. 
The governing body further finds that each separate adverse secondary effect of adult entertainment businesses and sexually oriented businesses constitutes a substantial government interest, that each substantial government interest includes, but is not limited to, preventing future adverse secondary effects of both pre-existing sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment businesses in the city and those that may open in the future, and the viability of each separate substantial government interest of the city addressed herein does not depend upon any comparative analysis between adult entertainment businesses and nonadult entertainment businesses. 
The governing body therefore finds that it is in the best interests of the health, welfare, safety, and morals of the city and the community and the preservation of its businesses, neighborhoods, churches, schools, residential areas, public parks and children's day care facilities to prevent or reduce the adverse impacts of adult entertainment establishments. Therefore, the governing body of the city finds that licensing and regulations are necessary for any adult entertainment establishment, and finds that these regulations promote the public welfare by furthering legitimate public and governmental interests, including, but not limited to, reducing criminal activity and protecting against or eliminating undesirable community conditions. The governing body further finds that licensing and regulations will not infringe upon the protected constitutional rights of freedom of speech or expression. To all of these ends, this chapter is hereby adopted. 
Also based upon all of the information, studies, reports, statements, findings in court decisions, and testimony referenced above, as well as the well-known and self-evident conditions and secondary effects caused by the commercial exploitation of commercial total nudity combined with the sale, dispensing and consumption of alcoholic beverages, the governing body also finds and concludes that the sale, dispensing, or consumption of alcoholic beverages of any kind in an adult entertainment establishment as defined herein tends to independently create, aggravate, exacerbate, and add to all of those negative secondary effects set forth in this section. The purpose and intent of this chapter is to address and forestall those negative secondary effects in the City of Gainesville, Georgia, within the permissible limits and parameters of the Georgia and United States constitutions. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-2. - Definitions. 
Except as specifically defined herein, all words used in this chapter shall be as defined in the most recent edition of the New Illustrated Book of Development Definitions (Rutgers). Words not defined herein or in the foregoing book shall be construed to have the meaning given by common and ordinary use, and shall be interpreted within the context of the sentence and section in which they occur. The following terms used in this chapter defining adult entertainment establishments shall have the meanings indicated below: 
Adult bookstore means a commercial establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, merchandise, books, magazines, or other periodicals or publications which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or an establishment wherein ten (10) or more square feet of the total floor space devoted to the sale or display of merchandise is dedicated to the sale or display of such materials and/or merchandise, or an establishment which derives five (5) percent or more of its annual net sales from such materials or merchandise. When an applicant applies for a city business license to operate a bookstore in which any such materials or merchandise will be sold, the applicant shall furnish the city marshal with a detailed drawing of the inside of the structure where the business will or is being operated with the square footage of the structure (as measured along the inside walls) and showing the location and square footage of the total space dedicated for the sale and/or display of materials and merchandise which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matters depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Upon request of the city marshal, the owner of a store selling or displaying any such materials or merchandise shall furnish a copy of its annual net sales from such materials and/or merchandise, and a copy of its overall annual net sales figures for the past five (5) years. 
Adult dancing establishment means a business that features dancers displaying or exposing specified anatomical areas. 
Adult entertainer means any person employed by an adult entertainment establishment who exposes his or her "specified anatomical areas," as defined herein. For purposes of this chapter, adult entertainers include employees, as well as independent contractors, and "adult entertainer" also includes any person who exposes his or her "specified anatomical areas" in any adult entertainment establishment, even if such person is not compensated or paid. Adult entertainers also include persons who perform in a manner so as to feature, depict, display, or emphasize their genitals, pubic region, anus, or female breasts, even if their specified anatomical areas are opaquely covered. 
Adult entertainment means entertainment that is characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, display, or featuring of "specified anatomical areas." Adult entertainment includes performances by persons that are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on "specified sexual activities" as defined herein, and/or performances that feature, depict, display, or emphasize performers' genitals, pubic region, anus, or female breasts, even if their specified anatomical areas are opaquely covered. 
Adult entertainment establishment shall be defined to include the following types of businesses: 
(1)  Any commercial establishment that employs or uses any person live, in any capacity in the sale or service of beverages or food while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing, so as to expose any portion of his or her "specified anatomical areas," as defined herein; 
(2)  Any commercial establishment which provides live entertainment where any person appears unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose any portion of his or her "specified anatomical areas" as defined herein or where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on "specified sexual activities" as defined herein; 
(3)  Any commercial establishment in which persons perform live in a manner so as to feature, depict, display, or emphasize their genitals, pubic region, anus, buttocks, or female breasts, even if their specified anatomical areas are opaquely covered; 
(4)  Any commercial establishment which holds, promotes, sponsors or allows any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in subsections (1), (2), and/or (3) herein; 
(5)  Any commercial establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, books, magazines or other periodicals, videotapes or movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" as defined herein or "specified anatomical areas" as defined herein or having a segment or section comprising more than fifty (50) square feet of its total floor space, devoted to the sale or display of such material, or which utilizes twenty-five (25) percent or more of its display area for the display or offer for sale or rental of such media or materials, or which derives more than five (5) percent of its net sales from the sale or rental of such media or material; 
(6)  Any commercial establishment utilizing an enclosed building with a capacity of fifty (50) or more persons used for cinematographic or videographic presentation of material distinguished by or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas", as defined herein, for observation by patrons therein; 
(7)  Any adult motion picture theater, adult motion picture arcade, adult mini-motion picture theater, adult bookstore, adult dancing establishment, or adult video store, as defined herein; 
(8)  The definition of "adult entertainment establishment" shall not include traditional or mainstream theater, which means a theater, movie theater, concert hall, museum, educational institution, or similar establishment which regularly features live or other performances or showings which are not distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, display, or description or the featuring of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities in that the depiction, display, description or featuring is incidental to the primary purpose of any performance. For purposes of this subsection, such performances and showings are regularly featured when they comprise at least eighty (80) percent of all annual performances or showings. 
Adult mini-motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity for less than fifty (50) persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult motion picture arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein paper currency, coin- or slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projectors or other impact producing devices are maintained to show images to five (5) or fewer persons per machine at any one (1) time and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of fifty (50) or more persons, used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult video store means a commercial establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, video tapes, movies, merchandise, or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or an establishment wherein ten (10) square feet or more of its total floor space devoted to the sale or display of merchandise is dedicated to the sale or display of such materials or merchandise, or an establishment which derives five (5) percent or more of its annual net sales from the sale or rental of video merchandise which is characterized or distinguished by its emphasis on matter depicting specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. When an applicant applies for a city business license to operate a store selling or renting video tapes, movies, or other reproductions in which any such video tapes, movies, or other reproductions will be sold, the applicant shall furnish the city marshal with a detailed drawing of the inside of the structure where the business will or is being operated with the square footage of the structure (as measured along the inside walls) and showing the location and square footage of the total space dedicated for the sale and/or display of materials and merchandise which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matters depicting describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Upon request of the city marshal, the owner of a store selling or displaying any such materials or merchandise shall furnish a copy of its annual net sales from such materials and/or merchandise, and a copy of its overall annual net sales figures for the past five (5) years. 
City means the City of Gainesville, Georgia. 
Church means a body of communicants gathered into church order: united under one (1) form of government by the profession of the same faith and the observance of the same ritual and ceremonies, place where persons regularly assemble for worship, congregation, or organization for religious purposes. 
Convicted or conviction shall mean and include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime or an ordinance violation in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
Good moral character means a person is of good moral character according to this chapter if that person has not been convicted of a drug-related or alcohol-related felony, sex-related crime, or a crime of moral turpitude, or the attempt to commit any such criminal act, in the past five (5) years. 
Minor means, for the purposes of this chapter, any person who has not attained the age of eighteen (18) years. 
Specific anatomical areas shall include any of the following: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region, anus, buttocks, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or 
(2)  Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified sexual activities shall include any of the following: 
(1)  Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory functions in the context of sexual relations, and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellatio, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, sapphism, zooerasty; or 
(2)  Clearly depicted human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; or 
(3)  Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus or masturbation; or 
(4)  Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast; or 
(5)  Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the infliction of pain; or 
(6)  Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being; or 
(7)  Human excretion, urination, menstruation, vaginal or anal irrigation. 
State means the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-3. - Regulations. 
(a)  No person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall advertise, or cause to be advertised, an adult entertainment establishment, as defined in this chapter, without a valid adult entertainment license issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  An adult entertainment establishment licensee shall maintain and retain for a period of two (2) years from the date employed the names, addresses and ages of all persons employed as dancers and/or models. 
(c)  No adult entertainment establishment licensee shall employ or contract with as a dancer or model a person under the age of eighteen (18) years or a person not licensed pursuant to this chapter. 
(d)  No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be admitted to an adult entertainment establishment. 
(e)  An adult entertainment establishment, as defined in this chapter, shall be closed between 12:45 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. each day and on Christmas Day. 
(f)  An adult entertainment establishment licensee shall conspicuously display all licenses required by this chapter. 
(g)  All dancing and/or modeling shall occur on a platform intended for that purpose which is raised at least two (2) feet from the level of the floor. 
(h)  No adult entertainment licensee shall suffer or permit an employee or any other person on the premises to engage in any specified sexual activity. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-4. - Exceptions. 
This chapter applies only to commercial adult bookstores, adult dancing establishments, adult entertainment establishments, adult mini-motion picture theaters, adult motion picture arcades, adult motion picture theaters, and adult video stores, and to employees and patrons thereof, including adult entertainers. It does not apply to mainstream performance houses, museums or theaters not specifically defined herein, nor does it apply to noncommercial activity in private residences (single-family or multiple-family) or private behavior. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-5. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership, corporation or limited liability company, or any other entity to engage in adult entertainment, or to conduct, promote, or carry on, in or upon any premises within the city, any adult entertainment establishment as defined in this chapter without a permit or license to do so. No permit or license so issued shall condone or make legal any activity thereunder if the same is deemed illegal or unlawful under the laws of the state or the United States. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-6. - Operation of unlicensed premises unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an adult bookstore, adult dancing establishment, adult mini-motion picture theater, adult motion picture arcade, adult motion picture theater, adult video store, or any other adult entertainment establishment unless such business shall have a currently valid license or permit or shall have made proper application for renewal within the time required thereof under this chapter, provided that such license or permit is not under suspension or permanently or conditionally revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-7. - Admission of minors unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for a licensee to admit or permit the admission of minors within the premises of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-8. - Sales to minors unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter, or give to any minor any service, material, device, or thing sold or offered for sale by an adult entertainment establishment, adult bookstore, adult motion picture theater, adult mini-motion picture theater, adult motion picture arcade, adult video store, or adult dancing establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-9. - Location. 
No adult entertainment establishment restricted hereunder shall be located: 
(1)  Within three hundred (300) feet of any parcel of land which is zoned inherently to allow multiple-family or single-family uses or purposes. 
(2)  Within three hundred (300) feet of any parcel of land upon which a church, school, governmental building which is simultaneously owned and occupied by a government entity, library, civic center, public park, or playground is located. 
(3)  Within one thousand (1,000) feet of any parcel of land upon which another adult entertainment establishment is located. 
(4)  Within any zoning category other than the following two (2) categories: 
a.  Light industrial (L-1) as defined in Gainesville City Code chapter 9-6-6. 
b.  Heavy industrial (H-I) as defined in Gainesville City Code chapter 9-6-7. 
For the purposes of this section, distances shall be by airline measurement from property line to property line using the closest property line of the parcels of land involved. The term "parcel of land" means any quantity of land capable of being described by location and boundary, and designated and used or to be used as a unit. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-10. - Adult entertainment establishment employees. 
(a)  Qualifications. Employees of an adult entertainment establishment shall not be less than eighteen (18) years of age. Every employee must be of good moral character as defined in this chapter. Any employee who is convicted of a sex-related crime, crime of moral turpitude, or drug-related or alcohol-related felony or an attempt to commit such crimes while employed as an adult entertainment establishment employee shall not thereafter work on any premises requiring a license under this chapter for a period of five (5) years from the date of such conviction unless a longer time is ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. The term "convicted" shall include an adjudication of guilt, a plea of guilty, a plea of nolo contendere or a bond forfeiture. The terms "employed as an adult entertainment establishment employee" and "worked on any licensed premises" shall include all work done or services performed while in the scope of employment elsewhere than on the licensed premises. 
(b)  Approval for employment. Before any person may work on a licensed premises, such person shall file a notice of intended employment with the city police department on forms that require applicant's full name, current address, Social Security Number, date of birth, birth place, race, sex, telephone number, aliases, nationality, driver's license number, addresses for last five (5) years, business occupation and employment history for the last five (5) years, proof of age (certified birth certificate, photo I.D. from governmental agency) and complete information concerning the conviction of any crime within the past five (5) years. Upon the filing of the notice with the city police department, the applicant may become a conditional employee and work on the licensed premises. The city shall have forty-five (45) days to investigate the information furnished by the applicant. If the applicant is found to be of good moral character, and if the applicant has not falsified the application or failed to disclose information required on the application, the chief of police shall grant approval of employment. Upon approval, the applicant shall be issued an employee permit to work on the licensed premises. The permit shall be with the employee when the employee is on the licensed premises. 
(c)  Appeal. Notification of any denial, suspension, or revocation of a permit for employment in a licensed premises shall be in writing and served either in person or by certified mail to the address listed in the permit application (as updated) and shall contain the reasons for such action and the notice of the right to appeal the decision. 
(1)  Decisions of the chief of police denying, suspending, revoking, or otherwise adversely affecting or aggrieving an applicant or permit holder may be appealed to the administrative hearing officer, as provided in section 1-8-1 of this Code. All appeals shall be submitted in writing to the chief of police within ten (10) calendar days after notification of the adverse action, and shall contain the grounds for the appeal. 
(2)  A hearing shall be conducted on each appeal within forty-five (45) days of the date of the filing of the written appeal, unless a continuance of such hearing is agreed to by the applicant and the chief of police, or unless the hearing is rescheduled by the hearing officer for good cause shown, otherwise, the permit is deemed granted. 
(3)  The appellant shall be notified in writing of the date and time of the hearing at least seven (7) calendar days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(4)  The findings of the administrative hearing officer shall be final unless appealed by certiorari to the Superior Court of Hall County within thirty (30) days of the date of the finding. 
(5)  Applicants and permit holders shall have the duty to furnish the city's police department with a new mailing address if the applicant's or permit holder's address shall change during the investigation/appeal period or term of employment at the licensed premises. 
(d)  Suspension, revocation of permit. Conviction of violating the provisions of this Code, the ordinances of the city, laws and regulations of the state, or the rules and regulations of the city shall subject an employee to suspension or revocation of their permit for a period of not less than one (1) year. Permit holders who are found to have falsified the application or failed to disclose information required on the application shall also have their permit suspended or revoked for a period of not less than one (1) year. 
(e)  Permits nontransferable. Employee permits are nontransferable and are valid only for the individual named on the permit. Each such permit is valid for the individual named while employed in any establishment licensed in the city. 
(f)  Independent contractors. For the purpose of this chapter, independent contractors shall be considered as employees and shall be licensed as employees, regardless of the business relationship with the owner of license of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(g)  Fees. A nonrefundable fee as designated in title 10 of this Code must be paid at the time of filing the notice of intended employment with adult entertainment establishments. The amount of the fee shall be calculated by the city to reimburse it for the time and expense of investigating each applicant for employment, and any other costs to the city necessitated by the permit process. 
(h)  Permit expiration. Permits issued under this section shall be active for a period of one (1) year. At the expiration of one (1) year from the date of the issuance of the permit, it shall be the duty of the employee to renew the permit by going through the process described in this section. In addition, employees who cease employment with the adult entertainment establishment with which they were employed when their permit was obtained for a period of six (6) months or more must also renew their permit before returning to adult entertainment in the city. Permitted employees whose information supplied to the city during the permitting process changes must inform the city of any such changes, otherwise, their permit is invalid. Employees who are convicted of an offense that may affect their good moral character under this chapter are under a duty to fully inform the city of any such conviction, and to supply sufficient documentation relating to the conviction to allow the city to fully investigate it. The failure to inform the city and/or provide documentation of any such conviction invalidates of an employee's permit. It shall also be the duty of the adult entertainment license holder to file with the city marshal's office, on a monthly basis, a report which lists all employees currently employed in a capacity that would require an employee permit. Each such report shall include the name and date of birth of all such individuals, as well as the same information on all such individuals who have terminated employment during the one-month employment period. Failure to submit said report to the city marshal's office by the twentieth day each month shall constitute a violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-11. - Application for license. 
(a)  Any person, association, partnership, corporation or limited liability company, or any other entity desiring to obtain a license to engage in adult entertainment, or to operate, promote, or conduct any adult entertainment establishment shall make application to the city marshal, or his designated representative. Prior to submitting such application, a nonrefundable fee, established by resolution of the city council shall be paid to the director of the business license department in an amount designed to defray, at least in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this chapter. The director of the business license department shall issue a receipt showing that such application fee has been paid. The receipt, or a copy thereof, shall be supplied to the city marshal at the time such application is submitted. 
(b)  The filing of an application for license does not, by itself, authorize the engaging in, operation of, conduct of, or carrying on of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-12. - Application contents. 
Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's full true name, Social Security Number, date of birth, place of birth, aliases, race, sex, and nationality. 
(2)  The present address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(3)  Acceptable written proof that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(4)  Business, occupation or employment history of the applicant for the five (5) years immediately preceding the date of application. Business or employment records of the applicant, partners in a partnership, or directors and officers of a corporation must be included, depending upon the type of applicant. 
(5)  The business license history of the applicant and where such application, in previous operations in this or any other city, state, or territory under license has had such license or permit for an adult entertainment business or similar type of business revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and a description of any business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation. 
(6)  If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the place and date of incorporation, and the names and addresses of each of its current officers and directors. If the applicant is a partnership, the applicant shall set forth the name, residence address, and dates of birth of the partners. If the applicant is a limited partnership, it shall furnish a copy of its certificate of limited partnership filed with the county clerk. If one (1) or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply. The applicant corporation or partnership shall designate one (1) of its officers or general partners to act as its responsible managing officer. Such designated persons shall complete and sign all application forms required of an individual applicant under this chapter, but only one (1) application fee shall be charged. 
(7)  If the applicant, any partners, or any corporate officers or directors (if the applicant is a corporation), have been convicted of any crime impacting their good moral character in the past five (5) years and if so, a complete description of any such crime, including date of violation, date of conviction, jurisdiction, and any disposition, including any fine or sentence imposed and whether terms of disposition have been fully completed. 
(8)  If the applicant is a person doing business under a trade name, a copy of the trade name properly recorded. If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of authority to do business in the state, including articles of incorporation, trade name affidavit, if any, and last annual report, if any. 
(9)  At least three (3) character references from individuals who are in no way related to the applicant or individual shareholders, officers or directors of a corporation and who are not or will not benefit financially in any way from the application if the license is granted and who have not been convicted of any crime involving moral character. The licensing officer shall prepare forms consistent with the provisions of this subsection for the applicant who shall submit all character references on such forms. 
(10)  Address of the premises to be licensed. 
(11)  Whether the premises are owned or rented. 
(12)  A plat by registered surveyor, licensed by the state, showing that the location of the proposed premises is consistent with the provisions obtained in section 6-10-9 hereof. 
(13)  Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: 
a.  If the applicant is an individual, the individual; 
b.  If the applicant is a partnership, by the manager or general partner; 
c.  If the applicant is a corporation, by the president of the corporation; 
d.  If the applicant is a limited liability company, by its manager or a member; 
e.  If any other organization or association, by the chief administrative official. 
(14)  In addition to the information required herein, the application shall disclose the name, address, social security number and date of birth of any and all persons who have a financial interest of any type in the entity which is applying for the license. 
(15)  A financial statement of the applicant shall be furnished as a part of the application for adult entertainment license on forms provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-13. - Applicant to appear. 
The applicant, if an individual, or designated responsible managing officer, if a partnership or corporation, shall personally appear at the city and produce proof that a nonrefundable application fee, established by resolution of the city council, has been paid and shall present the application containing the aforementioned and described information. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-14. - Application; investigation. 
The city shall have forty-five (45) days to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Upon completion of the investigation, the city marshal will grant the license within five (5) days of his or her completion of the investigation if the city marshal or his or her designated representative finds all of the following: 
(1)  The required license application fee has been paid; 
(2)  The application contains all of the information required by section 6-10-12; 
(3)  The applicant has not made a material misrepresentation in the application; 
(4)  The applicant (if an individual), or any officers or directors (if the applicant is a corporation), or any of the partners, including limited partners (if the applicant is a partnership), or any member(s) or manager(s) (if the applicant is a limited liability company) has not been convicted (as defined herein) in a court of competent jurisdiction of a sex-related crime, a drug-related or alcohol-related felony, or a crime of moral turpitude, or convicted of an attempt to commit any of the above-mentioned offenses, or convicted in any state of any offense which if committed or attempted in this state, would have been punishable as one (1) or more of the above-mentioned offenses within the past five (5) years; 
(5)  The applicant has not had an adult entertainment establishment license or other similar license or permit denied or revoked for cause in this city or any other local government jurisdiction located in or out of this state prior to the date of the application; 
(6)  The building, structure, equipment, and location of the premises of the adult entertainment establishment, as proposed by applicant, would comply with all applicable health, fire, safety, zoning, and distance laws, including section 6-10-9, and would qualify to receive a certificate of occupancy; 
(7)  The applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age; 
(8)  On the date the business for which a license is required herein commences, and thereafter, the applicant has represented that there will be a responsible person on the premises to act as manager at all times during which the business is open; 
(9)  The grant of such license will not cause a violation of this chapter or any other ordinance or regulation of the city, state or the United States; 
(10)  The applicant has given assurances that the licensee shall maintain at all times a written listing at the licensed premises of the name, address and phone number of the manager or assistant manager in charge of the licensed premises and that there shall at all times be a manager in charge and on the premises during operation hours; 
(11)  The applicant has appeared before city council at all hearings or meetings on the issue of the grant or denial of the requested license as required by section 6-10-13; 
(12)  The city has not found evidence that any specified sexual activity has occurred in or upon the premises where such adult entertainment establishment is to be located, and the city has not found evidence that any solicitation for specified sexual activities has occurred on said premises in the past. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-15. - Persons prohibited as licensee. 
No license provided for by this chapter shall be issued to or held by: 
(1)  An applicant who has not paid all required fees, property taxes, and other taxes for a business at that location; 
(2)  Any person who is not of good moral character; 
(3)  Any corporation, any of whose directors are not of good moral character; 
(4)  Any partnership or association, any of whose partners or members is not of good moral character; 
(5)  Any limited liability company, any of whose members or managers is not of good moral character; 
(6)  Any applicant who is not qualified to hold and conduct business according to the laws of the United States, the state or the city; 
(7)  Any applicant who fails to meet all of the criteria specified in section 6-10-14. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-16. - License renewal. 
Licenses for adult entertainment establishments may be renewed on a calendar year basis provided that the licensees continue to meet the requirements set out in this chapter. The renewal fee for adult entertainment establishment licenses shall be established by resolution of the city council. Renewal applications shall be submitted by November 15 of each year prior to January 1 of the year for which such license is requested. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-17. - Licenses nontransferable. 
No adult entertainment establishment license may be sold, transferred, or assigned by a licensee, or by operation of law, to any other person(s) or entity. Any such sale, transfer, or assignment, or attempted sale, transfer, or assignment shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of such license and such license shall thereafter be null and void; provided and excepting, however, that if the licensee is a partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or other similar entity and one (1) or more of the partners, shareholders, or members should die, one (1) or more of the surviving partners, shareholders, or members may acquire, by purchase or otherwise, the interest of the deceased partner(s), shareholder(s), or member(s) without effecting a surrender of termination of such license; and in such case the license, upon notification to the city, shall be placed in the name of the surviving partner, shareholder, or member. An adult entertainment establishment license issued to a corporation shall be deemed terminated and void when either any outstanding stock of the corporation is sold, transferred, or assigned after the issuance of a license or any stock authorized but not issued at the time of the granting of a license is thereafter issued and sold, transferred, or assigned. An adult entertainment establishment license issued to a partnership or limited liability company or other similar entity shall be deemed terminated and void if any interest in the partnership or limited liability company is sold, transferred, or assigned to a person or entity that was not a partner or member when the license was issued. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-18. - Change of name. 
(a)  No licensee shall advertise, operate, conduct, manage, engage in, or carry on an adult entertainment establishment under any name other than his own name and/or the name of the business as specified on his license. 
(b)  Any application for an extension or expansion of a building or other place of business where an adult entertainment establishment is located shall require inspection and shall comply with the provisions and regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-19. - License; refusal; appeal. 
If the city following investigation of the applicant, deems that the applicant does not fulfill the requirements as set forth in this chapter, it shall notify the city clerk of such opinion and, within forty-five (45) days of the date of application, provide copies of the investigation report to the city clerk. The city clerk shall within three (3) days, notify applicant by certified mail of such denial. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-20. - Appeal procedure. 
(a)  Any applicant who is denied a license may appeal such denial by filing a notice of appeal with the city marshal within ten (10) days of the date on which he is notified of the denial. The notice of appeal shall specify the subject matter of the appeal, the date of any original and amended application or requests, the date of the adverse decision (or receipt of notice thereof) the grounds or basis for the appeal, the action requested, the name and address of the applicant, and the reasons why the license should be granted. 
The city marshal shall schedule a hearing before the administrative hearing officer at a time and place not more than forty-five (45) days after receiving the notice of appeal. At the hearing, the applicant shall have the opportunity to present argument and evidence as to why his application should not be denied. The city marshal shall also be given the opportunity to present argument and evidence as to why the application should be denied. The administrative hearing officer shall not be bound by the traditional rules of evidence in the hearing, but the rules governing evidence in administrative hearings shall apply. Both parties shall be afforded the opportunity to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses. The administrative hearing officer shall have the power to rule on the admissibility of evidence, hear testimony under oath, and consider documents and other tangible evidence presented. The administrative hearing officer shall either approve or deny the license application in writing, shall issue findings of fact with the reasons supporting his decision, and shall issue the findings of fact and the decision within fifteen (15) days of the conclusion of the hearing. The decision of the hearing officer shall be mailed or delivered to the applicant. If the hearing is not held within forty-five (45) days as provided herein, or the decision is not rendered within fifteen (15) days of the conclusion of the hearing as provided herein, then the applicant's license application shall be deemed granted, unless the parties agree to a continuance, or the administrative hearing officer requests a continuance for good cause shown. 
(b)  The applicant or the city shall have the right to appeal the decision of the administrative hearing officer to the Superior Court of Hall County, Georgia, via certiorari as provided by Georgia law. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-21. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. In addition to such fine or imprisonment, violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of the license issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-22. - Unlawful operation declared nuisance. 
Any adult entertainment establishment operated, conducted, or maintained contrary to the provisions of this chapter shall be and the same is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. The city may, in addition to, or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action hereunder, commence an action or actions, proceeding or proceedings for abatement, removal, or enjoinment thereof, in the manner provided by law. It shall take such other steps and shall apply to such court or courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or remove such adult entertainment establishment and restrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting, or maintaining an adult entertainment establishment contrary to the provisions of this chapter. In addition, violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be, per se, grounds for suspension or revocation of a license granted hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-23. - Revocation and appeal. 
(a)  The city marshal shall be authorized to suspend or revoke a license previously granted herein. In the event the city marshal seeks to suspend or to revoke a license, the city marshal shall give written notification to the licensee of such action and such notice shall contain a specification of the violation or violations and/or the reasons for the suspension or revocation. 
(b)  The city marshal shall be authorized to suspend or revoke a license in the event of any one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  A licensee gave false or misleading information in the original application process; 
(2)  A licensee has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances on the premises and/or knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances to a minor on the premises; 
(3)  A licensee has knowingly allowed the violation of an ordinance of the city or a violation of any criminal law of the state to occur on the premises; 
(4)  A licensee has violated any provisions of this adult entertainment chapter; 
(5)  A licensee has been convicted of any drug-related or alcohol-related felony, any sex-related crime or any crime of moral turpitude, or any attempt to commit one (1) or more of such criminal acts; or 
(6)  A licensee fails to pay any fee, license fee, fine, or other amount of money due to the city under this chapter or any other licensing ordinance of the city. 
(c)  In the event the city marshal shall suspend any license hereunder, the suspension shall be for a period of not less than one (1) day nor more than five (5) years, within the discretion of the city marshal, provided, however, that the licensee shall be authorized to continue its business operations until the date of the hearing scheduled in accordance with subsection (d) hereafter. No licensee or other applicant may apply for a license for the same operation or premises during any period of suspension or revocation. 
(d)  In the event of a suspension or revocation by the city marshal, the licensee may appeal the decision of the city marshal using the same procedure designated in section 6-10-20 above. In the event the licensee does not file an appeal from the decision of the city marshal as provided in section 6-10-20, the decision of the city marshal shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-24. - License and annual renewal fees. 
There is hereby established a nonrefundable fee of three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00) to be submitted with any and every application to operate an adult entertainment establishment pursuant to the ordinance providing for the issuance of such permit. The annual renewal fee for any such license shall be three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00). 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-22, § I, adopted Oct. 7, 2014, repealed § 6-10-25 in its entirety. Former § 6-10-25 pertained to advertising and posting and derived from Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, adopted Sept. 21, 2010. 
Sec. 6-10-26 - Premises open for inspection. 
The premises of any adult entertainment establishment shall be open at reasonable times for inspection by the city to ensure compliance with this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-27. - Compliance. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of this Code, any adult entertainment establishment in existence on November 3, 1992, and which is in compliance with all of the terms, requirements and standards hereof, except for section 6-10-9, shall be a nonconforming use (section 9-1-8) and shall have the right to continue to operate in its present location so long as such adult entertainment establishment is in compliance with all of the terms, requirements, and standards hereof, except for section 6-10-9. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-28. - Alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  No person, association, partnership or corporation licensed under chapter 6-10 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Gainesville, Georgia, after the effective date of this chapter shall serve, sell, distribute, or suffer the consumption or possession of any intoxicating liquor, beer or wine or controlled substances upon the premises of any licensee. Any licensee whose license was granted prior to the effective date of this chapter shall not be subject to the restrictions in this amendment relating to alcoholic beverages, however, any licensee that is required to obtain a new license under the requirements of section 6-10-17 shall thereby lose its exemption from the alcoholic beverages prohibitions in this subsection. 
(b)  This section 6-10-28 shall not apply to nor prohibit the live performance of legitimate plays, operas, ballets at main stream theaters, concert halls, museums or educational institutions, which derive less than twenty (20) percent of their gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-29. - Booths and viewing areas 
All adult entertainment establishments which are otherwise permitted to have booths, rooms, cubicles or enclosed spaces, including all adult bookstores, adult mini-motion picture theaters, adult motion picture arcades, adult motion picture theaters, and adult video stores shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Access. Each booth, room, or cubicle shall be totally accessible to and from aisles and public areas of the establishment, and shall be unobstructed by any curtain, door, lock, or other control-type device or any view-obstructing devices or materials. 
(2)  Construction. Every booth, room, or cubicle shall meet the following construction requirements: 
a.  Each booth, room, or cubicle shall be separated from adjacent booths, rooms, and cubicles and any non public areas by a wall. 
b.  Have at least one (1) side totally open to a public lighted area or aisle so that there is an unobstructed view of anyone occupying the booth from the area in which the cash register for the adult entertainment establishment is located. 
c.  All walls shall be solid and without openings, extended from the floor to a height of not less than six (6) feet and be light colored, nonabsorbent, smooth-textured, and easily cleanable. 
d.  The floor must be light colored, nonabsorbent, smooth-textured, and easily cleaned. 
e.  The lighting level of each booth, room, or cubicle when not in use shall be a minimum of ten (10) foot candles at all times, as measured from the floor. 
(3)  Occupants. Only one (1) individual shall occupy a booth, room, or cubicle at any time. No occupant of any booth, room, or cubicle shall engage in any type of sexual activity, or cause any bodily discharge while therein. No individual shall damage or deface any portion of the booth, room, or cubicle. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
Sec. 6-10-30. - Private dancing or modeling sessions prohibited. 
No adult entertainment establishment shall allow, and no dancer or model thereof shall engage in, private dancing or modeling sessions or other activities involving sexual displays in which one (1) dancer or model is placed in a one-on-one situation with one (1) customer, and a regular show area with open seating shall be required for such sessions or displays; neither shall any adult entertainment establishment or any dancer, model, or employee thereof allow personal physical contact between customers and models, dancers, or employees. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § I, 9-21-10) 
CHAPTER 6-11. - SECURITY ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 6-11-1. - Declaration of findings and policy. 
It is hereby declared that excessive alarm calls within the corporate city limits of Gainesville, Georgia result in an inefficient use of emergency services resources, reduces faith in security alarm signals, and promotes complacency in police and fire investigation of alarm signals which creates a general public safety hazard detrimental to the protection and to the health, safety and welfare of citizens, and the emergency services personnel responsible for the investigation of alarm signals. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-2. - Administration and enforcement. 
The police department shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-3. - Operation and maintenance; transmission. 
The city shall operate and maintain equipment in the city public safety building designed to receive burglar and/or fire alarms over customer leased telephone lines. The city's obligation with respect to maintenance shall be construed to apply only to the equipment installed by the city and housed in the city public safety building. Alarm companies, alarm users or individuals transmitting alarms over leased lines to the police or fire departments are responsible for keeping their equipment in good working order and repair and the city shall have no obligation with respect thereto. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-4. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings given: 
Alarm company means any corporation, partnership, business or individual (operated for profit) engaged in the business or the installation, maintenance, alteration, servicing, or monitoring of an alarm system or which responds to such alarm systems. 
Alarm response means any response to a premise by the police or fire department as a result of an alarm signal. Should the police or fire department discover evidence of an occurrence that the alarm signal was designated to detect, that errant should be considered an alarm response for the purpose of this chapter. 
Alarm signal means the activation of an alarm system resulting in a request for an alarm response regardless of cause. 
Alarm system means any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, designed to signal an occurrence of robbery, burglary, unauthorized entry, attempted entry, fire, smoke, heat or water application, or any other circumstance requiring urgent attention and to which police or fire personnel are expected to respond. 
Alarm user means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind who or which purchases, leases, contracts for, or otherwise obtains an alarm system, or the servicing, maintenance or monitoring of an alarm system from an alarm company. 
Automatic dialing device means a device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to a predetermined telephone number and which automatically transmits by recorded voice message or signal the existence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police or firefighters are expected to respond. 
City means the City of Gainesville, Georgia. 
False alarms means any signal [of] an occurrence of robbery, unauthorized entry, heat, smoke or water application, or any other circumstance when there exists no actual or threatened criminal activity or emergency to which police or fire department personnel are expected to respond. 
Fire department means the City of Gainesville, Georgia Fire Department. 
Person means any individual, group of persons, firm, partnership, association of any kind, company or corporation. 
Police department means the City of Gainesville, Georgia Police Department. 
Protected premise means the premises upon which an alarm system has been placed for the purpose of detecting a hazard. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-5. - Intentional false alarms prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and willfully activate a security alarm system to summon police or firefighters when there is no actual or threatened emergency or criminal activity. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-6. - Automatic dialing device restrictions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to install, operate or maintain any automated dialing device which is programmed to transmit a prerecorded message or code signal directly to the city public safety building by public telephone lines. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-7. - Required equipment. 
(a)  An alarm system operated within the corporate city limits of the city shall be equipped in such a manner so as to prevent false alarms due to interruptions in electrical power. 
(b)  Any alarm system within the corporate limits of the city which is equipped with a horn, bell, siren or other noise device audible beyond the confines of the premise shall be adjusted in such a manner that it will not sound for longer than fifteen (15) minutes before resetting and silencing itself. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-8. - Notification of alarm system emergency information. 
(a)  Within ten (10) days of installing an alarm system, the alarm user shall furnish the police department all emergency information concerning the protected premises, the alarm user, and the alarm company. 
(b)  If, at any time, there is a change in the status of the protected premises which renders any part of the emergency information inaccurate, the alarm user shall supply the police department supplemental emergency information within ten (10) days of the change. 
(c)  Alarm users with alarm systems installed prior to March 1, 1994 shall comply with this section prior to October 1, 1994. 
(d)  Any alarm response which results from an alarm signal initiated by an alarm system which is not in compliance with this section shall be deemed to be an excessive alarm response and a violation of section 6-11-9 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-9. - Excessive alarm responses prohibited. 
(a)  On and after thirty (30) days from the installation date of an alarm system, it shall be unlawful for any alarm user in the city to allow an excessive number of alarm responses to occur at a protected premise for which the alarm user is responsible. 
(b)  Alarm responses to a protected premise in excess of five (5) in any consecutive twelve-month period, or three (3) in any consecutive four-month period, or three (3) in any one (1) month are deemed to be an excessive number and shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  If an alarm user shows to the satisfaction of the chief of police and/or fire department or his designee that the false alarm was not the result of the negligence or improper maintenance by the alarm user, the administrative service fee sanction may be waived. 
(d)  Police and fire department personnel assigned to incidents which are determined to be an alarm response shall, whenever possible, leave written notice for the alarm user which provides the following information: 
Date and time of alarm response. 
Officer/firefighter's name and business telephone number. 
Brief synopsis of the alarm ordinance. 
Such notice shall not be left on the exterior of the protected premises, nor in such a position so as to be read by an individual on the exterior of the protected premise. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-10. - Inspection of alarm systems. 
An alarm user in violation of section 6-11-9 shall cause their alarm system to be inspected by an alarm company licensed to conduct business in the city. The inspection shall entail a complete examination of the alarm system including, but not limited to, satisfactory design and installation of the equipment, proper functioning of the equipment and user education in the operation of the equipment. The alarm company shall record the details of the inspection and make such record available to the alarm user. Notification of the requirements of this section shall be made by the police department in writing, within thirty (30) days of the violation, to the registered alarm user. The completed inspection report shall be returned to the police department by the alarm user within thirty (30) days of the initial notification by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-11. - Penalties for noncompliance with inspection. 
If the police department does not receive the completed inspection report within thirty (30) days of the notification as provided in section 6-11-10, an administrative service fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be assessed against the alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-12. - Penalties for subsequent violations. 
(a)  If within twelve (12) months of the notification, as provided in section 6-11-10, there are more than two (2) alarm responses to a protected premise, administrative service fees, in accordance with the following fee schedule shall be assessed against the user for all subsequent alarm responses: 
(Proposed Administrative Service Fee Schedule) 
(1)  Third response ..... $ 20.00 
(2)  Fourth response ..... 50.00 
(3)  Fifth response ..... 75.00 
(4)  Sixth response ..... 100.00 
(5)  Seventh response ..... 125.00 
(6)  Responses in excess of seven, each ..... 150.00 
(b)  To ensure that the assessed amounts are representative of costs incurred by the city to provide alarm responses and to administer this chapter, the amounts contained in the administrative service fee schedule shall be evaluated and amended, as necessary, on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-13. - Application. 
Alarm companies desiring to have an alarm system connection to the city public safety building via an alarm board shall file an application with the police department. Written notice of the police department decision shall be mailed to the applicant at the address given on the application within thirty (30) days of the date of such application. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-14. - Initial permit forms and instructions to alarm users. 
Every alarm company selling, leasing or furnishing to any alarm user an alarm system which is installed on any premises located in the city shall furnish to the police department the user's initial permit forms in a completed form within ten (10) days of installing an alarm system. The alarm company shall also furnish the alarm user with instructions that provide information to allow the alarm user to operate the alarm system properly and to obtain service for the alarm system at any time. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-15. - Connection and termination requirements. 
All approvals by the police department for connection of alarm systems shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Applicant shall use only alarm equipment which meets minimum alarm device standards of Underwriters Laboratories and the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) and which is compatible with the city public safety building alarm equipment. 
(2)  All installation costs associated with connection to the city public safety building alarm system shall be borne by the applicant. 
(3)  All costs associated with disconnection or termination of service shall be borne by the applicant, whether such disconnection or termination is required by the police department or by choice of the owner. Such costs include the costs of termination and reconnection in the event the city public safety building alarm system is relocated. 
(4)  The police and fire department reserve the right to inspect any applicant's equipment at any time for any reason related to the efficient operation of the alarm system. Failure to allow inspection shall be cause for immediate removal. 
(5)  Applicant shall sign an agreement which holds the city, its agents and employees harmless for any and all damages or losses resulting directly or indirectly from an alarm system connection with the city public safety building alarm system. 
(6)  Council shall establish the fees for these services by resolution and shall be a part of the schedule of fees for the city. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-16. - Reporting requirement. 
All alarm companies located within the corporate limits of the city shall, within sixty (60) days from the effective date of the enactment of this chapter, provide to the police department, the name and last known address of all alarm users located within the corporate limits of the city from which the aforementioned businesses are currently collecting a monitoring fee. Any alarm company violation this section shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for each day the alarm company fails and/or refuses to report the information required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-17. - Review committee. 
The city council shall appoint a review committee consisting of a representative of the police department, a representative of the fire department, a representative of an alarm company licensed to conduct business in the city and a member of the public safety committee of the city council, which is empowered to hear the appeal upon request of any alarm company or alarm user adversely affected by any decision of the police department or fire department. The representative to an alarm company shall serve for a period of two (2) years. 
(1)  Appeals to the review committee shall be within three (3) days from the date of service of written notice of a decision adversely affecting an alarm user or alarm company. 
(2)  Failure to file an appeal within such three-day period shall constitute a waiver of the right to such appeal. 
(3)  The decision of the review committee shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 6-11-18. - Penalties. 
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, any person, alarm user or alarm company who violates any provision of this chapter or any rules, orders or regulations made pursuant to this chapter, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-1-7. 
(Ord. No. 94-06, § I, 2-15-94) 
CHAPTER 6-12. - SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS 

Sec. 6-12-1. - Registration required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a canvasser or solicitor, calling at residences without the previous consent of the occupant for the purpose of soliciting orders, sale, subscriptions, or business of any kind, or for seeking information or donations without first having registered in the office of the city marshal. Each registrant shall give their complete identification, their signature, the name of their employer, the nature of the products or services in which they are interested, the names of the manufacturers of such products, or of the organization which they are representing, and the proposed method of operation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 94-52, § I, 1-3-95) 
Sec. 6-12-2. - Fee. 
Each registrant shall pay a regulatory fee in the amount provided in Title 10 for persons engaged in business as a canvasser or solicitor. 
(Ord. No. 94-52, § I, 1-3-95) 
Sec. 6-12-3. - Certificate. 
(a)  Each applicant who shows evidence of good character and who pays the fee provided for in this chapter shall be furnished a certificate by the chief of police and the city marshal indicating that he or she has registered and showing the dates covered by such registration. 
(b)  Each person shall at all times while soliciting or canvassing in the city carry upon his or her person the registration certificate and the same shall be exhibited by such registrant whenever he or she is required to do so by any police officer or by any person solicited. 
(c)  No certificate shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of a felony within the past ten (10) years. 
(Ord. No. 94-52, § I, 1-3-95) 
Sec. 6-12-4. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to officers or employees of the city, county, state or federal government, or any subdivision thereof, when on official business. 
(Ord. No. 94-52, § I, 1-3-95) 
Sec. 6-12-5. - Revocation. 
Any such registration may be revoked by the mayor or the chief of police because of any violation by the registrant of this chapter or of any other ordinance of the city, or of any state or federal law, or whenever the registrant shall cease to possess the qualifications and character required in this chapter for the original registration. 
(Ord. No. 94-52, § I, 1-3-95) 
Sec. 6-12-6. - Grant or denial of certificate generally. 
The grant or denial of a certificate under this chapter shall be based on a consideration of the public welfare, peace, safety, health, good order and convenience. The person who grants such a certificate may suspend or revoke it, based on the same consideration. 
(Ord. No. 94-52, § I, 1-3-95) 
Sec. 6-12-7. - Due process. 
Any person who believes that he or she has been denied due process of law under this chapter shall be entitled to a hearing, pursuant to section 1-8-1. Unless such hearing is requested within five (5) working days after the alleged denial of due process, such person shall be presumed to have accepted summary process. 
(Ord. No. 94-52, § I, 1-3-95) 
CHAPTER 6-13. - SIDEWALK CAFES[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-19, § I, adopted Aug. 15, 2017, amended Ch. 6-13 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 6-13, §§ 6-13-1—6-13-6, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2010-29, § I, adopted Aug. 17, 2010; Ord. No. 2015-21, § I, adopted July 7, 2015. 

Sec. 6-13-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Sidewalk cafe means the location and use of tables and chairs and other associated equipment and furnishings on the public sidewalk or city-installed and/or approved parklet and operated as an extension of a licensed eating establishment or licensed alcoholic beverage premises.
