Public right-of-way shall mean the surface, the airspace above the surface and area below the surface of any street, highway, alley, avenue, boulevard, sidewalk, pedestrian/bicycle lane or trail, driveway, bridge, utility easement or any other public ways owned, dedicated by plat, occupied or used by the public and within grantor's geographical limits or boundaries established by applicable law. 
Telecommunications services means the receipt and/or distribution, through any means, including, without limitation, coaxial cable, optical fiber, or satellite or microwave transmission, of one (1) or more audio, voice or data signals. 
(Ord. No. 2012-36, § I, 12-27-12) 
Sec. 6-17-2. - Administration and regulations of the use of city rights-of-way. 
(a)  (1)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except a franchisee as provided in section 6-15-1 et seq. or one holding an access permit, to install, construct, move, or relocate pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, and other equipment, facilities or appliances upon, under, along, and over the right-of-way without the approval of the city manager or his/her designee. Such access permit shall be granted only for a specified portion of particular and the issuance of an access permit. 
(2)  Such access permit shall be granted only for a specified portion of particular right-of-way. 
(3)  Such access permits shall be granted only for a specified time period as deemed necessary by the city manager or his/her designee. 
(b)  Such approval shall be obtained from the municipality via an access permit. 
(1)  The access permit shall specify the name of the streets and/or right-of-way involved, the purpose for which the pipes, wire, cable or conduit is run, the type and length of pipe, wire, cable or conduit and any other utility infrastructure to be run, and the time allowed for performance of the work. 
(2)  The city manager or his/her designee shall review applications for conformance to the utility accommodations policy and standards of the Georgia Department of Transportation, as well as city standards and policies before issuing an access permit. An access permit holder does not grant a person exclusive right to use of the right-of-way. If the installation interferes with the safe use of the right-of-way or a street construction improvement, then the person shall remove, relocate or repair its facility to remove such interference, upon notification by the city manager or his/her designee at the permit holder's expense. 
(3)  All plan documents must be reviewed by the planning review committee. 
(4)  Once plans are approved, the community development department will issue the access permit. 
(Ord. No. 2012-36, § I, 12-27-12) 
Sec. 6-17-3. - Compensation by access permit grantee for use of the city's rights-of-way. 
(a)  The access permit grantee shall provide for due compensation to the city in an amount equal to the maximum amounts specified or allowed by applicable state or federal law, rule, or regulation. 
(b)  For purposes of computing due compensation relating to access permit obtained pursuant to the provisions of Title 10 of O.C.G.A. § 45-5-1 et seq., the term "retail end user customer" shall mean any person or owner provided with a telecommunications service or other services for its own consumption and not for resale in whole or in part. 
(c)  Any due compensation required pursuant to chapter [title] 10 of this Code shall be remitted to the city on a quarterly basis, which must be submitted within thirty (30) days of calendar quarter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-36, § I, 12-27-12) 
Sec. 6-17-4. - Liability of holder of an access permit. 
The holder of an access permit shall at all times be responsible to the public and hold the city harmless for any property damage or personal injury caused or occasioned by the installation, maintenance or occupancy of any wire, cable or conduit and any other utility infrastructure under, upon, along, and over the public roads and highways and right-of-way as permitted in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-36, § I, 12-27-12) 
Sec. 6-17-5. - Authority to require relocation. 
The city manager or his/her designee shall be authorized to require that any person holding an access permit shall relocate their pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, and other equipment, facilities, or appliances if such relocation is a public necessity as determined by the city manager or his/her designee. The city manager or his/her designee may also require an overhead wire, cable, fiber or other utilities system to be relocated underground if the street involved should convert from an overhead system to an underground system. 
(Ord. No. 2012-36, § I, 12-27-12) 
Sec. 6-17-6. - Insurance and bonding requirements. 
(a)  (1)  Any person seeking to obtain an access permit shall provide proof of general liability insurance or self-insurance with the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) to the finance department of the city. Such insurance shall cover all work done by such person upon, under, along and over the city right-of way and shall be maintained during all periods such work is being done. The city shall be named as an additional insured. Proof of the renewal certificate of the general liability insurance policy must be provided to the finance department of the city annually before the expiration date. 
(2)  The insurance policy shall contain the following endorsement: 
"This insurance policy may not be canceled, or allowed to lapse until thirty (30) days after receipt by the city, by certified mail, return receipt requested, of a written notice from the issuer of the insurance company of intent to cancel or not to renew." 
a.  If deemed necessary, the city may require any person seeking to obtain an access permit to provide a surety bond before issuance of the permit. Such bond shall cover all work done by such person upon, under, along, and over the city rights-of-way and shall be maintained during all periods such work is being done. 
b.  In situations where the city requires the person to provide a surety bond, the person shall deposit with the city a surety bond in an amount determined by the city to be sufficient to ensure satisfactory completion of the work from a surety company authorized to do business in Georgia and fulfillment of the warranty provided for herein and in a form approved by the city attorney. Said bond shall guarantee completion to the satisfaction of the city of all work required by this chapter and by the conditions of the permit within the time limits set by the permit. Said bond shall further guarantee that all work shall be free from defects in workmanship or materials for a period of two (2) years after the date said work is completed and accepted by the city. The bond shall be conditioned to protect and save harmless the city, the city council and all agents, servants, employees and city attorney from all claims and damages for cleaning or repairing any damage by the person and will be used to reimburse the city for any cost incurred to clean or repair city rights-of-way, to re-ditch or repair existing ditch structure or for other damage caused as a result of the actions of the person after the issuance of the right-of-way access permit. 
c.  In instances where the city has required a surety bond under paragraph (a) the person may opt to secure their permit by providing an irrevocable bank letter of credit attesting to solvency to the city in the amount determined by the city to ensure satisfactory completion of work. 
d.  Such surety bond or irrevocable letter of credit shall protect the city against any damage caused by such person tendering the surety bond or letter of credit, or any agent, employee or contractor or said person and will be used to reimburse the city for any cost incurred to clean or repair city rights-of-way, stormwater infrastructure, other utilities, landscaping, to re-ditch or repair existing ditch structure or for other damage caused as a result of the actions of the person after the issuance of the permit. The person responsible for operations under the permit will be given notice of the damage and allowed seventy-two (72) hours to restore the street to a safe and operable condition as determined by the city manager or his/her designee. All repairs, material used and final releasing condition shall be approved and accepted by the city manager or his/her designee. 
e.  The surety bond or letter of credit may be released by the city manager or his/her designee upon notification of completion by the person or firm obtaining the permit and only upon final inspection and approval of the sites and all affected rights-of-way. The surety bond or letter of credit may be retained against future or continuing operations by the person in the city. 
f.  A surety bond shall be issued by a surety acceptable to the city, and shall contain the following endorsement: 
"This bond may not be canceled, or allowed to lapse until thirty (30) days after receipt by the city, by certified mail, return receipt requested, of a written notice from the issuer of the bond of intent to cancel or not to renew." 
g.  The city may require verification of continuing coverage by the surety bond, as needed. 
(Ord. No. 2012-36, § I, 12-27-12) 
Sec. 6-17-7. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. In addition to such fine or imprisonment, violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of any permit issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2012-36, § I, 12-27-12) 
CHAPTER 6-18. - FRANCHISES FOR ELECTRIC SUPPLIER OR PROVIDER[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-03, § I, adopted February 19, 2008, amended chapter 6-18 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, chapter 6-18 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 2006-63, § 1, adopted December 19, 2006. 

Sec. 6-18-1. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this chapter, the term "distribution facilities" means poles, lines, wires, cables, conductors, insulators, transformers, appliances, equipment, connections, and other apparatus installed by or on behalf of an EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider in the streets, alleys, or public places of the city for the purpose of transmitting, conveying, conducting, using, supplying and distributing electricity for light, heat, power and other purposes for which electrical current may be or becomes useful or practicable for public or private use, within the present and future limits of the city. Distribution facilities do not include any of the following: 
(1)  Electric transmission lines with a design operating voltage of forty-six (46) kilovolts or greater (hereafter referred to as "transmission lines"); 
(2)  Poles, towers, frames, or other support structures for transmission lines (hereafter referred to as "transmission structures"); 
(3)  Transmission lines and related wires, cables, conductors, insulators, or other apparatus attached to transmission structures; 
(4)  Lines, wires, cables, or conductors installed in concrete-encased ductwork; or 
(5)  Network underground facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § I, 2-19-08) 
Sec. 6-18-2. - Grant of franchise to Jackson Electric Membership Corporation. 
Jackson Electric Membership Corporation, which is an electric membership corporation defined in O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1, et seq., its successors, lessees and assigns (the "EMC") or any other secondary electric supplier or provider, is hereby granted the authority, right, permission and consent, for a period of thirty-five (35) years, to occupy and use the streets, alleys and public places of the city within the present and future limits of the said city as from time to time the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider may deem proper or necessary for the overhead or underground construction, maintenance, operation and extension of poles, towers, lines, wires, cables, conduits, insulators, transformers, appliances, equipment, connections and other apparatus for the business and purpose of transmitting, conveying, conducting, using, supplying and distributing electricity for light, heat, power and other purposes for which electric current may be or become useful or practicable for public or private use, and to re-enter upon such streets, alleys and public places from time to time as the EMC or any secondary electric supplier or provider may deem proper or necessary to perform these functions, and to cut and trim trees and shrubbery when and where necessary, in the judgment of the EMC or other secondary electric supplier or provider, to ensure safe and efficient service. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § I, 2-19-08) 
Sec. 6-18-3. - Considerations, terms and conditions. 
The rights, permission and consents herein contained are made for the following considerations and upon the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider shall pay to the city on or before the first day of March, 2008 a sum of money equal to four (4) percent of the gross sales of electric energy to all of the residential, commercial and industrial customers of such EMC or such other secondary electric supplier or provider served within the corporate limits of the city during the period beginning on the date this chapter becomes effective, through and including December 31, 2007 and on or before the first day of March of each year thereafter during the term of the franchise herein granted a sum of money equal to four (4) percent of the gross sales of electric energy to all of the residential, commercial and industrial customers of such EMC or such other secondary electric supplier or provider served within the corporate limits of the city during the preceding year. 
(2)  The amount, if any, of any tax, fee, charge or imposition of any kind required, demanded or exacted by the city on any account, other than ad valorem taxes on property and license taxes on the sale of home appliances, shall operate to reduce to the extent of such tax, fee, charge or imposition the amount due from the percentage of gross sales as provided herein in subsection (1). 
(3)  The EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider shall fully protect, indemnify and save harmless the city from all damages to person or property caused by the construction, maintenance, operation or extension of poles, wires or other apparatus, or conditions of streets, alleys or public places resulting therefrom, for which the said city would otherwise be liable. 
(4)  The EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider shall, in constructing, maintaining, operating and extending its poles, wires and other apparatus, submit and be subject to all reasonable exercises of the police power by the city. Nothing contained herein, however, shall require the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider to surrender or limit its property rights created hereby without due process of law, including adequate compensation, for any other purpose at the instance of the city or for any other purpose at the instance of any other entity, private or governmental. 
(5)  The city, the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider benefit from economic development with the city. Accordingly, when it is necessary to relocate any of the EMC and any other secondary electric supplier or provider's facilities (whether distribution facilities, transmission lines, transmission structures, or other facilities) within the city, the city and the EMC and any other secondary electric supplier or provider shall work cooperatively to minimize costs, delays, and inconvenience to both parties while ensuring compliance with applicable laws and regulations. In addition, the city and the EMC and any other secondary electric supplier or provider shall communicate in a timely fashion to coordinate projects included in the city's five-year capital improvement plan, the city's short-term work program, or the city's annual budget in an effort to minimize relocation of the EMC and any other secondary electric supplier or provider's facilities. Such communication may include, but is not limited to: 
a.  Both parties' participation in the Georgia Utilities Coordinating Council, Inc. (or any successor organization) or a local utilities coordinating council (or any successor organization), and 
b.  Both parties' use of the National Joint Utility Notification System (or any successor to such system mutually acceptable to both parties). 
(6)  With regard to each streetscape project undertaken by or on behalf of the city, the city shall pay the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider in advance for the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider's estimated cost to relocate any of the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider's facilities (whether distribution facilities, transmission lines, transmission structures, or other facilities) in connection with such project. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § I, 2-19-08) 
Sec. 6-18-4. - Additional conditions. 
In addition to the terms and conditions set forth in this chapter, the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider's occupancy and use of the streets, alleys, and public places of the city as authorized in this chapter are subject to the following terms and conditions: 
In the event that the city reasonably believes that the EMC's or any other secondary electric supplier or provider's distribution facilities either (i) constitute an obstruction or interference with the use or safe operation of the city's streets, alleys, or public places, or (ii) will interfere with contemplated construction or maintenance of such streets, alleys or public places, then the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider shall relocate, at its expense, the distribution facilities affected by such project or improvement. The EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider's obligations under this paragraph shall not affect the amounts paid or to be paid to the city under the provisions of this chapter. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this paragraph, the EMC or any other secondary electric supplier or provider shall not be obligated to relocate, at its expense, any of the following: 
(1)  Distribution facilities that are located on private property at the time relocation is requested or demanded; 
(2)  Distribution facilities that are relocated in connection with sidewalk improvements (unless such sidewalk improvements are related to or associated with road widenings, the creation of new turn lanes, or the addition of acceleration/deceleration lanes); 
(3)  Streetscape projects or other projects undertaken primarily for aesthetic purposes; or 
(4)  Distribution facilities that are converted from an overhead configuration or installation to an underground configuration or installation. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § I, 2-19-08) 
CHAPTER 6-19. - LIBERTY ENERGY (GEORGIA) CORPORATION[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Editor's note— Inasmuch as the gas franchise has been assigned from Atmos Energy Corporation, Kentucky/Mid-State Division to Liberty Energy (Georgia) Corporation pursuant to Ord. No. 2013-01, § I, adopted March 5, 2013, the title of chapter 6-19 has been amended to read as herein set out at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 6-19-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this agreement, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
Commission refers to and is the Georgia Public Service Commission, the state utility regulatory commission having jurisdiction over the rates, services and operations of grantee within the state or other administrative or regulatory authority succeeding to the regulatory powers of the commission. 
Force majeure shall mean any and all causes beyond the control and without the fault or negligence of grantee. Such causes shall include but not be limited to acts of God, acts of the public enemy, insurrections, terrorism, riots, labor disputes, boycotts, labor and material shortages, fires, explosions, flood, breakdowns of or damage to equipment of facilities, interruptions to transportation, embargoes, acts of military authorities, or other causes of a similar nature whether or not foreseen or foreseeable which wholly or partly prevent grantee from performing one or more of its obligations hereunder. 
Franchise shall mean the rights and privileges granted by grantor to grantee under the terms and provisions of this franchise. 
Grantee shall mean Liberty Energy (Georgia) Corporation. 
Grantor shall mean Gainesville, Georgia. 
Public right-of-way shall mean the surface, the airspace above the surface and area below the surface of any street, highway, alley, avenue, boulevard, sidewalk, pedestrian/bicycle lane or trail, driveway, bridge, utility easement or any other public ways owned, dedicated by plat, occupied or used by the public and within grantor's geographical limits or boundaries established by applicable law. 
Revenues refer to and are those amounts of money which grantee receives from its customers within grantor's geographical limits or boundaries for the retail sale of gas under rates, temporary or permanent, authorized by the commission and represents amounts billed under such rates. "Revenues" shall include adjustments for refunds, net write-offs of uncollectible accounts, corrections or other regulatory adjustments. "Revenues" do not include miscellaneous service charges, including but not limited to turn ons, meter sets, non sufficient funds, late fees and interest, which are related to but are not a part of the actual retail sale of gas. 
System shall mean the system of works, pipes, pipelines, facilities, fixtures, apparatus, lines, machinery, equipment, structures, appliances, appurtenances or other infrastructure reasonably necessary for the storage, transportation, distribution or sale of natural, artificial or mixed gas to residential, commercial and industrial customers and the public generally, within the geographical limits or boundaries of grantor. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09; Ord. No. 2013-01, § I, 3-5-13) 
Editor's note— Inasmuch as the gas franchise has been assigned from Atmos Energy Corporation, Kentucky/Mid-State Division to Liberty Energy (Georgia) Corporation pursuant to Ord. No. 2013-01, § I, adopted March 5, 2013, the definition of "grantee" has been amended to read as herein set out at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 6-19-2. - Grant of franchise. 
(a)  There is hereby created and granted unto grantee a non-exclusive franchise to enter upon, acquire, construct, operate, maintain and repair in the public right-of-way the system, subject to the provisions of this agreement. The franchise granted hereunder shall be extended to territories that are annexed by grantor upon the same terms and conditions herein, subject to the approval of the commission, if any such approval is required. 
(b)  The franchise granted to grantee by grantor shall not be exclusive and grantor reserves the right to grant a similar franchise to any other person or entity at any time. In the event grantor shall grant to another person or entity during the term hereof a franchise for a gas distribution system within the geographical boundaries or limits of grantor similar to the one herein granted to grantee, it is agreed that the terms of any such franchise agreement shall be no more favorable to such new additional grantee than those terms contained herein. Additionally, it is agreed that any such new/additional grantee shall have no right to use any portion of the system without grantee's written consent. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-3. - Term, effective date, and acceptance of franchise. 
(a)  The term of this franchise shall be for an initial term of fifteen (15) years from and after its passage and approval; provided, this franchise and all rights and privileges herein provided shall be extended for one (1) successive period of five (5) years unless grantor by notice given to grantee by ordinance duly enacted and approved at least six (6) months before the end of such initial term shall declare such termination effective. 
(b)  The franchise created hereby shall become effective upon its final passage and approval by grantor, in accordance with applicable laws and regulations, and upon acceptance by grantee by written instrument within sixty (60) days of passage by the governing body, and filed with the clerk of the grantor. If grantee does not, within sixty (60) days following passage of this chapter, express in writing its objections to any terms or provisions contained therein, or reject this chapter in its entirety, grantee shall be deemed to have accepted this chapter and all of its terms and conditions. 
(c)  The terms and conditions of Ordinance 79-5 are superseded by the terms and conditions hereof. 
(d)  On the expiration of this franchise, in the event the same is not renewed, or on the termination of any renewal of said franchise, or on termination of said franchise for any other reason, the plant and facilities of grantee installed, constructed and operated hereunder may, at the option of the city become the property of the city, upon payment to grantee, its successors and/or assigns, of a fair valuation thereof, such fair valuation to be determined by agreement between the city and grantee, its successors and/or assigns. Grantor agrees that, at the time of such transfer of facilities, it shall assume grantee's contractual and regulatory obligations maintained in connection with the system. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-4. - Grantee's rights in and to public right-of-way. 
Grantee shall have the right and privilege of constructing, erecting, laying, operating, maintaining, replacing, removing and/or repairing a gas distribution system through, along, across and under the public right-of-way within the geographical boundaries or limits of grantor as it now exists or may hereafter be constructed or extended, subject to the inherent police powers conferred upon or reserved unto grantor and the provisions of this agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-5. - Operation of system; excavation of public right-of-way. 
(a)  The system shall at all times be installed, operated and maintained in good working condition as will enable grantee to furnish adequate and continuous service to all of its residential, commercial and industrial customers. The system shall be designed, installed, constructed and replaced in locations and at depths which comply with all applicable federal and state laws and regulations regarding minimum safety standards for design, construction, maintenance and operation of gas distribution systems. 
(b)  Grantee shall have the right to disturb, break, and excavate in the public right-of-way as may be reasonable and necessary to provide the service authorized hereby. 
(c)  Grantee will repair any damage caused solely by grantee to any part of the public right-of-way and will restore, as nearly as practicable, such property to substantially its condition immediately prior to such damage, within a reasonable time, and shall not unnecessarily obstruct or impede traffic upon the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Grantee shall use reasonable care in conducting its work and activities in order to prevent injury to any person and unnecessary damage to any real or personal property. 
(e)  Grantee shall, when reasonably practicable, install all pipelines underground at such depth and in such manner so as not to interfere with the existing pavement, curbs, gutters, underground wires or cables or water or sewer pipes owned or controlled by grantor. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-6. - Degradation/restoration of public right-of-way. 
(a)  In the event that grantor or any other entity acting on behalf of grantor requests or demands that grantee remove, move, modify, relocate, reconstruct or adjust any part of the system from their then-current locations within the streets, alleys, and public places of grantor in connection with a public project or improvement, then grantee shall relocate, at its expense, the system facilities affected by such project or improvement. Grantee's obligations under this paragraph shall apply without regard to whether grantee has acquired, or claims to have acquired, an easement or other property right with respect to such system facilities and shall not affect the amounts paid or to be paid to grantor under the provisions of this chapter. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this paragraph, grantee shall not be obligated to relocate, at its expense, any of the following: 
(1)  System facilities that are located on private property at the time relocation is requested or demanded; 
(2)  System facilities that are relocated in connection with sidewalk improvements (unless such sidewalk improvements are related to or associated with road widening projects, the creation of new turn lanes, or the addition of acceleration/deceleration lanes); 
(3)  Streetscape projects or other projects undertaken primarily for aesthetic purposes; or 
(4)  System facilities that are converted from an overhead configuration or installation to an underground configuration or installation. 
(b)  Grantor and grantee recognize that both parties benefit from economic development within the boundaries of grantor. Accordingly, when it is necessary to relocate any of grantee's facilities within the boundaries of grantor, grantor and grantee shall work cooperatively to minimize costs, delays, and inconvenience to both parties while ensuring compliance with applicable laws and regulations. In addition, grantor and grantee shall communicate in a timely fashion to coordinate projects included in grantor's five-year capital improvement plan, grantor's short-term work program, or grantor's annual budget in an effort to minimize relocation of grantee's facilities. Such communication may include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Both parties' participation in the Georgia Utilities Coordinating Council, Inc. (or any successor organization) or local utilities coordinating council (or any successor organization), and 
(2)  Both parties' use of the national joint utility notification system (or any successor to such system mutually acceptable to both parties). 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-7. - Compensation for use of public right-of-way and consideration for franchise. 
(a)  In consideration for the granting and exercise of the rights and privileges created hereunder, and in further consideration of the grant to the franchisee of the right to make use of public right-of-way, grantee shall pay to grantor, during the entire life of the franchise, a sum equal to five (5) percent of its revenues. The fee prescribed herein shall be paid to grantor quarterly on or before the 30th day after the end of each calendar quarter after the effective date hereof, and grantee shall furnish to grantor quarterly a statement of grantee's revenues. 
(b)  Grantee may add a line-item surcharge to the monthly bills of each of its customers located within the geographical boundaries or limits of grantor, which surcharge may be designated as a franchise fee, in an amount that is sufficient to recover the portion of the franchise fee paid by grantee to grantor that is attributable to the revenue derived by grantee from such customer. 
(c)  The franchise fee provided herein, together with any charges of grantor for water, sewage and garbage services provided by grantor to grantee, and any applicable occupational license fees or sales, ad valorem or other taxes payable to grantor by grantee under applicable law, shall constitute the only amounts for which grantee shall be obligated to pay to grantor and shall be in lieu of any and all other costs, levies, assessments, fees or other amounts, of any kind whatsoever, that grantor, currently or in the future, may charge grantee or assess against grantee's property. The franchise fee herein contemplated shall be uniformly and equally applied to all natural gas utilities, of like services or any other natural gas service that competes with grantee, such that grantee will be excused from collecting and paying franchise fees and/or taxes if grantee's competitors are not also required to do so. 
(d)  Grantee as the holder of the franchise privilege hereunder is responsible for the payment of all franchise fees payable hereunder. Grantor through its authorized representative or representatives shall have the right to inspect and audit the books and records of grantee for the purpose of determining the amount of its revenues received from the sale of natural gas within grantor's boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-8. - Service to new areas. 
If during the term of this franchise the boundaries of grantor are expanded, grantor will promptly notify grantee in writing of any geographic areas annexed by grantor during the term hereof ("annexation notice"). Any such annexation notice shall be sent to grantee by certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall contain the effective date of the annexation, maps showing the annexed area and such other information as grantee may reasonably require in ascertaining whether there exist any customers of grantee receiving natural gas service in said annexed area. To the extent there are such customers therein, then the revenue of grantee derived from the retail sale of natural gas to such customers shall become subject to the franchise fee provisions hereof effective on the first day of grantee's billing cycle immediately following grantee's receipt of the annexation notice. The failure by grantor to advise grantee in writing through proper annexation notice of any geographic areas which are annexed by grantor shall not relieve grantee from any obligation to remit any franchise fees to grantor which are actually billed and collected by grantee based upon revenues derived by grantee from the retail sale of natural gas to customers within the annexed area. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-9. - Breach of franchise; remedies. 
In the event of a breach by grantee of any material provision hereof, grantor may terminate the franchise and rights granted to grantee hereunder, provided, however, that such termination shall not be effective unless and until the procedures described below have been followed: 
(1)  Grantor must deliver to grantee, by certified or registered mail, a written notice signed by the mayor or other duly authorized member of grantor's governing body or the city manager, attested by grantor's secretary. Such notice must: 
a.  Fairly and fully set forth in detail each of the alleged acts or omissions of grantee that grantor contends constitutes a breach of any material provision hereof; 
b.  Designate which of the terms and conditions hereof grantor contends grantee breached; and 
c.  Specify the date, time, and place at which a public hearing will be held by the governing body of grantor for the purpose of determining whether the allegations contained in the notice did in fact occur, provided, however, that the date of such hearing may not be less than thirty (30) days after the date of such notice. 
(2)  Within thirty (30) days following the adjournment of the public hearing described in subsection (1), grantor must deliver to grantee, by certified or registered mail, a written notice signed by the mayor or other duly authorized member of grantor's governing body, attested by grantor's secretary, setting forth: 
a.  The acts and omissions of grantee described in the first notice that the governing body of grantor determines to have in fact occurred, and 
b.  The specific terms and conditions hereof listed in the first notice that the governing body of grantor determines to have in fact been breached by such acts or omissions of grantee. 
(3)  Grantor must permit grantee the opportunity to substantially correct all of the breaches hereof set forth in the written notice described in subsection (2) within sixty (60) days after grantee's receipt of such notice. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-10. - Additional requirements; miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Grantee shall at all times indemnify and hold harmless grantor from and against any and all claims for injury to any person or property by reason of grantee's or its employees' failure to exercise reasonable care in installing, maintaining and operating the system. Provided, however, that none of the provisions of this paragraph shall be applicable to the extent grantor, its officials, officers, employees, contractors, or agents, were negligent and such negligence was the sole or contributing factor in bringing about injury to any person or property. In such event, any liability shall be apportioned between grantor and grantee based upon the percentage of fault assigned to each by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  Grantee may remove all or any part of its system upon the expiration or termination of the franchise and rights granted hereby. 
(c)  Grantee may transfer or assign the franchise created by this agreement to any other person, proprietorship, partnership, firm or corporation with written permission of grantor, which permission shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(d)  This agreement shall extend to, be binding upon, and inure to the benefit of, the parties hereto, and their respective successors and assigns. 
(e)  To the extent that any other ordinances of grantor or portions thereof are in conflict or inconsistent with any of the terms or provisions hereof, then the terms of this chapter shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-11. - Right of customer to select natural gas supplier. 
It is further ordained that nothing contained in this chapter shall limit or restrict the right of customers within the corporate limits of grantor to select a natural gas supplier as may hereafter be provided by law. The provisions of this section are applicable only in the event grantee becomes an "electing distribution company" under the Georgia Natural Gas Competition and Deregulation Act, O.C.G.A. §§ 46-4-150, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Sec. 6-19-12. - Conflicts. 
Be it further ordained that upon such acceptance of all laws and ordinances, and all agreements between grantee and grantor with respect to grantee's occupancy and use of grantor's streets, alleys, and public places, in actual conflict herewith be and the same shall thereupon stand repealed and terminated, respectively. 
(Ord. No. 2009-26, § I, 7-7-09) 
Chapter 6-20. - [ATLANTA GAS AND LIGHT COMPANY FRANCHISE] 

Sec. 6-20-1. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Dedicated design day capacity means the sum of the individual capacity in Dekatherms attributable to all firm customers, as defined below, located within the city limits of the city, which as of the date hereof is 748.61. 
Firm customers means all residential and business customers who purchase gas service that ordinarily is not subject to interruption or curtailment. 
Fiscal year means the twelve-month period ending September 30 of each year. 
Franchise fee factor means fourteen dollars and fifty-nine cents ($14.59), as periodically adjusted pursuant to section 6-20-4. 
Franchise fee factor adjustment means the percent change in the cost of gas distribution service as determined by the GPSC as a result of a base rate case proceeding in respect of the company. 
GPSC means the Georgia Public Service Commission or such successor regulatory body having general regulatory authority over the company. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-2. - Grant of franchise. 
In exchange for making the franchise fee payments as provided in this agreement, the city grants to the company, its successors and assigns, a non-exclusive right to lay, construct, extend, maintain, renew, replace and repair gas pipes, valves, manholes, service boxes, posts, lamps, structures, appliances and all appurtenances and appendages under, along, through and across any streets, avenues, roads, public highways, alleys, lanes, ways, parks, rights-of-way and other public places in the city (hereinafter collectively referred to as the "city's property") and to use and occupy the city's property for the purpose of therein laying, constructing, extending, maintaining, renewing, replacing and repairing mains, pipes, valves, manholes, service boxes, posts, lamps, structures, appliances and all appurtenances and appendages thereto, used and useful for the manufacture, transmission, distribution and sale of gas within and through the present or future territorial limits of the city, such right, when exercised as herein provided, to commence as of November 1, 2015 and to continue for a term for fifteen (15) years from the date of approval of this chapter. In acknowledgment of the company's prior use of city streets and rights-of-way since November 2004, company also agrees to make a one-time up-front payment of eighteen thousand six hundred ninety-three dollars and fourteen cents ($18,693.14) when this agreement has been executed by both parties. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-3. - Term, effective date, and acceptance of franchise. 
(a)  The term of this franchise shall be for an initial term of fifteen (15) years from and after its passage and approval; provided, this franchise and all rights and privileges herein provided shall be extended for one (1) successive period of five (5) years unless city by notice given to grantee by ordinance duly enacted and approved at least six (6) months before the end of such initial term shall declare such termination effective. 
(b)  The franchise created hereby shall become effective upon its final passage and approval by city, in accordance with applicable laws and regulations, and upon acceptance by grantee by written instrument within sixty (60) days of passage by the governing body, and filed with the clerk of the city. If company does not, within sixty (60) days following company's receipt of notice from city regarding city's passage of this chapter, express in writing its objections to any terms or provisions contained therein, or reject this chapter in its entirety, company shall be deemed to have accepted this chapter and all of its terms and conditions. 
(c)  Subject to the last sentence of this subsection (c), on the expiration of this franchise, in the event the same is not renewed, or on the termination of any renewal of said franchise, or on termination of said franchise for any other reason, the plant and facilities of grantee installed, constructed and operated hereunder may, at the option of the city become the property of the city, and city receiving all legally required regulatory approvals, including, but not limited to, approval of the Georgia Public Service Commission (GPSC), upon payment to company, its successors and/or assigns, of a fair valuation thereof, such fair valuation to be determined by agreement between the city and grantee, its successors and/or assigns. City agrees that, at the time of such transfer of facilities, it shall assume grantee's contractual and regulatory obligations maintained in connection with the system. Notwithstanding the foregoing sentence, upon the expiration or termination of this franchise for any reason, company may, at its election, remove or retire all or part of its system upon the expiration or termination of the franchise and rights granted hereby. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-4. - Considerations, terms and conditions. 
(a)  Company shall be entitled to charge for gas distribution service furnished by it at such rates as are prescribed by the GPSC or other lawful regulatory body of the State of Georgia. 
(b)  The franchise fees due to the city for each fiscal year during the term of this chapter shall equal the product of the franchise fee factor, as periodically adjusted pursuant to this section 6-20-4, and the dedicated design day capacity in the city as of the last day of the previous fiscal year. 
The following formula quantifies this payment: FF = FFF x DDDC 
Where: 
FF = total franchise fees due city for each Fiscal Year 
FFF = the Franchise Fee Factor 
DDDC = the Dedicated Design Day Capacity in the City as of the last day of the previous Fiscal Year 
(c)  The franchise fee factor shall be adjusted periodically by multiplying the franchise fee factor and the franchise fee factor adjustment. Such adjustment shall occur only in the fiscal year immediately following a resolution of a base rate case proceeding with the GPSC in respect of the company. 
(d)  The company as the holder of the franchise privilege hereunder is responsible for the payment of all franchise fees payable hereunder, and shall file such reports and returns as required by this ordinance. In addition, the company shall report annually to the city the names of all gas marketers for which company is transporting natural gas on the distribution system within the city. Company shall make the franchise fee payments to city on the same schedule and with such supporting documentation as company provides to other municipalities in Georgia. 
(e)  The franchise fee payments required hereunder shall be in lieu of any franchise fee, license fee, permit fee, administrative fee, occupation tax or other payment for the use of the rights-of-way by the company for the provision of gas distribution service, but shall not prohibit imposition of a license fee or an occupation tax on gas marketers. The mayor and council of the city through its authorized representative or representatives shall have the right to inspect and audit the books and records of company for the purpose of determining the amount of its revenues received from the provision of gas distribution service as set forth above within said territorial limits. The company shall comply with the city's utility right-of-way permitting process, as enacted, so long as such process does not conflict with O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92 and is not more restrictive than rules and regulations as promulgated by the Georgia Department of Transportation. The city will not charge the company any other franchise fee, occupation tax, or regulatory fee, as prohibited by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-16, or any other fee prohibited by state law. Company reserves the right to reduce the annual franchise fee payable to the city for any and all fees, taxes or charges assessed by the city in contravention of this section in connection with the granting of permits to perform company's work on city's property during such fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-5. - Rights granted. 
All rights herein granted and authorized by the city shall be subject to and governed only by this chapter; provided, however, that the city expressly reserves unto itself all of its police power to adopt general ordinances necessary to protect the safety and welfare of the general public in relation to the rights hereby granted not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-6. - Operation of system; excavation of public right-of-way. 
(a)  Company, upon making an opening in the city's property, for the purpose of laying, repairing or maintaining gas facilities, shall use due care and caution to prevent injury to persons, and shall replace and restore the city's property to its former condition as nearly as practicable, and within a reasonable time, and shall not unnecessarily obstruct or impede traffic upon the streets, avenues, roads, public highways, alleys, lanes, ways, parks and other places of the city. In the event that city or any other entity acting on behalf of city requests or demands that the company move to remodify, relocate, reconstruct or adjust any part of the system from their then current locations within the streets, alleys and public places of the city in connection with a public project or improvement, then company shall relocate, at its own expense, the system facilities affected by such project or improvement. If the number of company's active customers within the geographical boundaries of the city does not exceed one thousand two hundred (1,200), company's obligations under this paragraph shall apply without regard to whether the company has acquired, or claims to have acquired, an easement or other property right with respect to such system facilities and shall not affect the amounts paid or to be paid to city under the provisions of this chapter. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, company shall not be obligated to relocate, at its expense, any of the following: 
(1)  System facilities that are located on private property at the time relocation is requested or demanded; 
(2)  System facilities that are relocated in connection with sidewalk improvements (unless such sidewalk improvements are related to or associated with road widening projects, the creation of new turn lanes, or the addition of acceleration/deceleration lanes); or 
(3)  Streetscape projects or other projects undertaken primarily for aesthetic purposes. 
(b)  When the city reasonably determines it necessary to have a gas facility removed, relocated, or adjusted, resulting from a city street improvement project as set forth above, the city shall give to the company at least sixty (60) days written notice directing it to begin the physical removal, or relocation, or adjustment of such gas facility obstruction or interference. Such notice to company shall include the submission of a letter and a set of preliminary plans for the proposed improvement project. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-7. - Hold harmless by company. 
Company shall save and keep harmless the city from any and all liability by reason of damage or injury to any person or persons whomsoever, on account of negligence of the company in the installation, maintenance and repair of its mains and pipe lines located in the city's property, provided the company shall have been notified in writing of any claim against the city on account thereof and shall have been given ample opportunity to defend the same. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-8. - Insurance. 
Throughout the term of this franchise agreement, the company shall, at its own cost and expense, maintain comprehensive general liability insurance and provide the city certificates of insurance designating the city as additional insured and demonstrating that the company has obtained the insurance required in this section. Such policy or policies shall be in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death to any one person, and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death to any two (2) or more persons resulting from one (1) occurrence, and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for property damage resulting from any one (1) accident. Such policy or policies shall be non-cancelable except upon thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the city. The company shall provide workers' compensation coverage in accordance with applicable law. The company shall indemnify and hold harmless the city from any workers' compensation claims to which the company may become subject during the term of this franchise agreement. Alternatively, and in lieu of the foregoing insurance requirements, the company may elect to self-insure or insure through its captive insurance carrier, provided that company or its parent company have sufficient net worth to do so, as determined by customary practice in the natural gas utility industry. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-9. - Granting of additional franchise. 
If city grants a franchise to any other person, firm or corporation, for the distribution and sale of gas in the certificated territory then served by company, or if the city elects to establish a municipal system for the distribution and selling of gas, any proposed facilities within the certificated area of company, city shall obtain necessary approvals as required by law or applicable regulations. City shall notify, or shall require any person, firm or corporation franchised for distribution and sale of gas to notify the GPSC and company of their intention to install facilities within the company's certificated service territory at least thirty (30) days prior to such installation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16) 
Sec. 6-20-10. - Notices. 
Any and all notices required to be given under this agreement shall be in writing and shall be delivered by U.S. Mail, return receipt requested, commercial overnight courier or hand delivery and shall be deemed delivered when received or rejected for receipt by the recipient. 
(Ord. No. 2015-37, § I, 1-5-16)

CHAPTER 8-3. - PROPERTY NUMBERING; STREET NAMES 

Sec. 8-3-1. - Established. 
There is hereby established a uniform system for numbering property and buildings along all streets, avenues and other public ways within the city. 
(Code 1958, § 19-34) 
Sec. 8-3-2. - Base lines defined; base line map established. 
The base lines for the uniform system for numbering property and buildings within the city shall be defined as follows and shall be described on a map entitled Property Numbering Base Line Map of the City of Gainesville: 
(1)  North/south base line. The base line known as the north-and-south base line, which shall divide the city into a northern section and southern section, shall be defined as follows: 
Beginning at a point where land lots #5, #6, #171 and #172 intersect; thence along the boundary line between land lots 171 and 170 to a point where land lots 171, 170, 164 and 165 intersect; thence along the boundary line between land lots 171 and 164 to a point where it intersects with Washington Avenue; thence along Washington Avenue to its intersection with State Highway 53; thence in an easterly direction along State Highway 53 to Washington Street; thence along Washington Street to its intersection with Prior Street; thence in a southerly direction on Prior Street to its intersection with Spring Street; thence in an easterly direction along Spring Street to its intersection with U.S. Highway 23; thence in an easterly direction along U.S. Highway 23 to its point of intersection with that part of East Main Street in New Holland which is not a part of U.S. Highway 23. 
(2)  North and south streets. All streets north of the north-and-south base line and running generally in a northerly-southerly direction shall be known as north streets. And likewise all streets south of the north-and-south base line running generally in a northerly-southerly direction shall be known as south streets. 
(3)  East/west base line. The base line known as the east-and-west base line, which shall divide the city into an eastern section and a western section, shall be defined as follows: 
Beginning at a point where South Bradford Street projected would intersect with the Gainesville Militia District boundary line; thence in a northerly direction along the line of South Bradford Street projected to the beginning of South Bradford Street; thence in a northerly direction along South Bradford Street to North Bradford Street; thence in a northerly direction along North Bradford Street to intersection with Academy Street; thence in an easterly direction along Academy Street to its intersection with North Green Street; thence in a northerly direction along North Green Street to its intersection with Thompson Bridge Road; thence in a northerly direction along Thompson Bridge Road to its intersection with Fairway Drive. 
(4)  East and west streets. Streets east of the east-and-west base line and running in a generally easterly-westerly direction shall be known as west streets. 
(Code 1958, § 19-35) 
Sec. 8-3-3. - Quadrants. 
(a)  Designated. The area north of the north-and-south base line and east of the east-and-west base line shall be designated as northeast. The area north of the north-and-south base line and west of the east-and-west base line shall be designated as northwest. The area south of the north-and-south base line and east of the east-and-west base line shall be known as southeast. The area south of the north-and-south base line and west of the east-and-west base line shall be known as southwest. 
(b)  Name of streets, avenues, etc., to carry quadrant designation. Any streets, avenues and other public ways shall hereafter include as a part of its name a designation indicating the quadrant in which it is located. 
(c)  Building number and address to carry quadrant designation. All buildings in the city shall carry a number and address which shall indicate the quadrant in which they are located. 
(Code 1958, § 19-36) 
Sec. 8-3-4. - Diagonal streets. 
All buildings on diagonal streets shall be numbered the same as buildings on north-south streets if the diagonal is in a north-south direction and shall be numbered the same as buildings on east-west streets if the diagonal is in an east-west direction. 
(Code 1958, § 19-37) 
Sec. 8-3-5. - Numbering. 
(a)  Property; odd and even numbers. The numbering of property on each street shall begin at the appropriate base line, and such numbers shall change from one hundred (100) to the next higher hundred on the basis of grid lines shown on the base line map. All numbers shall be assigned on the basis of one (1) number for each 13.2 feet of property frontage along a street. All property on the right hand side of a street as one leaves a base line and proceeds outward shall bear even numbers, and likewise all buildings on the left hand side of the street as one leaves a base line and proceeds outward shall bear odd numbers. 
(b)  Building numbers. A building shall be assigned the number assigned to the 13.2-foot interval of street frontage in which its main entrance lies. If the main entrance of the building is exactly upon the line which divides a 13.2-foot interval from another 13.2-foot interval, the number assigned to either interval may be assigned to the building entrance. 
(c)  Multiple entrances. Where a building has a number of entrances, each serving a separate occupant, then each entrance shall be assigned a separate number provided that there shall be enough numbers assigned to the lot on which the building is located to provide a number for each entrance. In the event there are not sufficient numbers assigned to the lot to serve each separate entrance, then each separate entrance shall carry the principal number plus a suitable letter suffix. 
(d)  Multifamily dwellings. A multifamily dwelling having only one (1) main entrance shall be assigned only one (1) number, and separate apartments in the building will carry a letter designation such as A, B, C, in addition to the number assigned to the main entrance of the building. 
(e)  Apartment projects with more than one building. In the case of an apartment project containing two (2) or more apartment buildings, one (1) of the numbers assigned to the property on which it is located shall be assigned to the total project. In addition, each building shall be numbered beginning with the number 1. Finally, each apartment in a particular building shall be assigned a letter designation in addition to the number of the building in which it is located. 
(f)  Extended streets. All buildings facing streets not extended through to the base line shall be assigned the same relative number as if the street had extended to the base line. 
(Code 1958, § 19-38) 
Cross reference— Building regulations, Ch. 7-1. 
Sec. 8-3-6. - Responsibility for placement of numbers on buildings. 
After a house or building shall be assigned its respective number or numbers, the owner, occupant or agent shall place or cause to be placed upon each house or building controlled by him the number or numbers assigned to such house or building under the system established by this article. 
(Code 1958, § 19-39) 
Sec. 8-3-7. - Effective date of numbers. 
All numbers assigned to houses and buildings shall be placed on such houses and buildings within twenty (20) days after such numbers are assigned. 
(Code 1958, § 19-40) 
Sec. 8-3-8. - Cost of numbers responsibility of property owners. 
The cost of numbers shall be borne by the property owner. The numbers used shall be not less than three (3) inches in height and shall be made of durable and clearly visible material. 
(Code 1958, § 19-41) 
Sec. 8-3-9. - Location of numbers. 
The numbers shall be conspicuously placed immediately above on or at the side of the proper door of each building or house so that the number can be seen plainly from the street line. Whenever any building or house is situated more than fifty (50) feet from the street line such number shall be placed near the walk, driveway or common entrance to such building or house, or upon a gate post, fencepost, tree or other appropriate place so as to be easily discernible from the sidewalk. 
(Code 1958, § 19-42) 
Sec. 8-3-10. - Plat book of property numbers; established; open to public. 
For the purpose of facilitating a correct numbering system, a plat book of all streets, avenues and public ways, showing the proper numbers of all property fronting upon all streets, avenues or public ways shall be prepared and shall be on file in the office of the planning director. These plats shall be open to inspection of all persons during office hours. Duplicate copies of such plats shall be furnished to the director of public works, the chief building inspector and such other departments or department directors as shall have need for such plats. Duplicate copies of such plats shall also be furnished to the United States Postal Service. 
(Code 1958, § 19-43) 
Sec. 8-3-11. - Administration by planning director. 
It shall be the duty of the planning director to inform any party applying therefor of the number or numbers belonging to or embraced within the limits of any lot or property as provided by this article. In the case of conflict as to the proper number to be assigned to any building, the planning director shall determine the number of such building. 
(Code 1958, § 19-44) 
Sec. 8-3-12. - New buildings; numbers required, prerequisite to issuance of building permit and final approval of structure. 
Whenever any building shall be erected or located in the city, the owner shall procure the correct number or numbers as designated by the chief building inspector for the property and shall immediately fasten the number or numbers so assigned upon such building as provided by this article. A building permit shall not be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has procured from the planning director the official number of the premises. Final approval of any structure erected, repaired or altered or modified shall be withheld by the chief building inspector until permanent and proper numbers have been affixed to such structure. 
(Code 1958, § 19-45) 
Sec. 8-3-13. - Street names; planning commission to examine, make recommendations. 
For the purpose of clarifying and systematizing the street names in the city, the planning commission shall examine all street names within the city, and when it shall find duplication of street names or similarity of street names which might cause confusion, or when it shall find street names that will cause difficulty in the assigning of numbers, it shall then recommend appropriate name changes to the city council. 
(Code 1958, § 19-46) 
Sec. 8-3-14. - New subdivisions—Plats to show street names; certification by planning commission. 
Every subdivision plat submitted to the planning commission shall show the proposed names of all streets, and the planning commission shall certify that these proposed names do not conflict with existing street names before such street names are officially adopted. 
(Code 1958, § 19-47) 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, Ch. 8-2. 
Sec. 8-3-15. - Same—Numbering. 
The various lots shown on plats of new subdivisions shall be numbered in accordance with the uniform numbering system established by this article. The numbers assigned to the various lots shall be approved by the planning director. 
(Code 1958, § 19-48) 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, Ch. 8-2.

(e)  Reserved.
