ARTICLE 2. - WASTEWATER DISPOSAL 

Sec. 10-1-16. - Classification of users. 
For the purpose of establishing sewer service charges under chapter 5-1, users are classified as follows effective July 1, 2005: 
(1)  Residential; 
(2)  Multi-family; 
(3)  Commercial; 
(4)  General industry. 
(Code 1958, § 18-55; Ord. No. 92-50, § 1, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 2005-36, § I, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 10-1-17. - Sanitary sewer service fees charged. 
(a)  Monthly account servicing fees and monthly per unit (one hundred (100) cubic feet) sanitary sewer service fees: 
(1)  Account servicing fees. All classes of sanitary sewer users inside or outside the corporate limits of the city who purchase water from the city shall pay no monthly account servicing fee on the sanitary sewer portion of the utility bill when billed with the water service. 
(2)  All classes of sanitary sewer users whether located inside or outside the corporate limits of the city whose sewer flow is metered and billed separately from their water meters shall pay a monthly account servicing fee in accordance with fees established in subsection 10-1-41(b). 
(3)  Monthly per unit (one hundred (100) cubic feet) sanitary sewer service fees for all classes of users by district: 

 
Effective January 1, 2017 Residential classification users will be capped at twelve (12) ccfs per month with a return factor of ninety-three (93) percent. 
(b)  The director shall notify all classes of users biennially of the actual cost of operation and maintenance of the system. 
(c)  In addition to the above, all classes of users except residential and multifamily shall be billed, as a surcharge, a fee based upon their pollutant load in excess of that found in the maximum residential waste effluent. The director, in accordance with the standard practice for sample taking and sample analysis, shall compute monthly for each class of user, the amount of waste pollutants in mg/l/ccf (milligrams per liter per hundred cubic feet) introduced in the sewer system in excess of the residential criteria hereafter established. Computation shall be based on sample(s) taken in a water service period. In the event there are no samples taken in a service period, the most recent sample shall be used for the monthly computation for up to four (4) consecutive monthly computations. 
(d)  In addition to surcharges, all classes of users except residential and multifamily shall be billed, as a penalty, a fee based upon their pollutant load of oil and grease in excess of that found in the maximum residential waste effluent. The director in accordance with the standard practice for sample taking and sample analysis, shall compute monthly for each class of user, the amount of waste pollutants in mg/l/ccf (milligrams per liter per hundred cubic feet) introduced in the sewer system in excess of residential criteria hereafter established. Computation shall be based on sample(s) taken in a water service period. In the event there are no samples taken in a service period, the most recent sample shall be used for the monthly computation for up to four (4) consecutive monthly computations. 
(e)  Waste effluent contaminants to be analyzed and measured for surcharge and penalty are: 
(1)  Biochemical oxygen demand; 
(2)  Suspended solids; 
(3)  Oil and grease; 
(4)  Phosphorus; 
(5)  Total Kjeldahl nitrogen. 
(f)  The criteria hereby established for maximum or upper limit residential waste is: 
(1)  Biochemical oxygen demand, 250 mg/l; 
(2)  Suspended solids, 250 mg/l; 
(3)  Oil and grease, 100 mg/l; 
(4)  Phosphorus, 7 mg/l; 
(5)  Total Kjeldahl nitrogen, 40 mg/l. 
(g)  The surcharge to industrial and commercial users for excess pollutants over the maximum residential criteria each month will be computed as follows: 
(1)  Biochemical oxygen demand. Nineteen-hundredths of a cent ($0.0019) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of residential criteria up to five hundred (500) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
(2)  Total suspended solids. Fourteen-hundredths of a cent ($0.0014) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of total suspended solids (TSS) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of residential criteria up to five hundred (500) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
(3)  Phosphorus. Two and two-tenths cents ($0.022) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total phosphorus (P) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of residential criteria up to eleven (11) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
(4)  Total Kjeldahl nitrogen. Five-tenths of a cent ($0.005) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of residential criteria up to seventy-five (75) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
(h)  The penalty to industrial and commercial users for excess pollutants over the maximum residential criteria each month will be computed as follows: 
(1)  Fats, oil, and grease. Five-tenths of a cent ($0.005) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total fat, oil and grease (FOG) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of residential criteria up to one hundred twenty-five (125) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
(i)  A minimum fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00) shall be charged for monitoring a minor stream spill of zero (0) to ten thousand (10,000) gallons. A minimum fee of four thousand, five hundred dollars ($4,500.00) shall be charged for monitoring a large spill greater than ten thousand (10,000) gallons. 
(j)  Fees for testing private water samples for contaminates are as follows: 
BOD 5 ..... $30.00 
COD ..... 20.00 
Coliform, fecal ..... 45.00 
Coliform, total ..... 45.00 
Nitrogen, ammonia ..... 20.00 
Nitrogen, nitrate ..... 20.00 
Nitrogen, total Kjeldahl ..... 40.00 
Oil and grease ..... 35.00 
pH ..... 5.00 
Orthophosphate, total ..... 30.00 
Phosphorus, total ..... 30.00 
Solids, total ..... 10.00 
Solids, total suspended ..... 11.00 
(Code 1958, § 18-56; Ord. No. 88-13, § 1, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 88-33, § 1, 6-21-88; Ord. No. 89-81, § 1, 12-19-89; Ord. No. 92-07, § 1, 2-18-92; Ord. No. 92-50, §§ 2—4, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 94-34, § I, 7-5-94; Ord. No. 94-38, § I, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 97-04, § I, 2-4-97; Ord. No. 97-44, § I, 9-16-97; Ord. No. 98-64, § I, 12-1-98; Ord. No. 99-93, § I, 1-4-00; Ord. No. 2000-58, § I, 8-15-00; Ord. No. 00-96, § I, 12-21-00; Ord. No. 2001-14, § I, 3-6-01; Ord. No. 2001-35, § I, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 2001-71, §§ I, II, 12-18-01; Ord. No. 2002-29, § I, 6-18-02; Ord. No. 2002-54, § I, 10-8-02; Ord. No. 2003-38, § I, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 2004-52, § I, 6-15-04; Ord. No. 2004-53, § I, 6-15-04; Ord. No. 2005-36, § I, 7-19-05; Ord. No. 2006-25, § I, 7-5-06; Ord. No. 2006-61, § I, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2006-62, §§ I, II, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2007-27, § I, 7-3-07; Ord. No. 2008-44, § I, 12-16-08; Ord. No. 2009-30, § I, 8-4-09; Ord. No. 2009-44, § I, 12-1-09; Ord. No. 2010-20, § I, 7-6-10; Ord. No. 2011-04, § I, 2-15-11; Ord. No. 2011-06, §§ I, II, 6-7-11; Ord. No. 2011-11, § I, 7-5-11; Ord. No. 2012-22, § I, 7-17-12; Ord. No. 2013-08, § I, 6-18-13; Ord. No. 2014-21, § I, 9-16-14, eff. 1-1-15; Ord. No. 2015-22, § I, 8-4-15, eff. 1-1-16; Ord. No. 2016-06, § I, 6-21-16, eff. 1-1-17) 
Sec. 10-1-18. - Calculation of charges. 
(a)  The monthly sewer charge for residential users who are located both inside and outside the city limits shall be calculated based on a percentage of the usage calculated from the monthly water meter readings. The percentage used for calculation of the monthly bill shall be eighty-five (85) percent of the metered water usage. The percentage calculation shall apply to all residential users except for multiple use served by a single or master meter on which the sewer charge shall be calculated on each month's entire water usage. 
(b)  The sewer charge for all other classes of users who are located both inside and outside the city limits of the city and who are served by the sewers shall be calculated on each month's water usage as shown by the water meter. In the event that any user receives a water supply from sources other than the city's system, such additional sources shall be metered, and the sewer charge shall be based upon the monthly total of all metered water supplied. 
(c)  In the event a portion of the water supply can be shown, to the satisfaction of the director, not to be discharged into the city's sewerage system, credit may be allowed by the city for that portion not discharged. 
(Code 1958, § 18-57; Ord. No. 92-50, § 5, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 2003-41, § I, 7-1-03) 
Sec. 10-1-19. - Excess contaminated waste. 
Wastewater acceptable for treatment without violating the provisions of this chapter is sewage with: 
(1)  Generally. 
a.  BOD of five hundred (500) mg per liter or less. 
b.  Total suspended solids of five hundred (500) mg per liter or less 
c.  Total phosphorus of eleven (11) mg per liter or less. 
d.  Total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) of seventy-five (75) mg per liter or less. 
e.  Fats, oil and grease of one hundred twenty-five (125) mg per liter or less. 
f.  Any wastewater accepted with effluent contaminants in excess of the limits of subsections (1)a.—d. of this section shall be charged a surcharge to be computed as follows: 
1.  Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD). 
i.  Five-tenths of a cent ($0.005) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of five hundred (500) milligrams per liter (mg/l) up to seven hundred (700) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
ii.  Fifty-seven-hundredths of a cent ($0.0057) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of seven hundred (700) milligrams per liter (mg/l) to nine hundred (900) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
iii.  One and twelve-hundredths of a cent ($0.0112) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of nine hundred (900) milligrams per liter (mg/l) 
2.  Suspended solids. 
i.  Thirty-five-hundredths of a cent ($0.0035) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of total suspended solids (TSS) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet, (CCF) in excess of five hundred (500) milligrams per liter up to seven hundred (700) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
ii.  Thirty-nine-hundredths of a cent ($0.0039) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of total suspended solids (TSS) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of seven hundred (700) milligrams per liter (mg/l) up to nine hundred (900) milligrams per liter (mg/1). 
iii.  Seventy-two-hundredths of a cent ($0.0072) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total suspended solids (TSS) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of nine hundred (900) milligrams per liter (mg/1). 
3.  Phosphorus. 
i.  Four and nine-tenths ($0.049) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of total phosphorus (P) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of eleven (11) milligrams per liter (mg/l) up to fifteen (15) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
ii.  Five and eight-tenths cents ($0.058) per milligrams per liter (mg/l) of total phosphorus (P) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of fifteen (15) milligrams per liter (mg/l) up to twenty (20) milligrams per liter (mg/1). 
iii.  Eleven and two-tenths cents ($0.112) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total phosphorus (P) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of twenty (20) milligrams per liter (mg/1). 
4.  Total Kjeldahl nitrogen. 
i.  One and three-tenths of a cent ($0.013) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of seventy-five (75) milligrams per liter (mg/1) up to one hundred (100) milligrams per liter (mg/1). 
ii.  One and six-tenths cent ($0.016) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of one hundred (100) milligrams per liter (mg/l) up to one hundred thirty-five (135) milligrams per liter (mg/1). 
iii.  Three and two-tenths cent ($0.032) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of one hundred thirty-five (135) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
g.  Any wastewater accepted with effluent contaminants in excess of the limits of subsections (1)e. of this section shall be charged a surcharge to be computed as follows: 
1.  Fats, oil and grease. 
i.  One and two-tenths of a cent ($0.012) per milligram per liter (mg/l) of total fats, oil and grease (FOG) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of one hundred twenty-five (125) milligrams per liter (mg/1) up to one hundred fifty (150) milligrams per liter (mg/1). 
ii.  One and four-tenths cent ($0.014) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total fats, oil and grease (FOG) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of one hundred fifty (150) milligrams per liter (mg/l) up to one hundred seventy-five (175) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
iii.  Two and eight-tenths cent ($0.028) per milligram per liter (mg/1) of total fats, oil and grease (FOG) for each one hundred (100) cubic feet (CCF) in excess of one hundred seventy-five (175) milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
Provided, however, that payment of the surcharge as provided for herein shall not excuse the violator from any other penalty, termination of service or legal or equitable relief pursued by the city to terminate such violation. 
(Code 1958, § 18-58; Ord. No. 92-07, § 2, 2-18-92; Ord. No. 99-22, § I, 4-6-99; Ord. No. 2001-71, § III, 12-18-01; Ord. No. 2011-06, § III, 6-7-11) 
Editor's note— Section 6 of Ord. No. 92-07, adopted Feb. 18, 1992, provided that section 10-1-19(1)f.4.a, b. and c. be effective with the first billing rendered in January, 1993. 
Sec. 10-1-20. - Tapping and other fees. 
The following fees are hereby established for tapping into the sewer system of the city: 
(1)  For a six-inch service line serving a single dwelling or commercial unit, connecting an outfall, truck or collector sewer, the fee shall be nine hundred dollars ($900.00) for both inside city and outside city customers. 
(2)  In all cases the city shall make the final determination as to the size of the service line to be provided. 
(3)  Service lines larger than six (6) inches may be installed for a fee based on the city's actual cost for each additional inch of diameter. 
(Code 1958, § 18-59; Ord. No. 92-60, § 6, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 2002-26, § I, 6-18-02; Ord. No. 2009-30, § II, 8-4-09; Ord. No. 2014-21, § II, 9-16-14, eff. 1-1-15) 
Note— Section XIII of Ord. No. 2009-30 states that subsection (1) shall become effective January 1, 2010. 
Sec. 10-1-21. - Sanitary sewer system connection fee. 
(a)  Users subject to fee. Users of the sewer system shall pay a sewer connection fee before new or additional service will be made available. Applications for new or additional sewer service must include the street address for a specific lot or lots where the service is to be provided. Applications for sewer service shall expire unless all fees have been paid to the finance department no later than ten (10) calendar days after the date of application issuance by the utilities department. Sewer service approved for a specific lot shall not be transferred to any other lot or property. Existing users shall be subject to the fee when their existing water service tap is inadequate to deliver the volume of water desired and requires an increase in the water service tap and meter size. New users will be subject to the fee at the time new service is requested. All users shall be subject to the sewer connection fee regardless of location (inside or outside city corporate limits) of the service tap. 
(b)  Determination of connection fee. 
(1)  The sanitary sewer system connection fee shall be imposed according to the following schedule: 

 
The sanitary sewer system connection fee shall be paid at the time of application for sanitary sewer service and in addition to the meter and sanitary sewer system tapping fees. 
(2)  The minimum connection fee for any new sanitary sewer service, regardless of the meter size, shall be three thousand five hundred seventy dollars ($3,570.00). 
(c)  Changing tap and meter size. 
(1)  After the original sewer connection fee has been paid and installation made, any customer requesting a change in water tap size resulting in a smaller water meter shall make proper application at the water and sewer department for this change. Such change shall be made without cost to the customer. No credit shall be given for sewer connection fees or water meter costs paid on the existing larger water meter. The water meter removed shall remain the property of the city and shall be returned to the city. 
(2)  After the original sewer connection fee has been paid and installation made, any customer requesting a change in water tap size resulting in a larger water meter shall make proper application at the water and sewer department for this change. The customer shall pay a sewer connection fee equal to the difference between the current applicable sewer connection fee for the existing water meter size and the current applicable sewer connection fee for the requested water meter size. The water meter removed shall remain the property of the city and shall be returned to the city. 
(d)  Payment of fee. 
(1)  Existing users shall pay the sewer connection fee at the time the application is made with the water and sewer department to increase the size of the existing water service tap on meter. 
(2)  New users shall pay the sewer connection fee at the time the application is made with the water and sewer department for sewer service. 
(e)  Revenue restrictions. 
(1)  All revenues received from each sewer system connection fee service area shall be accounted for separately and distinctly from any other system revenues. Available sewer system connection fee balances shall be invested and all interest earned on these investments shall be accounted for as part of the sewer system connection fee revenues for each service area. The accounting system shall be established so that sewer system connection fee collections from each service area, interest earned, and expenses can be clearly tracked on a monthly basis and so that connection fees are properly deposited, accounted for and expended in accordance with section 10-1-21(e). 
(2)  Sewer connection fee funds from each service area shall be expended only for costs related to system improvements, as defined in O.C.G.A § 36-71-2(19), as amended, that provide capacity to serve new connections to the sewer system located within that service area. All costs permitted under O.C.G.A. § 36-71-3(18), as amended, shall be permitted under this section. Such costs include, but are not limited to, planning, design, engineering, land acquisition, land improvement, surveying, and construction or reconstruction costs as well as principal, interest and other financing costs on contracts, bonds, notes or other obligations issued by the city to finance such system improvements. Sewer connection fee funds shall not be expended for maintenance or repair of system improvements nor for operational expenses. 
(f)  Applicant contributions of system improvements; credits/reimbursements. 
(1)  Project improvements are the responsibility of the developer or property owner and no credits against connection fees shall be made for project improvements. Project improvements include all lot or building improvements necessary to provide service (including for example the building sewer and cleanout and pre-stubs if required) and main extensions of eight (8) inches in diameter and up to one hundred (100) feet in length from the property line or project boundary as required to connect to the nearest main. Project improvements also include any other sewer system facilities, including but not limited to pump stations and larger diameter lines, that are planned, designed and are necessary to provide service to a particular development project in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-17-2(14), as amended. Tap costs are covered by the tapping fee imposed pursuant to the Code of the City of Gainesville section 10-1-20. 
(2)  Upon application for new or increased sewer service, the sewer connection fee otherwise due shall be reduced by any applicable credits for the contribution of money or dedication of land for or the construction of system improvements, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-17-2(19), as amended, within the service area where the new connection is located and serving the new connection and required or accepted by the city from the applicant or his predecessor in title or interest. In the event that the amount of credit due exceeds the total sewer connection fees due, an agreement between the applicant and the utilities department shall govern the amount and timing of reimbursement payments to the applicant. The city shall have the option of reimbursing an applicant by a lump sum payment or periodic payments and from existing funds or from sewer connection fees collected in the future. 
(3)  The amount of applicable credit/reimbursement, if any, shall be determined based on credible evidence submitted by the applicant on forms provided by the city utility department, which: (a) describes the contribution for which credit/reimbursement is claimed, (b) establishes the original cost and date of the construction, contribution or dedication, (c) identifies the specific development project for which the construction, contribution or dedication was made, including the location, land use, size, number of buildings or number of dwelling units in the original development project, and (d) describes the development project for which the credit/reimbursement against sewer connection fees is requested, if different from the project described in subsection (c). Credits/reimbursements may not be transferred from one development project to another project. All costs related to submitting the credit/reimbursement application and any additional information requested by the utilities director are the responsibility of the applicant. 
(4)  The director of utilities shall determine the amount of credit/reimbursement due per connection, if any, based on consideration of the original and current or depreciated value of the contribution or dedication, the facilities required to serve the development project, the ability of the contribution or dedication to provide service to other development, and, if the contribution or dedication is determined to be a system improvement which is eligible for credit/reimbursement, the per connection share of the present value of the construction, contribution and dedication. System improvements shall be determined based on accepted engineering principles and data produced by a registered engineer. The burden of establishing eligibility for a credit/reimbursement is on the applicant claiming the credit/reimbursement. All costs incurred by the utilities department, including the value of staff time and/or consultant fees as well as expenses, related to applications for credit/reimbursement shall be the responsibility of and charged to the applicant. Regardless of the results of any appeal of a determination of the utility director by the applicant, utilities department costs billed to and paid by the applicant shall not be refunded. 
(g)  Annual report. At least once every year, the director of utilities and director of finance shall jointly prepare a report on the sewer connection fees. Such report shall include: (1) the total amount of sewer connection fees collected within each service area during the past fiscal year, (2) the total expenditures and projects funded in part or in whole by sewer connection fees within each service are during the past fiscal year, (3) the sewer connection fee interest earned and account balance for each service area, (4) the sewer system projects within each service area anticipated to be funded in whole or in part by sewer connection fees, (5) any proposed changes to the sewer connection fee schedule or sewer connection fee calculation methodology, and (6) any other recommendations as the director of utilities or the director of finance deem appropriate or as may be requested by the city council. 
(h)  Appeal process. 
(1)  Applicants for a new or changed water meter may appeal any determination of the utilities director regarding the meter or line size required to serve the property or the amount of credits and/or reimbursement due for contributions of system improvements to the utilities review committee. Appeals to the utilities review committee must be filed with the city clerk no later than thirty (30) days after the date of determination by the utilities director. The utilities review committee shall provide the applicant with a written explanation of its determination within sixty (60) calendar days of filing of the appeal with the city clerk. Appeals shall be submitted to the city clerk on a form provided by the utilities department. 
(2)  Appeals and determinations of the utilities review committee may be made to the administrative hearing officer as provided pursuant to chapter 1-8 of the Gainesville City Code. 
(i)  Authority to establish an administrative fee. 
(1)  A reasonable fee to cover all or a portion of the administrative costs incurred in administering and managing the sewer connection fee system may be established by resolution of the city council. Such administrative fee may include, but is not limited to, the following costs to the extent the costs are related to the administration and operation of the connection fee system: reasonable charges for city staff time, consultant fees and expenses, and computer equipment/software or other equipment the costs of which are not included in the sewer connection fee calculations. 
(2)  The administrative fee adopted by resolution of the city council shall be paid at the time of application for new or changed sewer service and shall be paid in addition to the cost of the meter, sewer system connection fees and sewer system tapping fees. 
(Code 1958, § 18-59.1; Ord. No. 93-33, §§ I—IX, 7-20-93; Ord. No. 94-55, §§ I, II, 1-17-95; Ord. No. 95-55, §§ I, II, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 96-59, §§ I, II, 12-03-96; Ord. No. 97-66, §§ I, II, 11-18-97; Ord. No. 00-83, §§ I, II, 12-21-00; Ord. No. 2006-25, §§ II—IV, 7-5-06; Ord. No. 2006-61, §§ II—IV, 12-19-06) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2006-25, § II, adopted July 5, 2006, changed the title of § 10-1-21 from "Sewer system connection fee" to "Sanitary sewer system connection fee." The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 10-1-22. - Fund to cover costs of sewer line installation; connection and tapping fees to be paid into funds. 
All fees for tapping into the sewer system lines shall be paid into the water and sewer operational fund. All revenues received from the sewer system connection fees shall only be used for debt service payments, for capital improvements or deposited into the water and sewer construction fund for construction and purchase of capital improvements. All sewer lines installed in the city shall be paid from moneys of the water and sewer construction fund. 
(Code 1958, § 18-60; Ord. No. 95-18, § II, 6-6-95) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 95-18, § I, adopted June 6, 1995, repealed former § 10-1-22, which pertained to the deposit of sewer tapping fees. 
Sec. 10-1-23. - Fees where the water discharged into the city's sanitary sewer system is not purchased from the city. 
(a)  Meter requirement. All classes of sanitary sewer users located inside or outside the corporate limits of the city who do not purchase water from the city that is discharged into the sanitary sewers of the city, shall cause all such water to pass through a meter that is approved by the city and is set at a location that is approved by the city. The meter shall be read each month and a sum computed and paid monthly by the owner of the water as applicable in section 10-1-18. 
(b)  Account servicing fees. All classes of sanitary sewer users whether located inside or outside the corporate limits of the city who do not purchase water from the city, shall pay a monthly account servicing fee in accordance with fees established in subsection 10-1-41(e). 
(c)  Monthly per unit (one hundred (100) cubic feet) sanitary sewer service fees. In addition to the monthly account servicing fee all classes of sanitary sewer users whether located inside or outside the corporate limits of the city who do not purchase water from the city, shall pay a monthly per unit sanitary sewer service fee as established in subsection 10-1-17(a)(3). 
(Ord. No. 2006-25, § V, 7-5-06; Ord. No. 2006-61, § V, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2006-62, §§ III, Iv, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2007-27, § II, 7-3-07; Ord. No. 2008-44, § II, 12-16-08)

Sec. 10-1-24. - Disposition on discontinuance of service. 
(a)  In the event of failure of any person to pay any charge herein provided, execution therefor may be issued by the secretary of the city council, and the same may be enforced by levy and sale of any property with which city sewers are connected and to which such water is supplied. 
(b)  In event of failure of any person to pay any charge herein provided, the city may discontinue sewer service to the property at which the water was used and may not reinstate sewer service to such property until the amount owing has been paid. 
(c)  Upon failure to pay the monthly fees prescribed, the city shall have the right after five (5) days' notice to the party in default to discontinue water service to the party in default, if using city water, and to disconnect the sewer from such party's property, or both, until all sewer charges have been paid in full. 
(Code 1958, § 18-62) 
Sec. 10-1-25. - Service outside city; application, fees, costs. 
Any person located outside the city limits desiring to connect sanitary sewers with the sewer lines of the city shall be permitted to do so only after compliance with the following conditions: 
(1)  Application for permission to connect a sanitary sewer to the city sewer line shall be made on forms to be furnished by the city. 
(2)  All costs of construction, including materials, shall be paid by the property owner(s) who shall likewise bear all costs of maintenance and repair which shall be done by the city and paid for by the property owner(s). Original construction shall be done under supervision of the city and shall be done in accordance with the specifications of the plumbing code of the city. The plumbing inspector shall approve by inspection all connections and tap-ons before being completed. 
(3)  Fees prescribed in the plumbing code of the city for service inside the city for connections, inspections, etc., shall be paid as though the work was being done inside the city. 
(Code 1958, § 18-63) 
Sec. 10-1-26. - User charge system for operation and maintenance costs. 
(a)  Basis for user charge. The wastewater characteristics which are used to determine user charge are: 
(1)  BOD, 
(2)  Suspended solids, 
(3)  Flow volume, 
(4)  Oil and grease and 
(5)  Phosphorus. 
Normal wastewater dischargers and industrial wastewater dischargers of normal strength wastewaters, shall be charged a basic user charge in which flow volume is the wastewater characteristic for determining the charge. 
(b)  Basic user charge. The formula for determining basic user charge which applies to normal strength discharges shall be as follows: 

 
(c)  Surcharged wastewater. When BOD, suspended solids, oil and grease or phosphorus concentrations in a user's wastewater discharge is in excess of the range of concentration in normal strength wastewater, a surcharge shall be added to the base charge. 
(d)  Surcharge determination. When BOD, suspended solids, oil and grease and phosphorus exceed the range of concentration of those pollutants in normal strength wastewater, a surcharge shall be added in the basis charge. The surcharge shall be determined as follows: 

 
(e)  Unit value determination. The basic unit, C t , which shall be revised not less frequently than biennially, shall be determined as follows: 

 
C t ,B;sub  \sub;,S;sub  \sub;,G;sub  \sub; and P;sub  \sub; are as defined in subsections (b) and (d). B d ,S d ,G d and P d shall be revised not less frequently than biennially and shall be determined by dividing actual wastewater treatment plant loading less total surcharged loading by total annual volume contribution by domestic waste water dischargers. 
V;sub  \sub;,B;sub  \sub;,S;sub  \sub;,G;sub  \sub; and P;sub  \sub; shall be revised not less often than two (2) years by dividing their respective annual maintenance and operation costs by their respective annual loadings. Wastewater discharge volume (V m ) for dischargers of normal strength wastewater shall be one hundred (100) percent of the amount of water metered. For industrial waste- water dischargers which discharge surcharged waste, the wastewater discharge volume (V u ) shall be one hundred (100) percent of the amount of water metered, unless it can be shown that the volume of wastewater discharge is less. 
(f)  Biennial review. The total cost of operation and maintenance of the treatment works, its approved user charge system and the contribution of the users shall be reviewed not less than every two (2) years. Charges for users shall be revised to maintain the distribution of operation and maintenance costs among users and to generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and maintenance cost necessary to the proper operation and maintenance of treatment works equipment. 
(g)  Inconsistent agreements. The user charge system shall take precedence over any terms, conditions of agreements or contracts between the city and the user, including industrial users, districts, other municipalities or federal agencies which are inconsistent with the requirements of Section 204(b)(1)(a) of the Clean Water Act and these regulations. 
(h)  Excess revenue. Revenues collected in excess of revenues used to defray operation, maintenance and renewal and extension costs in any year shall be applied to the costs of operation and maintenance for the next year, and the user charge adjusted to absorb the excess. 
(i)  Toxic pollutants. Each user which discharges any toxic substance to the publicly owned sewer, which causes an increase in the costs of managing the effluent or the sludge of the treatment works, shall pay for the increased costs. 
(j)  Extraneous flows. Maintenance and operation costs for all flows not attributable to users shall be distributed among all users in proportion of flow volume of the user discharge. 
(k)  Notification. Each user shall be notified no less than annually with a regular bill, of the rate and that portion of the user charges which are attributable to wastewater treatment services. 
(l)  Implementation. The city shall implement the user charge system as soon as it is approved by the director of the environmental protection division. For the first year of operation, operation and maintenance charges shall be based upon past experience and judgment. After one (1) year of documentation of operation and maintenance cost and user loadings, user charges will be revised based on actual data. User charges shall be reviewed annually and revised to reflect actual operation and maintenance cost of the treatment plant works. 
(m)  Records. The city shall document the various waste treatment plant loading categories and the operation and maintenance costs attributable to each category, record user charge revenues and demonstrate that the user charge derived is a proportional distribution of operation and maintenance costs. 
(Code 1958, § 18-64.1) 
Sec. 10-1-27. - Private wastewater disposal. 
(a)  The application fee to start service related to discharging private wastewater into the publicly owned treatment works shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(b)  The cash bond required for discharging wastewater into the publicly owned treatment works or storage facility shall be in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(c)  The fee for discharging private wastewater into the publicly owned treatment works or storage facility shall be two hundred ninety-two dollars ($292.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons or a portion thereof. 
(Code 1958, §§ 18-11, 18-16.1; Ord. No. 92-50, § 8, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 94-38, § III, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 95-55, § III, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 2002-27, § I, 6-18-02) 
Sec. 10-1-28. - Commercial waste transporter permit fee. 
A commercial waste transporter permit fee will be assessed on an annual basis at a rate of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first truck and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each additional truck owned by the same company for tank trucks inspected and permitted by the city to haul commercial waste. 
(Ord. No. 2005-21, § I, 6-21-05) 
Secs. 10-1-29—10-1-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 3. - WATER 

Sec. 10-1-41. - Classification of users and rate schedule. 
(a)  Classification of users. For the purpose of establishing water service charges under chapter 5-2, users are classified as follows effective July 1, 2007: 
(1)  Residential; 
(2)  Multi-family; 
(3)  Commercial; 
(4)  General industry; 
(5)  Irrigation (commercial and residential). 
(b)  Account servicing fees. Effective January 1, 2010, all classes of water users whether located inside or outside the corporate limits of the city shall pay a monthly account servicing fee as determined by an annual review of costs to service billing accounts and as identified in subsection 10-1-41(e). 
(c)  Meter requirement. All classes of water users whether inside or outside the corporate limits of the city shall have a water meter installed by the city or its designated contractor and be charged an account servicing fee and monthly per unit water service fees as provided for in this chapter. Units are measured by each one hundred (100) cubic feet (ccf) of water used. 
It shall be unlawful to obstruct access to any water meter connected to the city's water system. Meters must not be obstructed by any method including, but not limited to, landscaping, debris or vehicles. If the customer fails to correct the violation after receiving notification, the public utilities department can take action to remedy the situation. Any expenses incurred by the utility will be the responsibility of the customer. 
(d)  Conservation pricing. The city hereby implements water conservation pricing. All classes of water users whether inside or outside the corporate limits of the city shall be charged for the water they use in hundred cubic feet. The structure of the water conservation rates is as follows: 
(1)  Residential classes of customers whether inside or outside the corporate limits of the city shall be charged for their consumption in blocks based on specific consumption amounts. 

 
(2)  Commercial and multi-family classes of customers whether inside or outside the corporate limits of the city shall be charged for their consumption in blocks based on averaging. 

 
Until an average is established, commercial and multi-family classes whether inside or outside the corporate limits of the city shall be charged for their consumption at the block 1 water service fee. 
(3)  General industry classes of customers will not be subject to a conservation rate and shall be charged for their consumption at the block 1 water service fee. 
(4)  Irrigation classes of customers whether inside or outside the corporate limits of the city shall be charged for their use at the block 3 water service fee. 
(e)  Fees charged.

No. 2011-11, § II, 7-5-11; Ord. No. 2012-22, § II, 7-17-12; Ord. No. 2013-08, § II, 6-18-13; Ord. No. 2014-21, § III, 9-16-14, eff. 1-1-15; Ord. No. 2015-22, § II(1), 8-4-15, eff. 1-1-16) 
Sec. 10-1-42. - Tapping fees. 
(a)  For making taps into the city water mains or water lines, the city shall charge according to the following schedule: 

 
(b)  The foregoing charges shall include not more than one hundred (100) feet of pipe to convey water to property line. If additional pipe is used to convey water to customer's property line, the cost of such additional pipe and installation thereof shall be paid by customer in addition to the foregoing charges at actual cost of such additional footage. 
(c)  After the original tapping fee has been paid and installation made, should the customer request a change in tap size resulting in a smaller meter, the customer shall make proper application at the water department for this change, and such change shall be made without cost to the customer. The meter removed shall remain the property of the city, shall be returned to the city and no credit given for tapping fees paid on the existing larger meter. 
(d)  After the original tapping fee has been paid and installation made, should the customer request a change in tap size resulting in a larger meter, the customer shall make proper application at the water department. A credit of sixty (60) percent of the tapping fee applicable to the existing meter in use will be deducted from the applicable tapping fee on the increased meter size, and the customer shall pay the net difference due in advance. The meter removed shall remain the property of the city and shall be returned to the city. 
(e)  Each water customer shall reimburse to the city all fees and costs paid by the city to any other governing body or authority. 
(f)  Deposit of tapping fees. All fees for tapping into the water system mains or lines shall be paid into the water and sewer operation fund. 
(Code 1958, § 25-1.1; Ord. No. 92-50, § 10, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 93-34, § X, 7-20-93; Ord. No. 2002-28, § I, 6-18-02; Ord. No. 2006-25, § VIII, 7-5-06; Ord. No. 2006-61, § VIII, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2006-62, § V, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2009-30, § IV, 8-4-09; Ord. No. 2014-21, § IV, 9-16-14, eff. 1-1-15) 
Note— Section XIII of Ord. No. 2009-30 states that subsection (a) shall become effective January 1, 2010. 
Sec. 10-1-43. - Deposit fees; disposition of deposit on discontinuance of service; discontinuance and late fee charges for nonpayment of bill; discontinuance for nonpayment of bill to provide deposit fees; to provide for deposits from all customers based on meter size. Effective August 1, 2012. 
(a)  Premises where water and/or sanitary sewer service are provided. Customers applying for service to premises where water and/or sanitary sewer are provided by the city shall be required to make the following cash deposits with the city before water and/or sewer service is begun, based on the meter size at said premise: 
5/8 ″ or ¾″ inside or outside city limits ..... $155.00 
1″ inside or outside city limits ..... 350.00 
1½″, 2″ or 3″ inside or outside ..... 400.00 
4″ or larger inside or outside ..... 500.00 
Upon failure to pay the monthly fees prescribed in subsections 10-1-17(a) and 10-1-41(b), the city shall require additional deposit(s) according to the following schedule: 
First cutoff for nonpayment within a continuous twenty-four-month period, deposit increased to the current deposit rate established for that customer meter size classification. 
Second cutoff for nonpayment within a continuous twenty-four-month period, deposit increased by fifty (50) percent of the current deposit rate established for the customer meter size classification. 
Third cutoff for nonpayment within a continuous twenty-four-month period, deposit increased by one hundred (100) percent of the current deposit rate established for that customer meter size classification. 
(b)  Disposition of deposit on discontinuation of service. Upon discontinuation of water service to a customer having made a deposit, such deposit shall be applied on unpaid water bills of the customer, on the cut-off service fee charged the customer and the balance, if any, shall be applied to any other indebtedness due the city, and the balance remaining, if any, shall be refunded to the customer. 
(c)  Due date established, nonpayment or partial payment of bills grounds for discontinuing service, late payment fee. 
(1)  A due date of twenty (20) days from the billing date for the monthly fees prescribed in section 10-1-17(a) and 10-1-41(b) is hereby established for all classes of water and sewer customers. 
(2)  Utility services to a customer shall be discontinued when one (1) month's bill is ten (10) days past due or when partial payment is made on accounts over thirty (30) days past due. 
(3)  A fee of ten (10) percent of the total monthly bill shall be assessed as a late payment fee for payments received after twenty (20) days of the billing date. 
(4)  No classes of customers shall be exempt from late payment fees, including federal institutions, without the approval of the city manager or designated representative. 
(Code 1958, § 25-1.3; Ord. No. 93-6, § I, 1-18-94; Ord. No. 94-38, § IV, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 99-78, §§ I, II, 11-2-99; Ord. No. 2009-30, § V, 8-4-09; Ord. No. 2012-22, § I, 7-17-12) 
Sec. 10-1-44. - Connection fee. 
(a)  Users subject to fee. Users of the water system shall pay a water connection fee before new or additional service will be made available. Applications for new or additional water service must include the street address for a specific lot or lots where the service is to be provided. Applications for water service shall expire unless all fees have been paid to the finance department no later than ten (10) calendar days after the date of application issuance by the utilities department. Water service approved for a specific lot shall not be transferred to any other lot or property. Water meters shall be installed by the city at the address specified in the application for water service no later than forty (40) days after payment of all fees due by the applicant. Existing users shall be subject to the fee when their existing water service tap is inadequate to deliver the volume of water needed and requires an increase in the water service tap. New users will be subject to the fee at the time new water service is requested through the purchase of a water meter. All users shall be subject to the water connection fee regardless of location (inside or outside city corporate limits) of the water meter. 
(b)  Determination of connection fee. 
(1)  The water system connection fee shall be imposed according to the following schedule: 

 
The water system connection fee shall be paid in addition to the cost of the meter and water system tapping fees. 
(2)  The minimum connection fee for any new water service, regardless of the meter size, shall be one thousand seven hundred twenty-six dollars ($1,726.00). 
(c)  Changing tap and meter size. 
(1)  After the original water connection fee has been paid and installation made, any customer requesting a change in the tap size resulting in a smaller meter at the same location shall make proper application at the water department for this change. Such change shall be made without cost to the customer. No credit shall be given for water connection fees or water meter costs paid on the existing larger meter. The meter removed shall remain the property of the city and shall be returned to the city. 
(2)  After the original water connection fee has been paid and installation made, any customer requesting a change in tap size resulting in a larger meter at the same location shall make proper application at the public utilities department for this change. The customer shall pay a water connection fee equal to the difference between the current applicable water connection fee for the existing water meter size and the current applicable water connection fee for the requested water meter size. A credit of sixty (60) percent of the tap and meter cost applicable to the existing meter in use will be deducted from the tap and meter cost of the increased tap and meter size. The meter removed shall remain the property of the city and shall be returned to the city. 
(d)  Payment of fee. 
(1)  Existing users shall pay the water connection fee at the time the application is made with the water department to increase or decrease the size of the existing water service tap or meter size. 
(2)  New users shall pay the water connection fee at the time the application is made with the water department for a water meter. 
(e)  Revenue restrictions. 
(1)  All revenues received from the water system connection fees shall be accounted for separately and distinctly from any other system revenues. Available water system connection fee balances shall be invested and all interest earned on these investments shall be accounted for as part of the water system connection fee revenues. The accounting system shall be established so that water system connection fee collections, interest earned, and expenses can be clearly tracked on a monthly basis and so that connection fees are properly deposited, accounted for and expended in accordance with section 10-1-44(e). 
(2)  Water connection fee funds shall be expenses only for costs related to system improvements, as defined in O.C.G.A § 36-71-2(19), as amended, that provide capacity to serve new connections to the water system. All costs permitted under O.C.G.A. § 36-71-3(18), as amended, shall be permitted under this section. Such costs include, but are not limited to, planning, design, engineering, land acquisition, land improvement, surveying, and construction or reconstruction costs as well as principal, interest and other financing costs on contracts, bonds, notes or other obligations issued by the city to finance such system improvements. Water connection fee funds shall not be expended for maintenance or repair of system improvements nor for operational expenses. 
(f)  Applicant contributions of system improvements; credits/reimbursements. 
(1)  Project improvements are the responsibility of the developer or property owner and no credits against connection fees shall be made for project improvements. Project improvements include all lot or building improvements necessary to provide service (including for example the building water and cleanout and pre-stubs if required) and main extensions of eight-inch diameter and up to one hundred (100) feet in length from the property line or project boundary as required to connect to the nearest main. Smaller mains of two (2) inches to six (6) inches in diameter may be allowed where the main will permanently terminate within a particular property or project. Project improvements also include any other water system facilities, including but not limited to larger diameter mains extensions, that are planned, designed and are necessary to provide service to a particular development project in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-17-2(14), as amended. Tap and meter costs are covered by the tapping fee imposed pursuant to the Code of the City of Gainesville section 10-1-42. 
(2)  Upon application for new or increased water service, the water connection fee otherwise due shall be reduced by any applicable credits for the contribution of money or dedication of land for or the construction of system improvements, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-17-2(19), as amended, serving the new connection and required or accepted by the city from the applicant or his predecessor in title or interest. System improvements shall be determined based on accepted engineering principles and data produced by a registered engineer. Analysis of the water distribution system shall be performed using the Hardy Cross hydraulic mathematical model. In the event that the amount of credit due exceeds the total water connection fees due, an agreement between the applicant and the utilities department shall govern the amount and timing of reimbursement payments to the applicant. The city shall have the option of reimbursing an applicant by a lump sum payment or periodic payments and from existing funds or from water connection fees collected in the future. 
(3)  The amount of applicable credit/reimbursement, if any, shall be determined based on credible evidence submitted by the applicant on forms provided by the city utility department, which: (a) describes the contribution for which credit/reimbursement is claimed, (b) establishes the original cost and date of the construction, contribution or dedication, (c) identifies the specific development project for which the construction, contribution or dedication was made, including the location, land use, size, number of buildings or number of dwelling units in the original development project, and (d) describes the development project for which the credit/reimbursement against water connection fees is requested, if different from the project described in subsection (c). Credits/reimbursements may not be transferred from one development project to another project. All costs related to submitting the credit/reimbursement application and any additional information requested by the utilities director are the responsibility of the applicant. 
(4)  The director of utilities shall determine the amount of credit/reimbursement due per connection, if any, based on consideration of the original and current or depreciated value of the contribution or dedication, the facilities required to serve the development project, the ability of the contribution or dedication to provide service to other development, and, if the contribution or dedication is determined to be a system improvement which is eligible for credit/reimbursement, the per connection share of the present value of the construction, contribution and dedication. The burden of establishing eligibility for a credit/reimbursement is on the applicant claiming the credit/reimbursement. All costs incurred by the utilities department, including the value of staff time and/or consultant fees as well as expenses, related to applications for credit/reimbursement shall be the responsibility of and charged to the applicant. Regardless of the results of any appeal of a determination of the utility director by the applicant, utilities department costs billed to and paid by the applicant shall not be refunded. 
(g)  Annual report. At least once every year, the director of utilities and director of finance shall jointly prepare a report on the water connection fees. Such report shall include: (1) the total amount of waste connection fees collected during the past fiscal year, (2) the total expenditures and projects funded in part or in whole by water connection fees during the past fiscal year, (3) the water connection fee account balance earned, (4) the water system projects anticipated to be funded in whole or in part by water connection fees, (5) any proposed changes to the water connection fee schedule or water connection fee calculation methodology, and (6) any other recommendations as the director of utilities or the director of finance deem appropriate or as may be requested by the city council. 
(h)  Appeal process. 
(1)  Applicants for a new or changed water meter may appeal any determination of the utilities director regarding the meter or line size required to serve the property or the amount of credits and/or reimbursement due for contributions of system improvements to the utilities review committee. Appeals to the utilities review committee must be filed with the city clerk no later than thirty (30) days after the date of determination by the utilities director. The utilities review committee shall provide the applicant with a written explanation of its determination within sixty (60) calendar days of filing of the appeal with the city clerk. Appeals shall be submitted to the city clerk on a form provided by the utilities department. 
(2)  Appeals and determinations of the utilities review committee may be made to the administrative hearing officer as provided for pursuant to chapter 1-8 of the Gainesville City Code. 
(i)  Authority to establish an administrative fee. 
(1)  A reasonable fee to cover all or a portion of the administrative costs incurred in administering and managing the water connection fee system may be established by resolution of the city council. Such administrative fee may include, but is not limited to, the following costs to the extent the costs are related to the administration and operation of the connection fee system: reasonable charges for city staff time, consultant fees and expenses, and computer equipment/software or other equipment the costs of which are not included in the water connection fee calculations. 
(2)  The administrative fee adopted by resolution of the city council shall be paid at the time of application for new or changed water service and shall be paid in addition to the cost of the meter, water system connection fees and water tapping fees. 
(Code 1958, § 25-1.4; Ord. No. 93-34, §§ I—IX, 7-20-93; Ord. No. 94-55, §§ III, IV, 1-17-95; Ord. No. 95-55, §§ V, VI, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 96-59, §§ III, IV, 12-3-96; Ord. No. 97-66, §§ III, IV, 11-18-97; Ord. No. 00-82, § I, 12-21-00; Ord. No. 2006-25, §§ IX—XII, 7-5-06; Ord. No. 2006-61, §§ IX—XII, 12-19-06)

Deposits will not be refunded for lost or stolen meters. The application fee, deposit, and late read fee shall be as follows:

Sec. 10-1-46. - Charges for discontinuance and resumption of service. 
A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be charged to each customer discontinuing use of city water. A fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be charged to each water customer resuming use of, or applying for new service from the city system. 
(Code 1958, § 25-4.1; Ord. No. 99-69, § I, 10-5-99; Ord. No. 2009-30, § VII, 8-4-09) 
Note— Section XIII of Ord. No. 2009-30 states that this section shall become effective January 1, 2010. 
Sec. 10-1-47. - Charges for reconnection after nonpayment of bill; charges for returned checks. 
(a)  When water has been cut off for the nonpayment of a water bill, or if it is necessary for the service worker to go to the premises for the purpose of cutting water off for nonpayment of bill, the consumer or owner shall pay a charge of forty dollars ($40.00) with payment being made at the utilities department office. In cases where customers have vacated premises leaving unpaid water bills, they will not be furnished with water elsewhere until such bill have been paid. 
(b)  When payment of a water bill occurs with a check which is subsequently returned by the bank or other financial institution upon which it is written, the customer shall pay a returned check charge as provided in section 2-2-1 of this Code to be paid at the water department office. Such charge shall be considered part of the water bill in determining nonpayment under paragraph (a) of this section. 
(Code 1958, § 25-5; Ord. No. 92-50, §§ 11, 12, 11-17-92; Ord. No. 97-26, § I, 5-6-97; Ord. No. 00-98, § I, 1-2-01; Ord. No. 2009-30, § VIII, 8-4-09) 
Sec. 10-1-48. - Cost of extending water service. 
Whenever a water service extension project is undertaken, the cost of such project shall be allocated as hereinafter set forth: 
(1)  City's portion of cost. Whenever the city shall have money appropriated for water service extension projects, it shall participate in financing the cost of approved water service extension projects provided, however, that the city's financial participation in any project shall not exceed the amounts set forth below: 
a.  Residential structure. In the case of projects to serve in-city property, the city shall spend not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each residential structure or equivalent thereof to be served by the project. In the case of projects to serve out-of-city properties, the city shall spend not more than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for each residential structure or equivalent thereof to be served by the project. When a residential structure contains two (2) or more dwelling units, each dwelling unit which has a separate water meter tap shall be counted as a separate residential structure. 
b.  Commercial structures. Whenever a water service extension project is undertaken to serve commercial structures, the city's share of the cost of the project shall not exceed an amount equal to ten (10) times the estimated net annual earnings from the sale of water to the commercial structures to be served by the project. 
(2)  Petitioner's portion of cost. Whenever the estimated cost of a water service extension project is found to be greater than the amount the city is authorized to spend on the project, then the petitioners for service shall be required to pay the difference between the city's authorized portion of the cost of the project and the total cost of the project. 
(3)  Payment in advance. Whenever a petitioner is required to pay a portion of the cost of a water service extension project, he shall make such payment in advance of construction along with other required fees. Such payment shall be deposited into the fund the city has established for water service extension purposes. This payment shall not be refunded. 
(Code 1958, § 25-42) 
Sec. 10-1-49. - Water shortage management surcharges. 
(a)  For first violation of water shortage management restrictions. For the first violation of water shortage management restrictions, water customers in noncompliance with chapter 5-2, article 3 shall be assessed a surcharge of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(b)  For second and subsequent violation of water shortage management restrictions. For a second and subsequent violation of water shortage management restrictions, water customers determined to be in noncompliance shall have water supply terminated and be assessed a surcharge of two hundred dollars ($200.00). Water supply shall not be restored until payment of the surcharge and a reconnection fee as described in section 10-1-47. 
(c)  For egregious violation of water shortage management restrictions. For egregious violation of water shortage management restrictions, water customers shall have water supply terminated and, upon authorization of the director, be assessed a surcharge of up to twenty-five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Water supply shall not be restored until payment of the surcharge and a reconnection fee as described in section 10-1-47. 
(d)  Procedures. 
(1)  The city manager shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this section by discontinuance of water service in the event any person violated the provisions of this section after receiving oral or written notice of the violation from the city. 
(2)  Whenever the city manager determines that a person is violating, or has violated any provision of this section and determines that the violation of this section endangers the public health, safety or general welfare of the community, the city manager shall have the power and authority to immediately terminate that person's water service, which termination shall be in writing. 
(3)  Any person aggrieved by having the water supply terminated by the city manager shall have the right to appeal the termination to the administrative hearing officer as provided in section 1-8-1 within ten (10) days of the date of termination by the city manager. 
(4)  If an appeal is made, then the city manager shall have the power and authority to reinstate the water supply until the administrative hearing officer renders a decision in order to avoid undue hardship, if the city manager is reasonably assured that the violation(s) for which the water supply was terminated will not continue. 
(Code 1958, § 25-77; Ord. No. 89-19, § VI, 5-16-89; Ord. No. 2006-42, § I, 9-19-06; Ord. No. 2007-52, § I, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-1-50. - Water and sanitary sewer permitting/inspection fees; building inspection coordination fee; backflow inspection fee; commercial wastewater inspection fee. 
(a)  Water main and sanitary sewers permitting/inspection fees. For all installations of water mains and sanitary sewers not constructed or contracted by the utility, both inside and outside the corporate city limits, a fee shall be charged for permitting/inspection of the installations to meet utility specifications. The permitting/inspection fee shall be one dollar and forty-nine cents ($1.49) per linear foot for water mains, and three dollars and sixty-two cents ($3.62) per linear foot for sanitary sewers. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  Backflow inspection fee. For all installations of a backflow device on private water service lines connected to the utility's water mains a fee of sixty dollars ($60.00) shall be charged for permitting/inspection of the installation to meet utility specifications. 
(d)  Commercial wastewater inspection fee. For all installations of wastewater sample stations for grease traps and oil-water separators a fee of fifty-five dollars ($55.00) shall be charged for permitting/inspection of the installation to meet utility specifications. 
(Ord. No. 2003-43, § I, 7-1-03; Ord. No. 2004-80, § I, 11-16-04; Ord. No. 2005-35, § I, 7-19-05; Ord. No. 2006-25, § XIII, 7-5-06; Ord. No. 2006-61, § XIII, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2007-27, § IV, 7-3-07; Ord. No. 2009-30, § IX, 8-4-09; Ord. No. 2015-22, § IV, 8-4-15)

The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes.

Sec. 10-1-63. - Alcoholic beverage fees and excise taxes. 
(a)  The amounts imposed for alcoholic beverage annual fees will be set by resolution of the governing body of the City of Gainesville. 
(b)  The amounts imposed for excise taxes in the city are as follows: 
(1)  The malt beverage excise tax imposed pursuant to section 6-4-50 shall be in the following amounts: 
a.  For malt beverages sold in or from a barrel or bulk container (commonly known as tap or draft beer) a tax of six dollars ($6.00) on each container sold containing not more than fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons and a proportionate tax on the same rate on all fractional parts of fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons. 
b.  For malt beverages sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of five cents ($0.05) cents per twelve (12) ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate of all fractional parts of twelve (12) ounces. 
(2)  The wine excise tax imposed pursuant to section 6-4-50 shall be in the amount of twenty-two cents ($0.22) per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate of all fractional parts of a liter. 
(3)  The distilled spirits excise tax imposed pursuant to section 6-4-50 shall be in the amount of twenty-two cents ($0.22) per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate of all fractional parts of a liter. 
(4)  The distilled spirits excise tax imposed pursuant to section 6-4-32 (mixed drinks consumed on premises) shall be in the amount of three (3) percent of the purchase price of the beverage. 
(Ord. No. 94-50, § II, 1-3-95; Ord. No. 99-31, § I, 6-1-99; Ord. No. 2001-40, § I, 7-17-01; Ord. No. 2005-48, § I, 11-1-05; Ord. No. 2006-13, § I, 5-2-06; Ord. No. 2009-29, § I, 7-21-09; Ord. No. 2015-03, § I, 2-20-15; Ord. No. 2017-20, § I, 8-15-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 94-50, § I, adopted Jan 3, 1995, repealed former § 10-1-63, which pertained to alcoholic beverage excise taxes, and added a new § 10-1-63 to read as herein set out. 
Secs. 10-1-64, 10-1-65. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 94-54, §§ I, II, adopted Jan. 3, 1995, repealed former §§ 10-1-64 and 10-1-65, which pertained tax on insurance and vehicles for hire. 
Sec. 10-1-66. - Professionally organized parades. 
In the event the parade is a professionally organized parade, the applicant or the organizer shall pay a fee for such permit of ten dollars ($10.00) per one hundred (100) participants or any portion thereof reasonably estimated to participate and if more actually participate, a supplemental fee to cover such additional participants as though included in the original application shall be due and payable immediately following the parade. In any event, the fee shall not be less than ten dollars ($10.00) for a professionally organized parade. In addition thereto, the applicant or organizer shall post a bond of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per hundred participants or any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 90-38, § 1, 8-21-90) 
Sec. 10-1-67. - Special events. 
An application for a special events permit shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable processing fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to cover administrative costs. 
(Ord. No. 90-38, § 1, 8-21-90) 
Secs. 10-1-68—10-1-80. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-26, § III, adopted Dec. 27, 2013, repealed § 10-1-68 in its entirety, which pertained to Georgia Mountains Center marquee rental and derived from Ord. No. 2001-21, § I, adopted April 3, 2001. 
ARTICLE 5. - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION 
Division 1. - Generally 

Sec. 10-1-81. - Streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  The permit fee for the display or sale of merchandise on streets or sidewalks under section 4-4-15 shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(b)  The fee for a residential driveway or sidewalk under section 4-4-72 shall be two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per lot. 
(c)  The fee for a commercial driveway or sidewalk under section 4-4-72 shall be five dollars ($5.00) per lot. 
(Code 1958, §§ 19-23, 19-60) 
Secs. 10-1-82—10-1-90. - Reserved. 
Division 2. - Building Regulations 

Sec. 10-1-91. - Building code. 
(a)  Fees; construction or alteration. 
(1)  The permit fee for the new construction of a building for a R3 occupancy, as defined in the Standard Building Code, including relocated buildings, shall be based on square footage as follows: 

 
(2)  The permit fee for structures accessory to R3 occupancy as defined in the Standard Building Code, additions to R-3 structures, and alteration or repair of an existing building for R3 occupancy, as defined in the Standard Building Code, shall be as follows: 

 
(3)  The permit fee for the new construction of a building for all occupancy uses (except R3), as defined in the Standard Building Code, shall be based on square footage as follows: 

 
(4)  The permit fee for alteration or repair of an existing building for all occupancy uses (except R3), as defined in the Standard Building Code, shall be as follows: 

 
(b)  Mobile homes, factory-built homes and relocated site-built homes. 
(1)  Mobile homes and factory-built homes shall be charged a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) plus a five dollar ($5.00) occupancy permit for a total of fifty-five dollars ($55.00); 
(2)  An existing mobile home requiring a site inspection will be charged a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for a mobile home site check; 
(3)  Site-built homes being moved from one (1) foundation to another will be charged a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for inspection before being moved; 
(4)  There will be a charge of fifty cents ($0.50) per mile for travel outside of the county for the purpose of such inspection. 
(c)  Re-inspection fees. When the owner or contractor calls for an inspection and the inspector finds that the work is not ready for inspection, a re-inspection fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the first re-inspection and fifty dollars ($50.00) for each subsequent re-inspection will be assessed. All re-inspection fees shall be paid prior to next inspection of said work. 
(d)  Square footage defined. The term "square footage" as used in this section means the square feet of floor area, enclosed or open area, for each separate floor or level including basements, canopies, carports, porches and other area under a roof. A separate building permit shall be issued for each separate structure. 
(e)  Penalty fee. There shall be a penalty of double the price of the permit, in addition to the permit fee, if the permit is not acquired before beginning of work. 
(f)  Occupancy. No residential, commercial or industrial building shall be occupied in the city until all construction is complete and final inspection has been made by the inspection services division, and final approval given. 
(1)  Occupancy permits for residential stick built homes, mobile homes or other residential sites requiring an occupancy permit shall be charged a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00); 
(2)  Occupancy permits for commercial, industrial buildings and new construction or businesses changing company names that require an occupancy permit, but does not require a site inspection, shall be charged a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00); 
(3)  Occupancy permits for existing buildings requiring a site inspection and review for a change in use of the building shall be charged a fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00); 
(4)  Temporary certificates of occupancy for residential and commercial buildings requiring an occupancy permit shall be charged a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00); 
(5)  A certificate of completion may be issued once the final inspection has been completed on any permit and shall be charged a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(g)  Governmental exemptions. Any governmental building shall be exempt from payment of any fee; however, application for inspection services is required. 
(h)  Agricultural exemption. Any non-residential farm or accessory building for agricultural, poultry or livestock uses shall be exempt from payment of any fee except the minimum fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
(i)  Fees; new plan review. All buildings or spaces shall be charged ten (10) percent of the permit fee or one hundred dollars ($100.00), whichever is greater. 
(j)  Fee; building code appeal. Each appeal shall be charged fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(k)  [Signs.] The permit fee for the construction or alteration of a sign shall be based on the square footage as follows: 

 
(l)  [Swimming pools.] The permit fee for the construction of a swimming pool shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) for private swimming pools and fifty dollars ($50.00) for public swimming pools. 
(m)  Change of contractor. There shall be a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) if a contractor is changed on a construction permit. 
(n)  Renewal of expired permit. There shall be a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to renew an expired permit as long as the original applicant is the same. 
(o)  [Re-establish electrical service.] Site inspection to re-establish electrical service that has been disconnected shall be charged a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
(Ord. No. 89-60, § I, 10-2-89; Ord. No. 93-40, §§ I, II, 8-3-93; Ord. No. 96-7, § I, 6-27-96; Ord. No. 96-48, §§ I—III, 11-19-96; Ord. No. 97-27, § I, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 2000-13, §§ I—VI, 4-4-00; Ord. No. 2000-31, §§ I, II, 6-20-00; Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 5-1-12) 
Charter reference— Water, sewers and drains, § 5.12. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 1995 Ga. Laws, p. 4542.
